number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												Pretty much everything there is to say about this game has been said, though I'd like to throw in my two cents as well as address a couple issues I've seen people comment on in some of the reviews. First of all, the game is out of Early Access and is feature complete(to my knowledge), and does have an end-game scenario. It's just not that easy to do. 195 hours in the game and I have yet to "beat" it. Ususally for me the story comes second to the survival gameplay. The story is unique and interesting from what I've uncovered(and read about), though some things can take a long time to complete, and usually I'll die before I come close to completing my objective.This brings me to my second point. The game is hard, yes, but it's not as impossible as some people make it out to be. Jumping right in to the game with no prior knowledge, like I did, will be tough. You'll die quite often until you start to make some sense of the mechanics and gameplay. You will also get unlucky at times and be woken from a dead sleep by a creature which can mess you up bad. But, like I said, it's not impossible. You just need to try new skill combinations and ways of going through the world. Taking the strong/tough perks will allow you to wreck NPCs that you come across, but when you're faced with a life or death story scenario, you may not be as well equipped to deal with dangers as you may have thought. At the time of writing this, I've been playing a no-combat-skills build. I've taken Hacking, Medic, Botany, Lockpicking, Eagle Eye, Tracking, Athletic and Electrician, along with Fragile and Insomniac for the extra points. I've been playing this character for three or four real life days now, and I've gone through at least thirty in-game days. Without dying. Playing like this forces you to reconsider everything you've been doing. Before, I'd walk right up to that feral dog and turn it in to a pin cushion with my bow. Now though, I'm fragile and unskilled at any combat. All I have for protection is a war club, which, in my hands, is about as deadly as a shoe. If I even see a feral dog, I'm headed in a new direction. I've also found out that running away  is ♥♥♥♥ing useful! . I may not be able to kill that guy and eat his body, but I'm alive for another day. And I didn't even need his man meat. I've got the botany skill and can just forage around some forests and fill up on berries. In this current game, I've also not used any noise traps when I sleep, because I don't have the room. I get burdened easy, and only carry a couple small backpacks. Still, I have yet to die. You just need to think a little before commiting to an action. Before I try to get some rest, I hide and wait for a few turns to see if anyone's in the area. If no one has wandered into my camp, I sleep. And since I have insomnia, I usually wake up before anything gets too close to me. I know there's a terrible and unfortunate death waiting for me in the future, but until then I'll keep scouring this wasteland, looking for the RFID spoofing software I need in order to advance a story encounter I have yet to complete.This game isn't for everyone, but for me, it's definitely in my top 5. It's easy enough to pick up and play for 30 minutes of down time, or I can spend hours in the game, completely immersed and elated when I find a text file worth nearly $2000 in a laptop that's been sitting in a building for years, and which would have been useless to me were it not for the hacking trait. If you're undecided, just play the demo or watch some videos. There's quite a bit of content missing from the demo, but you'll get the gist of things and be able to make a more informed decision on whether or not this is your type of game. To anyone buying this game, I sincerely hope you like it, as it's like no other game I've played before, and absolutely one of my favorites. Thanks for the amazing game Daniel, and I am looking forward to your next endeavor.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								You can, and you will die a hundered different ways. I spent hours just wandering through wilderness, trying to find something to warm myself, then I died because of unfiltered water. Another character was a survivalist, not a computer engineer type like the last one, so this time I had plenty of warmth, clean water(because I found cooking pot), food(human meat), and overall was a pretty badass. Died because of insatiable hunger for human meat. PROSRich and deep game with content gradually incoming from devs, really nice post-apo rpg sim, that is a nice retro in post-apo genre.CONSWell... it's early access, so you know what that means. If you're not fan of post-apo, original Fallout games seemed too complicated and old-fashioned, but Fallout 3 was a nice fps for you... I have bad news for ya. If you however want to support devs, so they can continue with this game, and you don't mind that you're buying half empty bottle(with a hope that it will refill later), go for it. Hours of fun, depth not seen in a long time, overall must have for fans of the genre.

content:

Early Access Review
								A solid good game, the style RPGs used to be, before all that skill-tree stuff. Combat is amazing, blow by blow, no numeral damage, just serious wounds. I found myself bashing a guy's limbs with a big rock until I finally hitted his head and he felt unconsciously to the floor. I then proceeded to smash his face in and steal his corpse.Examples aside, this game is passed on post-apocalyptical world, it is focused on scavenging and exploring, and although I haven't progressed much on the storyline I found the game to be just the kind of hardcore I was looking for.If you are into SURVIVAL, TURN-BASED, SCAVENGING and don't care about graphics, this game is worth checking out!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is to classic Fallout what FTL is to those old school space exploration games: it captures the spirit of exploration and survival, and trims it down to a bare bones, super replayable text/simple graphics adventure. While I wish there was more plot to explore, it is early access and more of that is probably coming. The mechanics are fun to play with, the music goes a really long way to selling the mood, and the minimalist visual and mechanic design makes you rely on your imagination in such a manner that, if you're willing to go with it, has a greater sense of place and verisimilitude than the most fancy of graphical productions, (not unlike reading a book). The general lack of plot means I won't be playing as long as classic Fallouts and whatnot, but what time I have spent with this has been super enjoyable. Give it a shot.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game intrigued me the minute I saw it.  I would always play Zork in a huddle with friends, but I was always the only one to beat it.  This led me to be fully engrossed in text based games for years to come.  NEO Scavenger takes text heavy elements that remind me of Zork.  These come into play during the small, but quite enjoyable narrative that the player builds into their game.  The exploration and post-apocalyptic atmosphere also brought back memories of Fallout, but much more serious.  This is by no means a bad thing though because players want a very realistic experience, full of imagery, when playing a text heavy game.  This realism is also extremely prevalent during combat with so many options to choose from depending on skills, gear, etc.  However skills and gear can also heavily limit combat.  This helps the player get a feeling for their character better when role-playing a smart, but incredibly weak character.  This game gets a 9/10 from me because even though it's in my list of personal favorites, it has some faults that limit the game.  These are noticeable if too many mistakes are made on a run, lack of devotion causing boredom, or the always prevalent difficulty curve of rogue-likes.  However, I would recommend this to anyone, regardless of these minor issues, due to the shear number of appealing qualities this game holds that a vast majority of gamers, looking for a new flavored splash of adventure in their games, can enjoy.

								It's an early access game that's been tons of fun to fall into.  There seems to be plenty of content initially, and the game author keeps adding more at a good clip. I like that the game has a 'take no prisoners' attitude.  One minute you're riding high, cart full of goods and a shot gun with *at least* three shells, next thing you know someone hit you in the head with a spear and you're bleeding out.It really makes you think twice about how you're going to play out each encounter, and there are real consquences for bad decisions.

This is fast becoming one of my favorite games of all time. Best 10 bucks i ever spent.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								It is not often you find a roguelike where all the tables are even from the start. Where the skill of you, the player, makes all the difference, and not simply how much time you have spent making your character stronger. That won't happen in this game. On top of all of that, and no matter how much gear you find, how good a weapon you have, how sharp your skills have become. There will always be something that can kill you.As day breaks, I spot hiding in the nearby woods, a creature that is both man and beast. To my luck, I find the target unawares, at rest. Creeping in closer, spear in hand, I get in close, so close, hoping that the beast will not notice. The rain works in my favor here, and before the beast has a chance to act, I pull back and plunge my spear deep into the creatures eye socket. Your life, can end just as easily.After the battle, I take out my trusty pocketknife and get to work, pulling the flesh from the bone, and using my skills to keep the pelt in one piece. Trophy in hand, I sling the pelt over my shoulders. Both as proof of my skills in combat, but also, I will not freeze. Not tonight.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								NEO Scavenger now has my full recommendation.This game has some deep tactical roots to it. A turned based rogue-like where you start off in the most startling position of weakness I could possibly imagine. “Scavenger” is the name of the game but this key aspect and function serves as a means to an end, and that end is survival. You wake up in a cryogenic facility with nothing of use but a hospital gown, medical bracelet. You're soon attacked by a supernatural creature, setting the tone for the brutal reality of survival, which seems to be the biggest note of the game. Notice I didn’t mention any shoes or memories. You’re barefoot and it’s autumn. No way to go through life in my humble opinion. I guess there’s a story about finding your identity or finding out what happened to the world.Sounds interesting, right? Like “28 Days Later” meets “DayZ”. I couldn’t tell you, because basically I’ve spent my hours just trying to survive against... get ready for it... Starvation. Food is scarce. I once savored a small packet of crackers for sustenance. I recently died trying to hunt a dangerous creature in what felt like a very realistic and thought out exchange in combat.Hydration. Water is not as scarce, but takes up storage space and the effects of dehydration can onset quickly leaving you weaker to take on the rigors of survival and ultimately lead to death.Hypothermia. It always seems cold and rainy. One play-through I traveled west for 12 hours and died of hypothermia desperately trying to find some degree of shelter or warmth.Brain damage and severe blood loss. Some people seem to be opportunists in this new and horrifying setting, attacking you on sight. You can try to reason with them or beat them to death or submission. Either way combat has to be dealt with or avoided one way or another. There are also inhumane beasts, such as the dogman who(that?) recently severed an artery in my leg, taking a fluke victory in what was described to me as brutal combat. The turned based combat plays out very interestingly, giving you often unique choices based on your surroundings, tools and skill set. In addition to normal attacks with your weaponry you often have different tactical options in a fight, like a trip or a head-butt. Leaving your opponent stunned and vulnerable is a key to winning conflicts and staying healthy. Wounds need attention and in a very animalistic way you need to learn that just because you can best a being in mortal combat it doesn’t necessarily mean he can be your prey.  The spoils of war are all well and good but damn well better be worth the cost of an open wound or wounded limb.Luckily there seems to be a wide array of technology, pharmaceuticals and med-kits to be found in your mysterious surroundings, everything seems to have something more to it. There's a vast world of crafting, trapping and other skills I've only touched the surface of. Hacking with a laptop can be far more effective than hacking with a cleaver.  Storage plays as big of a roll as anything I have mentioned thus far. I really enjoy the vast inventory options and the various challenges that arrive. The tools available to you in moving your life supporting cargo are just as varied. Plastic bags can be used as a light and spacious backpack but they quickly deteriorate under such use, a true backpack can handle much more rigors. Sleds can be used to drag your sleeping bag and other supplies but is outclassed by a modified shopping cart as a vehicle.Light sources can play a big part in safe scavenging, night time or not. Lighters run out of butane though, and flashlights need batteries. You often consume some of your items durability upon use as you scavenge for that rare useful weapon and equally sparse ammunition. There are some hiccups in this surprisingly immersive experience, like a lack of a local leaderboard and tracking or rating of your statistics and progress. The game doesn’t seem to integrate with windows well on start-up, but this is easily fixable in the settings. The aural potential of this game seems unrealized and the atmospheric tune that plays throughout doesn’t do enough for me. The lack of sound just about the only thing holding me back from having a more immersed experience.The slightly crude graphics and the fact that it is a Java game may be off putting to some, but those willing to look past the amateur feel will be rewarded with a view into this game’s deep, brutal, intelligent soul. The sense and reality of a true, terrifying post-apocalyptic survival setting seems fully represented. Made by Blue Bottle Games, which from what I can tell is just one dude, this frisky indie title feels like a true labor of love towards the bleak reality of our impending doom. 8.5/10

content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
												Highly recommend this game, it is a great survival game as well as it keeps its self interesting with tons of unique events, a couple of very unique locations which your very actions there can lead to profit, horrific injury or even sudden and terrible death, every action you make counts, no way to boil water? take a risk at drinking unidentified water and see if you die or not, hungry as hell nothing to eat? resort to canniblism to much and you go insane, as well as you'll have a faction hunting you down, get to confident? well a couple of dogmen will fix that! This game is great no two playthroughs are the same, each one presents different struggles for you to power through, or die trying, you may spend many days trying to find a pot or can to boil water with to die from waterborne diseases, you may end up being horrificly injured and try to do your best to survive it and end up barely surviving after weeks of hard work, this game is hard and punishing, it will abliterate you just like a real appocalypse will, definetely recomend this game

While I wish there was more plot to explore, it is early access and more of that is probably coming. The mechanics are fun to play with, the music goes a really long way to selling the mood, and the minimalist visual and mechanic design makes you rely on your imagination in such a manner that, if you're willing to go with it, has a greater sense of place and verisimilitude than the most fancy of graphical productions, (not unlike reading a book). The general lack of plot means I won't be playing as long as classic Fallouts and whatnot, but what time I have spent with this has been super enjoyable. Give it a shot.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game intrigued me the minute I saw it.  I would always play Zork in a huddle with friends, but I was always the only one to beat it.  This led me to be fully engrossed in text based games for years to come.  NEO Scavenger takes text heavy elements that remind me of Zork.  These come into play during the small, but quite enjoyable narrative that the player builds into their game.  The exploration and post-apocalyptic atmosphere also brought back memories of Fallout, but much more serious.  This is by no means a bad thing though because players want a very realistic experience, full of imagery, when playing a text heavy game.  This realism is also extremely prevalent during combat with so many options to choose from depending on skills, gear, etc.  However skills and gear can also heavily limit combat.  This helps the player get a feeling for their character better when role-playing a smart, but incredibly weak character.  This game gets a 9/10 from me because even though it's in my list of personal favorites, it has some faults that limit the game.  These are noticeable if too many mistakes are made on a run, lack of devotion causing boredom, or the always prevalent difficulty curve of rogue-likes.  However, I would recommend this to anyone, regardless of these minor issues, due to the shear number of appealing qualities this game holds that a vast majority of gamers, looking for a new flavored splash of adventure in their games, can enjoy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								I stumbled across this game while searching through for survival games. I took a look at the screenshots, and wasn't drawn to this game at all, however I saw there was a demo, and so decided to give it a go. To my surprise, I loved it almost instantly. It's different, something unexpected in this day and age of games. After playing the demo for 20 minutes I knew I wanted to buy it, and so I did. It's a very reasonable price, in my eyes, for what you get in the game, I could easily spend hours on this game at once. The main challenge? Surviving for longer than you did the time before. The map is sort of half randomised, the main places of interest always in the same place, but forests, hills, towns, all completely random, so there's always something slightly different at the start of the game.Yes it's in early access, and maybe there'll be some more added to the storyline, maybe some more items, but for me it feels almost finished already, all full package, and I would totally reccommend at least trying the demo for this game. Give it a chance, even if you think you won't like it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
Early Access Review
								This game is unlike any I have played in the last two decades. I recommend it to anyone who wants a turn-based hex RPG. Set in a post-apocolyptic Lovecraftian Michigan, your character emerges from a crygenic vat to step into a race against time. You can die from dehydration, starvation, disease  and hypothermia, in addition to wounds inflicted by the various denizens surrounding the Motor City's wastelands. This hard setting is further amplified by the decision not to include a leveling system. Each time you play, you learn more about the game mechanics and possibilities. You can augment your character with four of a dozen advantages, as well as about six disadvantages. Thes combination of these influence your play style, as some opportunities only present themselves to those with a given trait. For those who love to play first-person shooter "RPG" as murder hobos, this is not the game for you. It is more reminiscent of games from the late 1980s and early 1990s in that it tells its story in a piecemeal fashion with only one Rouge-like save option. While you can engage in combat, you will frequently die. Stealth, scavanging and crafting reveal much more of the story, and further contribute to the desperation as you try to unravel not only how you came to be cycled out of the cryogenics tank, but also what happened to create this near-future landscape. Expect to die a lot. And enjoy it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								That game is now in my favorite games ever played.It's one of those rare games that you get a feeling of accomplishment when you get some valuable loot and manage to keep it for a long period of time. Even if you die and have to start back from the cryo lab and the beginning is always the same, it's really easy to have a completly different experience while you play. You will never encounter the same enemy during your first travel to one place and you will really need luck to survive some obstacles (for example, someone steal all your stuff while you sleep, including your clothes. The amount luck you'll need to survive that is really really big).You know that you've progressed in this game when you look back at the main event that happened during your journey. From when you left that cryo lab with only a hospital gown with you and when you just killed 5 dogman with your rifle and your compound bow.Speaking of combat, this is one of the games where you feel more cruel when you kill someone than in a FPS game, and you dont even see it happen! It's just click and hope to read something that is good for you! Even if you are not reading a book each time you use an attack, you'll feel very cruel when you'll read that he died by lung bleeding, so you basically caused him to drown in his own blood.Anyway, go buy this game now! Its really worth it!15/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												This game is great!  Paid for itself the first day.  Ultimate replayability, the crafting system is excellent, no lack of challenge and great stories.  I feel like this should be the alpha version of this game as there is soooo much potential here.  Stirke a deal with sid meyer's if you can, but either way this game needs to be much bigger and available everywhere. Needs more spawn locations, add animated battle sequences (though I wouldn't mess too much with the battle system you've got), more craftables (this suggestion will never change, you can never have too many craftables), online maps, more gangs, recruit a crew and start your own gang and the obvious one, upgradeable and interchangeable skills.  I realize this game has just recently released and not a moment too soon.  Despite my long list of suggested improvements for future patches/releases, this game is a solid WIN!  (though I did manage to sneak past most of the story line and beat the game by wandering to the north, so you might want to address that too).  I highly recommend to everyone who enjoys turn-base, post-apocalyptic and/or crafting survival, styles. I would buy it as a phone app too.  Keep up the good work guys and gals!  and never forget about us mac gamers.  We know we're a pain to accomodate, but we need the mac for work (most of us) and I lose out on money to sacrifice disk space to run games, but that's our level of dedication.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								You can, and you will die a hundered different ways. I spent hours just wandering through wilderness, trying to find something to warm myself, then I died because of unfiltered water. Another character was a survivalist, not a computer engineer type like the last one, so this time I had plenty of warmth, clean water(because I found cooking pot), food(human meat), and overall was a pretty badass. Died because of insatiable hunger for human meat. PROSRich and deep game with content gradually incoming from devs, really nice post-apo rpg sim, that is a nice retro in post-apo genre.CONSWell... it's early access, so you know what that means. If you're not fan of post-apo, original Fallout games seemed too complicated and old-fashioned, but Fallout 3 was a nice fps for you... I have bad news for ya. If you however want to support devs, so they can continue with this game, and you don't mind that you're buying half empty bottle(with a hope that it will refill later), go for it. Hours of fun, depth not seen in a long time, overall must have for fans of the genre.

								Neo Scavenger.Where to begin...A game set in a post apocalyptic wasteland where everything is out to kill you however unlike most apocalyptic games it is set in the pen/paper style of dungeons and dragons.In addition it is by far one of the most realistic survival games out there including dirty water,medical illnesses and poisoned food.If you like hardcore games, apocalyptic games and other along those lines this is the game for you and if it isn't then at least check out the demo!!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Really great game. VERY addictive, so if you don't have much time to play games this may not be for you. Even in early access this game is very polished and I have yet to encounter a single bug. The choices you make during character creation significantly impact the way you play, and the threat of death from a variety of sources is omnipresent. Although the game is fairly complex, it's also pretty easy to get into because everything works as one would expect it to. For instance, I didn't need a guide or anything to figure out how to craft a campfire on my first attempt. That's not to say this game is easy, far from it: you are pretty much guaranteed to die a few times pretty quickly until you get the hang of things, but deaths in this game don't feel cheap or frustrating and I've never had a death that I didn't learn something from. Pretty much everything in this game is solid; the only thing I could say I want is more content because I have so loved what I have experienced that I want more.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												This is quite possibly the most well-thought-out game I've ever had the pleasure of experiencing. I can't speak from experience as to how accurate this game nails the zombie apocalypse because personally I have not been in one, but from the fact that I'm a zombie fanatic I can say this game is quite realistic when it comes to living in a wasteland.You wake up in a cryogenic facility with something (You later find out it's one of the game's meany creatures, a Dogman) trying to break in. You select your skills and use them to your advantage to defeat the beast, and then you are sent into the massive and unforgiving world that is NEO: Scavenger.This game absolutely nails scavenging. You search around for ages finding useless, irrelevant items such as string and broken glass bottles but that feeling of pure, unadulterated satisfaction when you find some of the more useful items such as a backpack or especially a crowbar, is amazing. Don't get me wrong, this game is unforgiving. As you'll read down below, someone didn't feel like boiling the water they found, got cholera, and died. That's the kind of thing you have to expect on a daily basis from this game. I once forgot to set my noise trap and was murdered by a guy with a meat cleaver in my sleep. I had a shotgun and a noise trap, but it was in my backpack and I didn't feel like getting it out. Another time, I shot and killed a deer, took the meat, put it in my backpack and forgot to cure it, and proceeded to eat it a few hours later after it had spoiled. I got some sort of weird disease and died after hours of diahorrea and blood loss. And while it's unforgiving, it's ultimately very satisfying to play. You find youself getting killed, cursing the game out, and then coming back a few hours later for seconds. And that one rare playthrough where you don't die a horrible, painful death, you just feel awesome. I have tons of screenshots I've taken of the various times when I've had a surplus of stuff.Also the developer, Daniel, is always reaching out to his fans. I'm personally friends with him here on Steam because I wanted to ask a question, so I shot him a friend request and he responded.If you are thinking about getting this game, get this game.If you are not thinking about getting this game, get this game.If you hate this game with a passion, get this game.If you're going to propose to your SO, buy them this game and put it in a virtual box.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												You know those survival first person games like Rust, Day Z, The Forest, etc., etc., etc.,? This game is hundreds of times more complex, yet somehow easier to play and more enjoyable. Sure, there's no multilayer, but you don't need it. Not only does it have the perfect lonely, post apocalyptic vibe pulsing through it the entire time you play it, it also has a wonderful cyberpunk sense of a style and flair.It's not perfect, the UI and Crafting can be a ♥♥♥♥♥ to learn, some skill don't line up how you want them too, but it's worth every penny you spend on it.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												A great turn-based survival game with a smart combat system and a slowly unfolding story to guide you along. The interface looks daunting but is actually fairly accessible. It's very difficult, but even repeating the early sections of the game before you reach the main (as far as I know) hub doesn't feel repetitive because of how large the possibility space is. If you don't enjoy watching yourself slowly die over the course of 30 turns because of one dumb, easily preventable mistake, probably not the game for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
												So far this is an okay game it's pretty rough for most new players since every choice you make might lead to your character death and I've kept dying but that's because I've been learning it the hardway, if you go around and look at a few let's play and read some of the Guides you'll find the game somewhat easier.I've been playing this game for a while now and after a while it does get a bit repetitive I keep trying to explore places but find it lacking in content could be just me.It's an okay game overall, I had a great adventure and even manage to write a story about it! Enjoy!**Story may contain Spoiler**This is the story of my latest adventureDay 1: I woke up in a strange facility, I have no clue who am I and why am I here.. Suddenly! Surprise Dogman appeared! I beat the living s**t out of it like there was no tomorrow until it stopped twitching.It was a good work out I don't remember when was the last time I had a work out or if I even work out at all. My stomach made a rumbling noise so I went to search the place for food but only found a green bag with a white cross sign inside it was just a bunch of dumb pills.. I stared at the dead dog like creature feeling somewhat regretful for killing.. perhaps it was just trying to help me.. So I chopped his body into pieces and brought some wood from the nearby forest to make fire to cook it."This is what it would've wanted me to do" I thought to myself silently thanking it for becoming a meal and a coat but also silently hating it at the same time for not bringing any condiments with it.After satisfying my stomach I went to stroll into the nearest town looking for any sign of civilization but nobody was here the streets were empty and ocassionally I'd see a few skeletons laying around, perhaps it's halloween and they're having a huge hide and seek event.. YES! that could only be the most logical reason!I looked around inside buildings ocassionally taking items with me "I'm just gonna borrow this stuff I'm sure they wouldn't mind" I thought to myself as I grabbed as much stuff as I could carry.It was starting to get dark and I was afraid if a stranger would walk up to me and offer me a sugar free candy, so I went back to the facility I woke up in and decided to call it home.I saw a faint glow of light in the distance and I knew it.. they were hiding from me.. nobody hides from me.. nobo.. *falls asleep* zzzZZZzzzZZZzz...Day 2: I had a good sleep last night but my stomach was beginning to complain again.. I went out and made myself a hardened spear before heading out any further.. just in case I encounter any stranger danger..As I headed out toward where I last saw the glow of light I spotted more Town! as I sprinted toward the town I came across a friendly stranger.He was carrying a revolver he must be dressing up as a cowboy and he was also wearing a pair of croc so I asked him to give me all of his stuff because my stuff sucks, but he refused and start to charge at me, The nerve of some people I tell you! So I poked him on the head with my sharp stick, he fell and was crawling away from me as he beg for mercy so I gave him what he wanted and kept poking him with my sharp stick until he was no longer in pain.I was pretty happy that I could borrow his croc I saw that cool kids wear these kind of sho- err sandals..? what ever it is.. the cool kids on the old worn out poster wear it so I'm a cool kid now.OH! and he also had an expired cracker and some ketchup! So I hack him and whack him and chop him since there's no point to let him go to waste no siree! he would've want me to eat him or else he would've told me stories about starving childrens in some distant foreign land! So being the civilized human being I am, I cooked him as best as I could with the few ingridients he had on him that I'm sure would've made Gordon Ramsay proud.Today was a good day I said to myself as I went to sleep.Day 3: A noise woke me up today.. it was a guy! He tried to take my precious empty bottle in the corner! “My Precious!!!” I shouted as I charge toward him and knocked some debris toward him, the debris made him vulnerable and as he tries to recover I stabbed him with my sharp pointy stick and carved a hole in his right arm.I kept stabbing him with my pointy stick as I hissed at him aggressively, nobody touches my precious! Nobody but me!I lacerated, gashed and carved him into pieces there was no mercy.. it was the sacrifice my precious neede- Oohh!! He had a crowbar! Now I can dress up as Gordon Freemsay the Angry crazy canibalistic chef with a Phd!And so I ventured out as Gordon Freemsay! Suddenly 3 Dog appeared! I knew it.. I should’ve double tapped him when I last met him at Galaxy News Radio.. now he reappeared before me as an actual 3 Dog! So I demolished one of the closest dog’s head using my crowbar! That really got the attention of the other 2 Dog and again I demolished the other dog head, it seem that knocked some sense to the last dog as it tries to fall back from me but it knew.. it knew it was too late.. it knew that it had done f**ked up and “WHACK!!” that was the last thing it heard.. “nobody.. mess with Gordon Freemsay..” I said to it in a silent hiss.As I went on my way I was again approached by more meanies.. they just don’t know when to quit..After slaughtering about 2 more Dog and 2 Stranger with an angry mother issue, I went off to go shopping for a sauce pan and back pack and found a cool sled and since I’m not a thief I left my plastic shopping bag with some rotting left over cooked human meat as a trade in case the owner came back.It was another great day, I cooked some water from a nearby lake so I can wash my boo-boo away and bottle some more in case I made some more boo-boo.I also did an art and craft project by stringing small can with a handful of strings and pebbles it made music if people step or trip on them! It will be a great addition to my house!Day 4: My art and craft project ringed in the middle of the night.. *sigh* I guess it’s time for a midnight snack, it was a dogie! “Chinese food it is then” I lured it into a trap but it still managed to scratch my coat before I stabbed a new nose into it’s lung and bled all over the floor.Great.. now I’m gonna have to clean that up.. *sigh* why do they have to make things difficult I grumble to myself as I enjoy my midnight snack and went back to sleep but as soon as I closed my eyes another stranger ringed my welcome bell.. I got up and quickly took cover.. I couldn’t see where or who this stranger was so I lashed out and swinged my sharp pointy stick wildly to where I think he’s at but this stranger managed to shred my upper left leg, I fell to the ground and just then I knew.. I done goofed.. and all the horrible things I’ve done.. I’ve become a monster.. and I didn’t want to acknowledge that.. I was in denial all this time.. this is it.. my time has finally come.. I am ready.. do your worst Karma.. and just like that I passed out.....Everything was silent.. I woke up.. there was a bright light as if the sun was shining upon me.....Wait a minute.. it actually is the sun! And sure enough! there he was.. The f**ker that tried to kill me! Laying on the ground with a hole in his chest.. Boy~! I sure didn’t learn a single thing from that experience so I cut that f**ker up and ate him. It sure was a glorious day in this man army! And it was pretty nice of him to bring me a hunting rifle with a scope, strap and there's even a bullet in it aww that's so sweet of him.I enjoyed the rest of the day munching on the left over while reading the outdated newspaper man.. I wish I had some fava beans and a nice chianti to go with this live- shh!! There were noises outside.. and sure it was another stranger waiting in the nearby outskirt of the forest.. and so Gordon Freemsay continues his rampage in this post-apocalyptic world..

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Very engrossing survival game where it actually feels like you struggle to survive. You have to watch what you eat and drink, make sure you’re clothed properly, and as the title suggest, scavenge the world for supplies and materials. Every time you play it's different, and it can come down to skill and some luck. There are interesting skills that provide you with a variety of crafting options that may otherwise be unavailable, or perks such as the ability to find more loot, get better information on your medical state, or craft certain items. Pretty good story (although I haven't gotten very far because I die a lot :D) Highly recommend to anyone who is into more hardcore survival games. The interface seemed strange at first, but after a few tries the combat and exploration became very engrossing, which I was not expecting from the screenshots. Highly recommended!

												This game is amazingly good. But it is also HARD AS SH**. Never been able to survive longer than 2 weeks. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have spent years looking for a true survivor game, one that didn't have a core around zombies or a nuclear wasteland, and starting out with nothing but basic cloths and skills. You have to scavenge, craft, and use your wits to survive. There has only been one game that has ever done it right, and this is it Neo Scavenger.Neo, is and has been my favorite indie game for the last several years, it's difficulty is brutal but not unfairly so, you need to think and use your skills to survive, as a single fight you were sure to win, could end in a second as your attacker trips you and kick your head in. This is not a game around fighting to live, it's a game about making the right choice at that moment just to live another day. Even if you die, you want to jump right back in, so pick up a copy today. No really, right now, this game is worth every penny of $10, and guess what? It's not even done yet. This game has my 100% backing and support.Look forward to:Amazing atmosphereCrafting is expansive and rewardingYour skills will define how you will surviveendless hours of addicting and amazing gameplayDifficult until you get used to how things works in this world. Noobs beware.You will die, again and againTheArmoredOwl score9/10 must own!This game receives one of my only and first platinum feathers

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								(Disclaimer: English is not my native language, expect some typos and grammar errors.)Oh my.... Where do I start?I came to find this game thanks to ''James Recommends'' from Extra Credits. So I knew that, based on his review, this game was going to be good. But... when I played it, I realized that my expectatives of ''Good'' were an utter underestimation. The game wasn't ''Good'', it was ''DAMN EPIC!!''.For a game with less than 100MB of size, this game stands WAAAAAY HIGHER than many Million Dollars AAA titles when it comes to survival; not even Fallout:New Vegas or State of Decay can hold a candle to NS when it comes to TRUE SURVIVAL. Which, when combined with Rogue-like makes for a WHOLE NEW GAME every time you play it; one in which you can never know if you'll succeed or fail until either of them shows up (Like when I found the Crowbar, some Binoculars and a Sauce Pan on the first town and I thought I was winning, only to freeze to death because I never found any shoes or clothes).Unlike in those games where you charge into a group of enemies with just a knife and an angry roar, knowing that if you die, you can just hit the Load Save button, in this game, you gotta think out real carefully each of your moves. Just as you would do if you were in the player's shoes (or bare feet). This makes the game feel extremely real and complex. ''Do you sneak up on that scavenger to kill him while he's asleep to steal his shoes and his gun? You already know that almost every gun you see lacks ammo, but what if this one's loaded? What if you trip on something and wake him up? You could end up losing all you've gathered so far, and there's a high chance you won't encounter most of that stuff again.''That's the feeling you get. And that's not something I've been able to feel with any AAA titles.Just a warning, tho; be prepared to die a thousand times, even right after the start. More than once I stepped into the first area just to be torn to shreds by a Feral Dog.My only critics to this game are the following:-Crafting Instructions are just too vague.The crafting system's utterly complex, but the instructions and recipes are even worse. You can't just figure out what do they say or what do they require until you go read the wiki. Perhaps if the items had some sort of Status Screen that told you what properties do they have, it'd be much easier to do this, as just figuring it out can take THOUSANDS of tries.-The Full Map is too hard to understand.At simple glance it looks just like a 300% Zoom on a SNES-era Sprite. You can't even tell what's what and even those places that are marked, it's hard to make out WHERE is the mark, as all you see is a big word. (Dunno if the iSlab or Smarphone's GPS Apps make it look better. Never gotten any of those.). I know this must be hard to do with a randomized map, but right now, there's just no real purpose to use the Full Map other than locating the Glow.-The Full Bottles' colors are confusing.Whiskey are orange-colored when full of whiskey, but also when full of water. Same goes for the Corn-a-Colas which are yellow. This can lead to a lot of confusion at the time of picking up stuff or even drinking. More than once I've been carrying around whiskey bottles filled with both water and whiskey and I've accidentaly drank Whiskey because I thought it was water and got drunk, which often led to death. This issue can be easily fixed with a couple palette swaps, so I hope it's fixed by the time the game leaves Early Access.-MOAR STUFF!No, seriously, this game needs more stuff, it's already cool enough as it is, but it could be even cooler. The current Item Pool is just too small for such a neigh-infinite world of random possiblities, so it's a bit sad that, once you manage to get some clothes and shoes to stay alive, they're almost always THE SAME. (Your shoes, the Hoodie, three shirts, some Cargo Pants and a Backpack if you're lucky are what you always end up wearing.). A game this big should have at least twelve variants of every piece of cloth or shoes.Aside from those, I have no other complains. This game has the markings of an Indie Masterpiece, and so far, it hasn't let me down. So I hope it has become even more of a Masterpiece by the time it leaves Early Access.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								I discovered this game through a blog post linked through Kerbal Space Program about how failure can be a good element of a game. Obviously, this raises a big flag about the difficulty of the game. I enjoy realism and brutal challenge in games though, so I investigated and tried the demo on their website. I loved it. It's basically a classic rogue-like, but takes place in post-apocalyptic michigan.I've died from the coldI've died from infectionI've died from lootersI've died from thirstI've only played for a few hours and already chalked up an impressive range of tragic ends. Each time you die, you take away a valuable lesson on survival in the games harsh, unforgiving world. Any fans of difficult rogue-likes or open-world adventure games should DEFINITELY check it out.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								A nice premise - old style hex adventure, but with the usual apocalyse scenario.Its far from easy, for example anyone thinking of rushing headlong against mobs the moment you start should think again or you will die, and it will happen often. Sneak around scavenging for clothing, weapons... craft those bits of junk into something useable. Then go out again - you'll still get killed, but perhaps less often. This is a game of learning and trial & error. You will learn as you die. And you will learn as you survive. Its something of a slow burner. You WILL come back to it after a period of frustration. It'll sit there somewhere in your mind, suggesting you have another go - maybe this time...Permadeath has to be in the game or would essentially ruin the story, and essentially this is the driving force - this game can be replayed with different information based on your skillset - perhaps some things that would be hidden would be revealed.I feel some things that need improving - crafting for example is good, but would be best if it remembered every combination you'd come up with from previous games (rather like the old son of in the old rogue type games. This has some previous recipes but not many, and trying to remember them all yourself is absurd.Also something that (I think) needs changing to a degree is the way loot is calculated - many times you can obtain a hoard from scavenging with almost no chance to gain anything, but then you can repeatedly find nothing when you have a good chance. Certain skills improve or reduce this, but I think too much in some cases.Basically here is a potentially good game, which needs many more refinements before it can really be considered complete.I enjoy this sort of game, but I really wonder if I'm actually anything better than totally rubbish at them. The fact is that despite any faults - any time you have what you deem to be a completely unfair death or when you were just starting to do well for once then along comes... a big nasty monster... at least you have the knowledge of what doesnt work next time, or a different skill to pick - maybe you'll endure the early multitude of deaths and finish the game - perhaps I really am rubbish at it, maybe it (the game) needs balancing, or maybe it always will be just a tad too hard.In conclusion:I'd play it more if I didnt die as often, if I got to see slightly more of the story.All too often you go through the initial stages then die in a low level battle. Perhaps if you were just left sometimes with your stuff robbed - at least you had a little chance...7/10 (with potential to be 9/10)**SPOILER ALERT**Leave the talisman alone.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is a bit of a hard sell at first. The user interface is not exactly intuitive, and the graphics are nice but a bit retro.If you overcome these initial scepticisms though, what you'll find is a game that is a mixture of "A dark room" (minus the initial set-up phase), "Minecraft" (minus the blocky 3d graphics) and any Rougelike (so expect to die frequently).The basic setup is always the same: you wake up in some kind of cryo-lab, and the world outside has turned into a post-apocalyptic dystopia similar to "The Walking Dead" or "28 Days Later".You have to find out about your own past and uncover the secret of what happened to the world.You walk around the landscape on hex-grids, scavenging the woods or the remains of long-gone cities for clothes, food, water and weapons, while avoiding (at least initially) other NPCs or animals, most of which want to see you dead. You can craft things together with recipes you find scattered around randomly, and from time to time you find pieces of newspapers which tell you a bit about what has happened.The environment is highly dynamic, you have different weather patterns which impact your sight (when you find a scope or binoculars, you can even increase your visible range), and many other scavengers are roaming the area on their own (one nice example: I once found a corpse, looted it and moved his stuff into my hideout, just to find him chopped to bits of meat when I came back the next day... and of course the killer was not far off and killed me a few minutes later...)The story unfolds bit by bit (you have to survive the first night to even get an idea on where you should be moving), and even though I not yet come very far in the story yet (did I mention it is very easy to die in this game?) it is a game I will keep on coming back for "just one more try..."The only downside (IMHO) is that there is no way of saving the game (except for the "save&quit" function), so every death is permanent. And since it's written in Flash there's no easy way of getting the save data out for bakup purposes. But that just shows that it's a real Roguelike at heart...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								Well well well.  Now this is something quite good and interesting.This game has pleasently took me by surprise and I'm enjoying whats on offer so far.  Best way I can sort of explain this, is basically a Tactics style game with Text Adventure Role Playing elements set in an apocolyptic environment, coupled with...I guess Day Z/Rust style scavenging.I'm only just starting to understand the basics of the game, however it is quite enjoyable.  Basically you are person thats escaped from a facility and you must try and uncover who you are.  To do this you must survive going through the world and scavenging stuff that you need.  To do this, you enter locations and you must decide if its worth it to scavenge there or not.  You may find nothing or the mother load!...or a trap and a jackass waiting to cave your skull in with a crowbar.I like how my first OMG YES!! moment was when I found a backpack so I could carry more stuff.  I guess thats the best part of it.  The thrill of finding those essential bits and pieces that you need and surviving those moments where you are attacked.The combat requires you to be thoughtful and tactical, until someone gives in or dies.  So you have to read the text box to see what is going on in that fight and do what you can accordingly.  One mess up and you are done.I like whats been done with this game.  You get the feel that everything is your enemy, from the human, the creatures and the world itself.  Hell you are just as likely to freeze to death as you are to be bludgeoned to death.  It will keep you on your toes.Give this a game a try, it will keep you engrossed for a long time and for what...a 60-70MB download?  I'm behind that all the way.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
NEO Scavenger is a turn-based survival RPG released by Blue Bottle Games in late 2014. The player roams a post-apocalyptic Michigan, simply trying to survive. The game is tile-based, with a complex combat system that is entirely described through text.  The combat system is one that sticks out. It's somewhat reminiscent of the original Wasteland, but instead of a hit point system, damage is actually done to the combantants.The commands are a little more complex than a lot of systems, if you're knocked down, for instance, you can either get up, roll away, or grab the enemy by the ankles and pull 'em down. Most combat is completely optional too, you can sneak away, talk your way out of it, or simply avoid it in general.Plenty of skills and flaws are selectable from the start, and more skills are able to be obtained later in the game. This encourages trial and error, which is more acceptable in this, considering the survival mechanics, as opposed to a more traditional RPG with cutscenes and dungeons you have to go through in the beginning. Speaking of survival mechanics, they're fantastic; this game is the survival game I've been waiting for. Food and water can be obtained in a myriad of ways. The crafting system is really general, so materials can usually be substituted for others, as opposed to needing very specific things.The quite clear flaw to all this (at least to some people) is almost unavoidable, and it's that it's not a casual-friendly experience. It's not extremely hard to get into, but a lack of experience and foresight is bound to get you killed on occasion. The randomness of your start also might decide your fate more-so than your skill, depending on the direction you go, but this was either pretty easy to bounce back from, or simply rare.ProsSurvival mechanics are pretty lifelike and full of depth.Combat is complex, and completely option if you decide you don't want to.Easy to pick up and play, but still a pretty deep and lengthy game if you aren't as bad as I am.ConsNot casual-friendly, although if you put a little time, thought, and elbow grease in it, you shouldn't have too many problems.Random map can screw you over early game on occasion. Final Thoughts:If you like survival games, or late-eighties CRPGs like Wasteland, than you'll find a pretty polished combination that's certain to pull quite a few hours out of you.Rating: 9/10This review was written for and is published on the  Lit Reviews [LR] curator page.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2016
												Attend the tale of Phillip Kindred, who died as he lived: partially clothed, dragging a sled, and fighting off an infection.NEO Scavenger is mean. It's unfair. It's cruel. It's grisly. The odds are stacked against you and odds are you won't make it a week. It's also one of the most fun procedural RPGs I've ever played.It's certainly not perfect. The UI is clunky at best and deeply confusing at worst (remind me to tell you about the time I accidentally ate spoiled human flesh) and the story, while it starts strong, peters out to an ending that hints at a design cycle that ended with exhaustion rather than completion.Still, NEO Scavenger is otherwise a remarkable and very well thought-out foray into a mythical, post-collapse Michigan with tons of interesting worldbuilding details and enough entertainment value to last you for a long, long time.

												Yeah it's hardish.. perma death with limited resources and an environment that can kill you easily (hypothermia, stavation, thirst)...all good stuff for an RPG in theory... but ultimately it's needlessly repeative in combat coupled with constant random encounters day and night that will probably kill you, mix with perma death and it makes a frustrating and somewhat boaring game due to so much "try 'n die". To give you an idea of the game, I survived a few  days finally and ran into a guy who  I traded the medalion your character has for a rifle (fair trade and no warning about the risk) and apparently  that means I get a MergaWriaththat follows me until it kills me... yeah that sort of thing in a game is♥♥♥♥♥♥poor design and serves no purpose other than the kill player so they keep the medallion until the end game. But without a wiki to tell I should not have traded it, I would not know this until the second or third time I got the MergaWriath...Is it worth the purchase price ($5) I paid? Well I've played it for a couple of hours so it was cheaper than a movie......But probably less enjoyable, I doubt I'll play it much due to the frustration levels it does bring to the RPG genre.It is aimed at hard core rpg gamers who like to die a lot and often for reasons beyond their control....

content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's hard to stop hitting the retry button on this game. While there's no hand-holding in this survivalist/sci-fi RPG, every loss gives you a bit of knowledge about how to survive better on the next playtrough. While most everything about the game is minimalist (lofi-graphics and text/icon turn-based combat), the game's approach to describing characters and events forces you to assess your decisions not based on a sheet of numbers or a cookie-cutter game sprite, but on what you know about your capabilities, and what you can see of the problem(s) you face. It's a great aesthetic that forces you to be your character instead of just playing them. It's a great game, and getting better.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												This is one of my favorite games of all time. If you liked Fallout 1 and 2, and you like survival and roguelike games, I think you'll love this. It's dark, creepy, atmospheric, insanely detailed and can be morbid beyond belief. Don't judge the screenshots - buy this game. Note: I played this off steam, that's why my game time is low. I probably hit triple digits in reality.Had some of my most memorable gaming experiences with NEO Scavenger while it was in Alpha, and weirdly enough it wasn't even anything dramatic, just stalking deer and making jerky, exploring and braving the elements with my prized and carefully assembled "kit" of equipment, feeling like a badass survivor in a totally harsh and unforgiving world. In another playthrough, some truly weird♥♥♥♥♥♥went down in an abandoned insane assylum turned cultist haven: At the door, I gave up my prized kit in exchange for a hospital gown, got involved in some crazy masochistic, self-flagellating religious nonsense and cultist court intrigues, left on strange and uncertain terms, and then got shot outside the gates (left me absolutely speechless, like, WTF just happened?)Quests go weird. Enemies can be unpredictable. Strange things can happen. Emergent gameplay up the whazoo.This game offers so much all at once... The detail in it is enough to sattisfy your worst OCD compulsions, because this game has the most detailed inventory management of probably any game ever made (plastic bags that you can crumple up and put in pockets, pill boxes you can stock with individual pills, batteries that you can stock and charge with individual electric cells, etc.) It also has a really detailed and fairly simple to use crafting system, with absolutely tons of stuff. Just ridiculous amount of stuff, much more available through mods.The atmosphere and tone is almost uniquely morbid. This is not necessary or recommended, but hypothetically you can kill someone with a sharpened stick, then carry their body to the woods, carve up the body into steaks and make canibal pemmican. That is outrageous, and disturbing, and just knowing the game lets you do that (though I think discourages it somehow), that in itself gives the game a uniquely dark tone (something about the graphic of the enemy's courpse, lying crumpled on its side, taking up your entire inventory and overburderning you, man that image got like burned in my mind I think). There are randomly generated scripted events and RPG/Adventure type of quests, choices, storylines. And the writing is actually good, I would even say excellent. These are optional though, so you can kind of "sandbox" it if you want. Anyway, I've sunk weeks into this game and enjoyed it tremendously, back when it wasn't even complete.Cons: - None, really. - After countless hours, combat can get a little repetetive.- Of course, the interface is pretty clunky and strange in some respects, so while on the one hand I absolutely adore this game just as it is, I also hope that one day it gets some kind of over-haul or redesign/relaunch.TL;DR: The game developer is a genius and this is clearly a labor of love. I buy very few games, but this is one I was almost giddy to pay for.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												Bought this game from the Blue Bottle website several month ago and have enjoyed it since. Connecting to steam recently, and thought I would promote it. If you are looking for a gritty, post-apoc simulator, this is one of the best. All aspects of your character, such as thirst, food, and even tempature. It can be difficult or easy depending on the starting traits, which alows you to scale how hard it is for you. Since I originally bought the game, there have been a steady flow of updates and new builds, so it is not a game that drops and leaves. The story, world, and enemies are ever changing and interesting. +Great Simulator+Scalable Difficulty+Amazing story and settingThe game certainly is not for everyone. It is akin to older text based adventure games, and the original Fallout games. If you need visual feedback or fidelity, you may want to go elsewhere. However, if you are ready for a real look at surviving the end of the world. NEO Scavanger is simply amazing.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2016
												Two eyes flickered open and heavy breaths followed as she awoke from the nightmare. Her body shot upward from the sleeping bag. She felt her grip on it loosen as she began to calm down. Her eyes adjusted to the dim lighting of the shed.  She listened to her racing heart and the rain on the shed’s metal roof.For a moment, a mere moment, the girl felt relaxed by the noise. Rain was soothing. The unbroken rhythm of each drop.But the ease was lost when she heard a grumbling noise from the pit of her stomach. Her eyes traveled to her stomach. She placed her hands on her stomach, and tried to remember a time where she felt full. As proof, she wore a protruding ribcage.Her attention was then drawn to the door of the shed. She could go out and search for food, risk death for food. Or stay here safe from the outside world and risk starvation.Another grumble from her stomach made up her mind. The young girl found the dagger behind her dirty pillow. She gazed at it’s worn appearance for a moment. A dagger was not much but she had not much else.With as must courage as she could muster, she slid out of the sleeping bag and crept slowly out of the shed. With one last look at the place she considered home, a dusty area with only one hole for light to penetrate through and a small space, she turned away from the shed.Her eyes looked around the forest and felt goosebumps as rain tickled her skin.        The air was coated in a thick fog and the air was stale. What little left of trees stood, but various scraps decorated the ground.        At the age of fifteen, she had been on her own since she was five. Well that what she could remember at least. Whatever happened to the world, she could not recall. The only thing she could recall was her name, or what she had been called at the time. Merida.    Merida shivered feeling the rain soak into her clothes, or what little there was of her clothes.    The scrawny young girl moved away from the shed. She crept through the forest, feeling her muscles tense. A few snarls, growls and footsteps reminded her that she was not alone in the woods. It was dangerous here.      A few moments of walking and she heard something. A bush rustled. Her eyes darted to the bush and she stopped suddenly. She moved quickly behind a log across from the bush. A small rabbit wandered out of the bush. It's ears twitched for a moment. Luckily, it seemed to not have noticed Merida's presence. The rabbit sniffed at the ground for a moment and turned it's back to the log.      Hunger outranked patience, and Merida suddenly leaped forward towards the rabbit. She aimed her dagger for the creature, but missed. The rabbit, startled, begin to ran. Merida eagerly chased the rabbit farther. Her legs ached as she forced herself to continue.  It wasn't until a while, when Merida managed to chase it to the outskirts of the forest. Caught up in the chase, she had not noticed where she was until she tripped on a tin can. She fell down the hill and into the heaps of scraps.      The dagger in her hand had slipped from her grasp. It fell along with her.      With a sudden stop downward, she caught a glimpse of the rabbit running through the scrapyard. Her eyes wandered around, and she felt fear gnaw at her. She had never been here before. She had never left the forest before.      Merida tried to catch her breath. Her small body was not strong enough for the run. Pain engulfed her right leg. She noticed a red liquid spilling from her leg. A large cut rested on her knee. Various scratches decorated her body as well.      She guessed the fall into the scraps had managed to give her the mark, along with the blade of the dagger. Tears threatened to seep out her eyes but she dare not cry.      The girl struggled to stand. But her leg was badly injured and the weight of body was too much.      So she crawled forward. After a few attempts, the girl gave up. The pain in her leg was unbearable.      There she lay, amongst the scraps, with a still empty belly, a damaged body and lost hopes.      'There's no one, no one here to help me..', she thought to herself in despair.      With that, she shut her eyes, and awaited death. She knew she was not dying at the moment; but without shelter, food, and with her wound, she didn't think she'd last a night.***      Night was present when she heard the noise of the beasts. Creatures of all variety were known to come out at night time. Her eyes tried to make out her surroundings in the darkness.      The night brought cold air to her. She shivered, and wished for her shed. At least it was shelter there.      Merida heard something rustle near the scraps. She shook in a terrified motion as the sound came closer. Clomp. Clomp. It almost sounded like footsteps. Merida tried to move her legs, but they felt numb.    She struggled to move, anything to avoid what ever it was.    The noise drew closer. All she could manage to do was hold her breath. A light as well, a red glow, was now close to her. She tried to avoid looking towards whatever it was, in fear that it would see her glancing.    The noise was now there near her. And the glow surrounded her. She close her eyes in fear. Suddenly, something cold and metallic touched her. She opened her eyes slowly, and saw two glowing eyes looking at her. The glow showed a mechanical being made of metal, gears and scraps.      And that was when she drifted into darkness.

												This game is for extreme hardcore strategists or masochists. If you are the one, then go ahead and buy it. My experience in this game didn't give me a lot of satisfaction nor fun. You just die, no matter what you do, no matter where you go. You will freeze to death or be killed by... anything. There is no rollback and you get permadeath. There are close to none information about your character and chances of succes of the actions you make. There is a weird combat system: even with a "strong", "melee" and "tough" perks you die, eventually. 50% of desicions you make is the Luck based, plus another 50% is the Curiosity, combined together will lead you to death.The concept is very good, but the implementation is still needs a lot of work.Combining with the other issues I would wait for improved version.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game is still very raw, but awesome already. If you are into survival stuff or/and a big Fallout fan, you must try this game out. Demo would be enough, though I found out that the full game differs in balance a bit. You won't be able to make a big progress using in-game info only, so prepare to browse external wiki a lot.Combat system is just awesome leaving you with a dire impressions of a martial combat to death, I can't think of anything exciting like that in recent turn-based games. You will feel the force of each crowbar punch landing on your enemies' breaking their limbs. I'm not being sadistic here, but that's what you expect from a post apocalyptic role play survival game. Lack of sex is a big disappointing here though, it would give the game a perfect touch.NEO Scavenger's mechanic is purely brilliant, but the main hardcorish problem to me is that story line is rather linear (though it gives you options to complete quests depending on your perks from time to time), once you've made "a wrong" decision you'll be punished with no option to progress at all, making you literally start the game over from the very beginning. It forces you to constantly peak into forums and wiki, leaving you with no free will options at all.I strongly recommend to buy this game to support its developer.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								An amazing game, reminds me very much of Fallout 1 and 2, only MUCH more forgiving. Still, that doesn't take away from this game's playabilitiy - in fact, my fondest memories are that of my first character. who died something like 6 hours into the game from hypothermia. The crafting system is great, if in need of a bit of refinement. Combat is fun, and sometimes a little bit scary. The environment is what REALLY takes the cake though, I haven't played a 2D game that's ever given me the willies so bad. Definitely a solid 8/10 in my book, and I only see it getting better!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is a great survival RPG for anyone who wants an unforgiving, challenging, and heavily replayable game. The gameplay is very enjoyable, and I find it interesting how realistic this game is. The developers really have put in time to make sure that true human necessities are represented, such as food, a warm place to sleep, something to drink, and a means of protecting yourself. You're almost guaranteed to not do well on your first playthrough, but that's one of the best things about the game. As you keep playing, you learn more and more about what you need to do and what to look for & avoid, and you constantly get better at it. If you've played Don't Starve, you'll see similar gameplay aspects in NEO Scavenger.If you're a fan of the original Fallout games, if you like survival games, or if you like truly tough games that take time and effort to succeed at, you'll surely enjoy this game.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game is still very raw, but awesome already. If you are into survival stuff or/and a big Fallout fan, you must try this game out. Demo would be enough, though I found out that the full game differs in balance a bit. You won't be able to make a big progress using in-game info only, so prepare to browse external wiki a lot.Combat system is just awesome leaving you with a dire impressions of a martial combat to death, I can't think of anything exciting like that in recent turn-based games. You will feel the force of each crowbar punch landing on your enemies' breaking their limbs. I'm not being sadistic here, but that's what you expect from a post apocalyptic role play survival game. Lack of sex is a big disappointing here though, it would give the game a perfect touch.NEO Scavenger's mechanic is purely brilliant, but the main hardcorish problem to me is that story line is rather linear (though it gives you options to complete quests depending on your perks from time to time), once you've made "a wrong" decision you'll be punished with no option to progress at all, making you literally start the game over from the very beginning. It forces you to constantly peak into forums and wiki, leaving you with no free will options at all.I strongly recommend to buy this game to support its developer.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												One of the mistakes people make when first playing this game is assuming it is unrelentingly hard just because you die a lot; it isn't. It just doesn't have a tutorial, and is very strict. You'll die, but those deaths are not random; they are because of some mistake you made. Learn from it. Don't die that way next time. And don't forget your skills; if you die of poisoning try to figure out why and not do it again. Maybe it had something to do with those mushrooms you ate? or that rancid swamp water you drank? Did you die of Sepsis? Then maybe try keeping your wounds clean instead of rubbing dirt in them.Once you get into the swing of things, it isn't hard to survive, and luck starts to be a fairly minor factor. This can take a bit of learning; even poring over the wiki isn't going to totally familiarize yourself with the mechanics, but it is a good idea to use the wiki for craftables. Not necessary, but helpful.One last bit of advice: there's no 100% completion for this game, so keep in mind you do not have to complete every challenge you come across. In fact, you shouldn't try; no character can handle all challenges. Pick your battles, and don't be afraid to run away, even if you are a full combat character. Most of all, the game is turn based. Take your time, think things through, and use your skills.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								This hex-based, turn-based, post-apocolyptic, survival exploration game is quite unique and fun. The gameplay largely centers around exploring abandoned cities searching for useful items and shelter. One of the best features of the game is the level of detail in everything, every item serves a purpose and every decision has its pros and cons. The combat is extremely brutal in spite of being text based, as the descriptions are very specific and make you think about what exactly you have done; eg 'You kick the enemy breaking their ribs and punctured their lung, they bleed to death.' There are a lot of hazards you can succumb to, such as temperature, sickness, bleeding and starvation.Overall I reccomend this game to anyone who likes challenging tactical turn based games, particularly permadeath roguelike style ones.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2016
												The game is flash-tier but still pretty good. It's innawoods simulator, minus the slavshit.Brutal survivalism and inventory management - I like how it takes cold, sleep, pain, and disease in ways that most so-called survival games overlook. This makes for a realistic and engaging but utterly merciless game. There is no save scumming in this game. Ironmode only. Too hard? Just give up, casual, and go back to Minecraft.If you want to play it on easy mode, get Strong, Melee, Botany, and Trapper. Get Myopia and Fast Metabolism as negative traits. Make a cloak out of the Dogman and get to Detroit, then make tannin tea from the forests near the sprawl and sell it until you can get into DMC, get eye implants, then as much equipment as you think you need to get going; this will compensate for your disadvantages. Still, never get cocky - one false step and it's over; I've died multiple times from being careless even when I had a full set of nanomachine healing thingies and plentiful supplies.

Early Access Review
								A lot to learn, and a lot of things that can go right and a lot can go wrong. Lots of opprotunities to do things, and the world is yours to explore. Tip; Start out with Melee/Tough/Strong, Eagle Eye, Trapping, and fight the Dogman. You'll need Eagle Eye to see the mutiltool in the room. Leave the room, then go back to the cryo building and then, you'll need to craft the multitool with the Trapping Skill, and the Dogman corpse. It'll give you one of the best starting out points, able to fight off hypothermia fairly easily.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Right now, it is a promising start for a Roguelike-like. The game offers an interesting spin on the survival genre, by almost singlemindedly focusing on resource gathering. Every mechanic of the game is geared toward that. You'll spend most of the time looking at a grid-based inventory screen, playing Tetris with items. This is no Diablo, though, and what you bring with you might make the difference between life and death.Food-clocks are a pretty common mechanic in traditional Roguelikes and many offshoots (Think of the advancing rebel army in FTL). Time and resource based constraints are a good way to keep the player on its toes, forcing him to push forward instead of farming lower level content to gain advantage. NEO Scavenger doesn't joke with time constraints. Get some clothing fast or it's unlikely you'll make past the first night. There are some balancing issue though, mostly due to the random world generation. Sometimes jeans are harder to find than sleds for some reason. Sometime, there are miles between your initial spawning location and any useful city hex tile.While dying like this might be realistic in a post-apocalyptic setting, it's kinda frustrating to experience more than a couple times.Also, there's a story going on; and by that, I mean a real story, not an emergent one - with quests, characters and dialogues. Not something you see everyday in these type of games. I'm not particularly bothered by it, but I wish I could opt out of it altogether and strike out on my own, handling my own business. The main issue I have with it is that, due to the nature of the game, you're going to see the same text-adventure inserts and lore pieces again and again. With all its quirks and unfinished or unpolished mechanics - combat is especially dull and clunky at the moment - it's shaping to be an interesting and unique game.
