Early Access Review
								I received a key through the official site over a year ago (hence the low Steam "play time") and am really enjoying my experience.  I'm still a bit fuzzy on the crafting (I still haven't figured out how to make a campfire, LOL), but it's fun going around and beating up bandits with crowbars and the like to steal their stuff.  I'm a big fan of the survival genre in general, though I don't often see a turn-based survival game done this well.  It also has a choose your own adventure vibe at times with your traits and perks modding the available outcomes.  Well worth the ten bucks, in my opinion.

												So I found myself writing this huge post about how I recomend this game, and how I got it back before 2015, but then steam said I had to play the game for atleast 5 minutes. So I open the game, then come back here. I made the unfortunate mistake of pasting it back here while the game was loading, so I lost the whole thing, and have to start over.I don't feel like re-writing all of it, and I don't honestly remember what I said. So here's the summary:I got this back when Desura was still an option for getting games.I played it until I was so tired I nearly had to make another pot of coffee, which says a lot since I was on my third, and I'm still thinking about making it.My first death happened almost 10 minutes later. I had a good backpack, a rifle, a crowbar, perhaps I even had a few hundred kills to my name. How did I die? A looter with a monkey wrench... Yup.But thats one of the reasons I love this game. Every time I play this game I find a new way to end my run. So far I think I've been killed by random people around the map more than anything else... Anyhow, about a year and a month or so later we could starting modding, and oh boy did people mod it fast. I loved the game, and I love the mods.Now I'm not saying this is a game for everyone. Infact, I would suggest doing quite a bit of research before buying it (Like, say, getting the demo!). A lot of people say this game has a big learning curve, it's not actually that big, but it could be hard for first time players to get a hand on what's going on. Now, the game also has permadeath, which many people have complained about in the past. So again, do a little research before buying, but I guess that goes for all games... er, um... I'm gonna stop typing now.Thanks for reading!

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												  You wake up to the sound of freezing rain on makeshift tarp shelter. You take a quick look through your gear making sure nothing has been stolen in the night. Shoving the pieces of your shelter into your pack and throwing your hide cloak around your shoulders you take off through the pouring rain.      You rummage through a few houses not finding much, these where the first places to get scavenger after everything went to ****. As you exit the last house on the street tearing an old tee shirt into rags, suddenly hearing a loud clatter you throw yourself to the ground and watch as a large figure resembling Werewolf from old story's lumbers past. It passes by and you release a breath you didn't know you where holding in. Unslinging the rifle from your shoulder you top off the magazine, fighting a dog man today is not something you wish to happen.        A few days later you stand atop a hill scanning the area with half a binocular you keep slung around your neck searching for any movement while munching on a handful of berries. After several hours you see the flash a blue sash moving out of the tree line, a blue frog preacher not friendly and normally carrying somewhat valuable objects you will have no remorse from ending this ones life. Moving closer as to not waste your valuable ammunition you line up a shot from your rifle. With a loud accompanying crack the figure drops to the ground motionless. as you get close the man jumps to his feet and sprints back into the tree line, Swear under your breath you give chase into the dense forest.       He couldnt have gotten far you think to yourself examining the blood trail. The trees seem to press closer on you and your draw a small revolver from your cargo pants pocket, your rifle would be ineffective at these close ranges. The blue sash makes it easy to find the lifeless body after a few minutes. Your so focous on looting the corpse you almost don't hear the rustle of foliage, you grab your pistol from where it lay beside the body and scan the woods searching for the source of the sound. A single shot whipes by your head and you throw yourself behind a log still searching for your attacker. You take a deep breath staying here is suicide, you lung forward from behind the log in a full on sprint. Stumbling over the overgrown roots of the trees you feel relieved as you see the light streaming for the edge of the forest. In all fairness you almost make it before the second shot rings out catching you in the leg. Gritting your teeth against the pain you fire blindly behind you as you break out into the field. You leap into the tall grass silently thanking what ever god stays about for the concealment. The third shot hits you in the back going through your lung, you cough blood flying from your mouth and then the fourth and final shot the only you don't hear finally ends your pain. Neo Scavenger is a post apocalyptic survival simulator. You must contend with food, water, the cold, the weight of your equipment, wild beasts and other people in your struggle to simply stay alive. Neo scavenger also adds in sides mission and a story although i must admit i have no lived long enough to complete any of them. Also random events can happen while moving about the hexagonal landscape ranging from slave auctions to abandon camps. Combat is turn based and visceral in its descriptions, enough to make you slightly uncomfortable with each killing blow. A skill is also in place allowing you to change your play style with each life keeping the game fresh. There can be quite a lot of reading in parts however its is done very very well, each line adds more to the atmosphere and does a good job of giving a visual of the surrounding area. This is a brutal unforgiving game Death comes quickly to the unknowing and the unprepared. Its not everyone's game by far taking up a niche role in giving a somewhat realistic survival game, probably the closest ive found to a proper simulator.  I give NeoScavenger an 8.5/10  Menus can be rather clunky at times and starting off as a new player can be rather brutal but once you grown acclimated to the environment it becomes a rather masochistic joy to play. Just be wary of purchasing and watch some footage and play to free demo to see if you think you would enjoy the game.

								Game is a fantasticly brutal survival sim. One character I had managed to take down a military (ATN?) guy with a crowbar, which gave me rad body armor, guns and a pack full of goodies. As I'm crowbarring his unconcious head in, his attack drone comes out of nowhere and messes up my arm and leg. After cowering in a nearby abandoned building that I tarted up with noise traps and tarps, I poured the dead soldiers whiskey all over my wounds and chowed down on my cured squirrel stash. I healed up, bailed the area and with my new armor and arms, became a total wasteland badass for about 50 turns. That is, Until 3 dogmen tracked me down to a forest shack and took turns arranging my intestines. Immense fun, highly reccomended to survival game fans.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2016
												The game is flash-tier but still pretty good. It's innawoods simulator, minus the slavshit.Brutal survivalism and inventory management - I like how it takes cold, sleep, pain, and disease in ways that most so-called survival games overlook. This makes for a realistic and engaging but utterly merciless game. There is no save scumming in this game. Ironmode only. Too hard? Just give up, casual, and go back to Minecraft.If you want to play it on easy mode, get Strong, Melee, Botany, and Trapper. Get Myopia and Fast Metabolism as negative traits. Make a cloak out of the Dogman and get to Detroit, then make tannin tea from the forests near the sprawl and sell it until you can get into DMC, get eye implants, then as much equipment as you think you need to get going; this will compensate for your disadvantages. Still, never get cocky - one false step and it's over; I've died multiple times from being careless even when I had a full set of nanomachine healing thingies and plentiful supplies.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Right now, it is a promising start for a Roguelike-like. The game offers an interesting spin on the survival genre, by almost singlemindedly focusing on resource gathering. Every mechanic of the game is geared toward that. You'll spend most of the time looking at a grid-based inventory screen, playing Tetris with items. This is no Diablo, though, and what you bring with you might make the difference between life and death.Food-clocks are a pretty common mechanic in traditional Roguelikes and many offshoots (Think of the advancing rebel army in FTL). Time and resource based constraints are a good way to keep the player on its toes, forcing him to push forward instead of farming lower level content to gain advantage. NEO Scavenger doesn't joke with time constraints. Get some clothing fast or it's unlikely you'll make past the first night. There are some balancing issue though, mostly due to the random world generation. Sometimes jeans are harder to find than sleds for some reason. Sometime, there are miles between your initial spawning location and any useful city hex tile.While dying like this might be realistic in a post-apocalyptic setting, it's kinda frustrating to experience more than a couple times.Also, there's a story going on; and by that, I mean a real story, not an emergent one - with quests, characters and dialogues. Not something you see everyday in these type of games. I'm not particularly bothered by it, but I wish I could opt out of it altogether and strike out on my own, handling my own business. The main issue I have with it is that, due to the nature of the game, you're going to see the same text-adventure inserts and lore pieces again and again. With all its quirks and unfinished or unpolished mechanics - combat is especially dull and clunky at the moment - it's shaping to be an interesting and unique game.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								One of the most beautifully crafted games, up there with AI War, and it's not even finished yet. The developer is incredibly active, pushing out quality updates often of content and bug fixes. Also pays heavy attention to the community and is well receiving of criticism and ideas alike.The game itself contains hundreds of recipes, items, and ways to die. The survival system is realistic. You need to eat, drink, stay warm, have vision, scavenge, hunt, trade, and try to keep healthy while doing it. Starving? Those mushrooms look mighty tasty. BAM! They're poisonous. Should have been a botanist, eh?Oh, you're tired? Cold? Campfire in the woods sounds nice, and man am I so glad I found that sleeping bag. BAM! Robbed in your sleep. Bam! Dogman fight! Oh god, you're bleeding out! Slap rags and a makeshift splint on your torn and broken arm. Ouch, you didn't boil them, now you have an infection.I've never really been one to enjoy hardcore games. Infact I usually stay away from roguelikes. This one's demo alone kept me in it for two weeks before buying it. Definitely a good pickup for survival and roguelike veterans and newbies alike.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2016
												So I found myself writing this huge post about how I recomend this game, and how I got it back before 2015, but then steam said I had to play the game for atleast 5 minutes. So I open the game, then come back here. I made the unfortunate mistake of pasting it back here while the game was loading, so I lost the whole thing, and have to start over.I don't feel like re-writing all of it, and I don't honestly remember what I said. So here's the summary:I got this back when Desura was still an option for getting games.I played it until I was so tired I nearly had to make another pot of coffee, which says a lot since I was on my third, and I'm still thinking about making it.My first death happened almost 10 minutes later. I had a good backpack, a rifle, a crowbar, perhaps I even had a few hundred kills to my name. How did I die? A looter with a monkey wrench... Yup.But thats one of the reasons I love this game. Every time I play this game I find a new way to end my run. So far I think I've been killed by random people around the map more than anything else... Anyhow, about a year and a month or so later we could starting modding, and oh boy did people mod it fast. I loved the game, and I love the mods.Now I'm not saying this is a game for everyone. Infact, I would suggest doing quite a bit of research before buying it (Like, say, getting the demo!). A lot of people say this game has a big learning curve, it's not actually that big, but it could be hard for first time players to get a hand on what's going on. Now, the game also has permadeath, which many people have complained about in the past. So again, do a little research before buying, but I guess that goes for all games... er, um... I'm gonna stop typing now.Thanks for reading!

content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												The info:In NEO Scavenger you will be fighting not only the vicious denizens of a post apocalyptic world; but nature itself.Between the cold, hunger and baddies you will have a hard time surviving.Finding something as simple as a potato chip bag seems like an accomplishment in this game as you will always be struggling to find ways to carry all the loot you find and and tools you need.Every item in the game has a health and when that health runs out, it's gone forever and just like in real life if you find a old shopping bag it might have a hole or two in it so there is always the chance that loot you find will already be near useless. Having to decide whether to go on with a sword that has 1% use left in it verses the completely fine stick just laying there will become a easy choice. But figuring out if the small pocket knife is better to take with you because it takes up less space or if it's worth losing that extra storage to a base ball bat is a much harder to decide.Every choice in NEO Scavenger could mean regret or death in the next few turns or happiness and success.  Some things to note before buying:If you like not being able to save your progress then this game is fore you. The only option you have is to 'save' game; which acquaints to going back to the start screen or quitting the game and being able to pick up where you left off however you soon realize it's not really saving anything the first time you die your save is gone. When you die you have to start over again with nothing . . .from the beginning. For me I really get depressed when I worked really hard to get what I got only to die because it was cold or because I drank some bad water.The good:ChallengingTons of content to seehigh replay valueThe bad:The random nature of  encounters and item generation is very unforgiving at times and often ends with your character being killed after only a few turns.A limited (small) set of starting skills to choose from.

The developer is incredibly active, pushing out quality updates often of content and bug fixes. number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												NEO scavenger is a tough as nails survival game that will make you hate it so much you'll either kick it off a window or end up loving it.It's a turn based tabletop-RPG-of-sorts that starts you waking up in a cryo facility in the middle of the post apocalyptic ruins of Detroit. It is sorta RPG because despite having almost no character progression to it you'll pick up a bunch of traits at the start and both skill checks and inventory management will be paramount to your survival, and sorta tabletop because you'll move across hexes using said abilities and items to gather, fight and resolve the situations you'll find yourself in.The graphics are reminiscent of the DOS games of the early 90s and the sound design is minimalistic but effective.The player model will reflect equipment changes and every item has it's own art, and hexes have varied art that will let you know what to expect from each. Everything is functional, but the real star of NEO scavenger is it's gameplay and game design, and its biggest make or break factor.The most important part of the game is undoubtedly the RNG, since it dictates how successful you'll be when scavenging, what you'll get, how combat will go, or whether you'll catch one of the many incredibly deadly diseases that plague the wasteland. There are some things that the player can do to nudge said rng one side or the other trough their abilities and gear, but make no mistake: take a whiff of blue rot or drink from the wrong water and you're pretty much done for, without being able to do much else about it.The beginning of the game is the toughest and most frustrating part of it, because you'll start out virtually naked and extremely vulnerable, to the point that an idiot with a frying pan will be able to do you in. Avoiding confrontation is without a doubt the most effective way to play the game, but the implacable entropy will eventually force you into taking risks be it food or gear. Combat can be equally frustrating since being in the wrong place at the wrong time can earn you being 1 shotted by a hick with a rifle, although I gotta admit when that happens to you killing an enemy with just one bullet feels badass and satisfying as hell.When you finally reach Detroit Megacity things get substantially easier. You'll be able to scavenge the surrounding areas and sell the loot for money, and you'll basically be doing scavenging trips while way better equipped and with better fallbacks. You'll be given missions regularly that will take you to stupidly dangerous places so you'll have to still stay on your toes. But having access to DMC is a far cry from scuttling around in a hospital garb praying to make it without ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ yourself to death due to cholera or freezing to death inside an abandoned building. You'll likely have to retry the first weeks over and over again, but once you manage to get a character rolling it gives you a great sense of accomplishment. Of course the game includes a full compliment of biological needs to take care of, but ironically those are one of the easiest parts of the game with the right perk or once you get some of the very early gear.In closing NEO scavenger is a very long, hard and replayable game that you'll either hate until you love it or just plain hate it. Regardless, it's cheap and if you like survival and a challenge you shouldn't be afraid to pick it up. 7/10.

number of helpful: 10 of 20 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												A devloper once told me, "UI (User Interface) is like a joke; If you have to explain it, then it isn't that good."This game fits into that category with poor UI as only one of many design flaws. Don't waste your time and money.* Unweildy Menu NavigationThe game plays in a window by default, which in and of itself isn't a bad thing. The problem comes when trying to back out of a menu just to end up closing the entire game instead (and losing any progress in the process). The menus themselves, such as inventory, crafting and the map are not very intuitve and require a lot of trial-and-error to figure them out. Saving a game is unweildy, too, because there is only one option; "Save & Quit" from the main menu. * Lack of Information and DirectionVery little information is given for each item beyond "condition" which is how well in a state of repair an item is. For example, when tying to compare weapons, stats such as range and damage are inaccesable to the player; You have to guess which weapons may or may not be better! Same goes for clothing; There are no stats beyond condtion that tell a player how well protected they are. Lack of stats and lack of other useful information leaves the player in the dark. Trial and error helps, but the game is so inconsitant that trial and error will only get you so far.* Nearly Impossible Early GameI like a challange, but this game has too many variables. The map, encounters and looting are all random, which could be a good thing. However, the game starts you out with next to nothing and already suffering from exposure to cold weather. When you need some basic supplies just to survive, and the only way to get those supplies is by a series of lucky random events, then the game becomes more about luck-of-the-draw and less about any real strategy.* Bad Combat EncountersOn top of just trying to survive the elements, there are things out there that want to kill you, and you have next to nothing to fight back with! Your choices are fight with a poorly-designed combat mechanism or try to run and ineveitably get overrun anyway. Even if you win the fight, it's likely you will succumb to the injuries sustained in combat, because you don't have the supplies you need to properly treat yourself.So on top on the bad, unhelpful UI design are a series of random events that will kill you rather quickly, because you never get a chance to get what you need to survive. This game is NOT fun, but rather frustrating, to have to start over and over again and get nowhere in the process. Don't waste your time - Go find a better game.

number of helpful: 10 of 20 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												It looks so good! It sounded like the survival game I'd been wanting for YEARS! But after scavenging only 2 abandoned towns I was shot at and constantly stunned until I died. I was Tough and had clothes on, not sure if that improves my defense or not, and I was behind cover. Infact getting behind cover was the one single action I was able to pull off.In my many playthroughs since I have never been able to find another frying pan or torch, and things were even harder. Finding a lighter is so damn hard that I usually starve to death. Or if I just try waiting it out and eating mushrooms in forests, I end up dying of sickness. This isn't a game about surviving, it's a game about taking a while to die. 2 days is my usual record.This game relies so incredibly heavily on luck that it just isn't fun. But survival is all about strategy, so this works out horribly. I've tried building a great shelter, but died of sickness. Tried never staying in one spot, but got mauled. There are only ways to lose and no ways to win. Also with the very small amount of recipes available, you'd think the game would give you hints on when you need just 1 more item to make something. Dragging the skills into the crafting table is just really monotonous. It should be doing this itself! It's the Minecraft crafting table all over again, with no user-friendliness.And the skills, they were a selling point for me, but now that I've gotten to play it I only pick the same skills each time. They are just not at all balanced. This is what I'd expect from a game still in beta. I thought I'd be avoiding these huge flaws in a finished game. Incredibly dissapointing. I've tried other survival roguelikes and they were pretty bad too in there own ways.Starting to wonder if this genre combo simply can never work.UPDATE: Same day I post this, a wonderful person tells me about a free game in beta called Cataclysm: Dark Days Ahead. It's got more content than I can handle! And despite it's wonky controls, it has a very clear crafting system, and loads of methods for getting materials. It's also far more immersive with you actually exploring the areas yourself. Just hope you don't need graphics, because that's the game's only flaw. To play it like Neo Scavenger, just turn zombies off and NPCs on. And finally, when you die in it, you learn from it. You play better next time. Something I sadly can't say about Neo Scavenger, where it's difficulty is based on a dice roll.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												While I really like the concept and everything:1) The menus are clunky.  This whole game revolves around those menus, so the game is clunky.2) Of the 10 tries or so, my character continually froze to death even if I had layered a shirt over a hoodie with pants and boots and slept in sheltered areas.3) The combat is awkward and does not feel engaging.4) Finding something to store my items was extremely difficult, so normally I'd only have a shiv or something.5) Crafting is strange and it's not clear what you can/should build.  You learn more about what you can make the more you play, and sometimes you even find recipes, but finding those items again by the time you need them seems somewhat unlikely.I feel like this could be spruced up and be far more exciting, but as it currently stands I cannot recommend it.

content:
Posted: January 12
												I know I will get flamed for this, but this game is just too hard. Period. End of story.I do not understand the modern trend of making these rogue-type games with no difficulty slider. (Teleglitch, I am looking at you.) I mean, you make a game to garner profits, then make that game so hard that only die-hards will even bother to buy it, and that is somehow the new model? Why not make the game approachable to a lot more people by having a difficulty slider, and then special achievements for those brave enough to try the hardest settings?Far Cry Primal, for example: It has an easy setting that a 3-year-old can play, but it also has a very very very difficult survivor expert mode that 99.9% of players will never even play, let alone beat. Often, with games like Far Cry and Metro and Fallout, I beat it on an easy setting first, then go back for punishment later. I get a lot of hours out of these games, and the key: they are FUN. I mean, I am not necessarily asking for excessive hand-holding like the quest indicators in Skyrim, but just asking for a decent save system and a difficulty slider.Games like Teleglitch and NEO Scavenger are absolutely terrible for the elitist attitudes they promote. Those games have nothing to do with FUN and everything to do with hollow acomplishments few people can even relate to. So why am I angry or even bothering? I am bothering because other than the difficulty levels, these games are interesting and COULD BE a lot of fun.Consider the absurdity of Teleglitch. That game advertises hundreds of custom guns, but guess what? 99% of those guns you will never find or even get to shoot on this side of 1000 hours of play due solely to the difficulty of the game. I just do not think that is cool. For this nightmare, NEO Scavenger, I have put in quite a few hours, and I have never even found a gun. Ever. Never won a fight. Ever. I fixed the HVAC heater, fixed the electricity, found sleeping and mummy bags, found shopping carts, and really that is about it, and I always always always died for stupid reasons that in real life would never happen. So sad that the difference between a no-star review and a 5-star review is the simple addition of a difficulty slider and custom achievements.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												InB4 Noob.There's games, and then there's exercises in sadism.This is an exercise in sadism.The concept isn't bad, to be honest; and I don't mind the whole permadeath thing; but the difficulty curve is just above and beyond ridiculous. You can, and -usually will- die just from wandering around, because apparently your character is some sort of lizard who can't stand temperate climates. This is just one of the many flaws; but the most glaring. This game punishes new players hard. It's very, very difficult to get into. I've yet to survive a single day game time. Unless you're willing to die hundreds of times, just to get to a reasonable point, you're better off not bothering.Immensely frustrating, seldom rewarding. And even then, you're going to die and lose all your cool stuff, so why even bother?TL:DR.If you're the sort of person who likes post apocalyptia; and enjoys inserting thumbtacks into their perineum; this is your game. If you enjoy post apocalyptia, but are sane, and don't feel like starting the same game ninety times just to get anywhere; look elsewhere for games.Definitely not recommended.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												I like that game, really, but it feels like an incomplete one. I started enjoing it thanks to the multiple wikias guides... but come on, that's where and when gameplay fails. Also there are some basic bugs, like losing the combat turn while changing weapon, even if you had the weapon ready in the other hand; or losing the combat turn if you check your inventory (just looking at it); and an Autosave bug that will disable almost all locations on the map so you're forced to start another game if you want to follow the plot... right, the plot. I felt like something is missing. Dialogues are well written but I just thought "why can't I start a new life on Detroit instead of roaming like a hobo?", no, it can't be done. Because... ok I won't spoil it, but, it's like the game has only few endings that left me still with a lot of unanswered questions in mind. It's a game released 1 and a half year ago, and I think developer should need a big hand on upgrade that nice project.It's a nice dream, and playing it leaves me just wondering how would it be once completed.

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
 TL;DR Neo Scavenger is a brutal 2D survival game set in a supernatural apocalypse where you try survive the wasteland of everything that wants, can, and will kill you should they ever get their claws on you. Also permadeath is on. A shining example of gameplay over graphics. Game Detail Name: Neo ScavengerGenre: Survival, Strategic Inventory ManagementPersonal score: I never knew masochism and sadism was an art form till today. Fun. What is Neo Scavenger Neo Scavenger is a 2D survival game set in a hex based world where a devastation has happened to the world and well, apocalypse thing happen and you are a survivor of it. In first glance the innocent looking graphic and the non threatening looking trailer may throw you off on how brutal this game is but as people often say, 'you don't know hell till you been there' read on. Permadeath is on btw. 1:Gameplay The main gist of Neo scavenger gameplay is well, scavenging old ruins of buildings and forest  to follow the trail of barebone story. Each hex has a protection value from beeing seen, comfort and how alert you can be when something goes near you. Each of this stats can be improved by items, shelter and other craftable. A low protection from the enviromental will make your character slowly freezes during the night and if their body temperature is already low enough they will die. A low alert level will cause your character to not wake up when threats are nearby and bandits/looter/stuff can kill you in your sleep and you will die. A low comfort will cause your character to fight less efficiently and you might suddenly fall asleep and you will die.Adding to that, the map is hex form and you have a limited numbers of move during the day and far less during the night to move around, scavenge or perform one of the many in game action before needing to end your turn for the AI to move. On each hex you can scavenge supplies with city tiles having more supplies but comes at the increase risk of being discovered by bandits and obtaining injuries. Scavenging is extremely important in this game because it is your only way of getting randomized loots early game. Pretty much everything you need can be obtain by scavenging. Which might leads to a fight should you encounter bandits while on the move.Fighting in Neo Scavenger is a game of chances and luck. A fully kited out bandit can still be defeated by you wielding nothing more than a rock but such a thing would of course take extreme luck due to the hidden diceroll system. Based on the perks you have chosen special attacks may not be available to you and only to the perk wielder. A few way fights can be resolve is through killing your opponent, dominating them and causing them to surrender or simply point your gun at them and watch them flee. Even an empty gun works occasionally to fool the AI seeing as in real life you would of course not attack the man with a gun even though its empty but you don't know that.Should you get wounded in Neo Scavenger you will have to treat them to prevent the blood loss from draining too much and yes it regenerates slowly. Wound treatment has their own special menu where you apply splints, bandages and meds to your character. Left unchecked a large wound has the potential to end your playthrough instantly. Also water and berries you collected are often time poisones because the game isn't hard enough. This might cause disease that has a similar effect to a tired status or in worse case scenario cause a total system failure which leads to your death.From all the materials you gathered from the scavenging you can use the crafting menu to create items. A wood with a sharp object will yield a spear that you can use to attack. Container with strings and stones will yield a noisemaker to increase the alert level of your campsite. Many other options exist for the player to find themselves.The player character will also experience hunger and thirst which can be reduce by eating and drinking, failure to do so will lead to death. But as mentioned earlier, most of the water and food you find in the forest where the risks are low are poisonous and consuming them will lead to death.Inventory management in Neo scavenger are quite realistic in terms of real life, your character has only 2 hands and thus can only hold 1 item in each hands without a bag. With a bag this frees up 1 hand for combat and allows more item to be carried but a bag is not your only means of carrying. Side pockets in pants, shirt and even a sledge can be found and use to help you carry more items which is especially important during end game where you often have to make far away expedition. Any item being held or use will eventually degrade before completely break down into nothing and in fact most of the things found in the wild are actually used goods and so they already have lowered durability. To beat the coldness of the night without a good shelter multiple cloths can be worn on top of each other to increase heat levels during the night and prevent freezing to death.The day and night system is also quite important. During the day enemies can spot you from further away and the same holds true for you and the during the night the decreased line of sight cause your action points to be less that during the day.As you traverse the deadly world of Neo Scavenger you might come across strange landmarks or building that will lead you to a random event. Success of survival and loot gain depends on the players perks chosen and dialog choices.And lastly the perks. During character creation you can choose several perks with perk points limiting the amount. The best perks are usually the most expensive but to help player with that negative perks can also be chosen that frees up point for more positive perks. 2:Sound Utilizing more ambient noises instead of spoken dialogs the world of neo scavenger is truly brought to life, The forest shakes and the ruined city exhibit an eerie feeling as the player explores it. But well, good filler is better than no filler. 3:Graphics Everything is sprite based no exception. The characters are sprites, the menu utilizes sprites and even the backgrounds are sprites but like other sprites these are well done enough to pass the inspection. You can clearly tell what an item is at a glance which should be the most important thing in a survival game like this.At least they do look pretty. Conclusion You will die a lot in this game. That is a fact and i hope i emphasized it enough. But the game definitely do not hold your hand at all from the moment you walk out of the facility till the next moment your guts spilled out from getting stabbed by an alcohol bottle. This game is intense. Fan of survival game should definitely get it.FInal verdict: Yes. TIPS! FIND A SHOE, SERIOUSLY.FIND SOME CLOTHES TOO WHILE YOU'RE LOOKING FOR THAT SHOE.YOU WILL DIE. AND IT'S PERMAD DEATH SO GET READY TO RESTART A LOT.BUT THE MOST IMPORTANT THING IS....don't eat those red berries.If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator GroupCheck out the Original Network Groups. Win free games, make new friends on Steam, & more!  Original Curators Group, Original Traders Group, &Original Giveaways Group

content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												This game is the best survival/adventure game you can find on steam up to this day. For some players can be distracted by graphics this game is critically underlooked but make no mistake, this game is hard, unforgiving and overall insteresting. The world of this game holds many secrets. The map can look shallow and empty at first, but if you wander around long enough you can find some really creepy or just cool locations.  Hidden lake for example The combat in this game has almost no limitations, even in most dire situtaion you can come up on top. At least i had one encounter with that happening. There was a guy with a shotgun, i had only a crowbar. I lured him to me without revealing myself, broke both his arms and took the shotty. I felt like a complete badass and you will too. Oh, and for everyone who already owns the game or wants to buy it. Unequip the copper amulet.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												This is the kind of game STEAM Greenlight was created for not iOS games, horrible Russian FPS and hidden item puzzle games. I am listed as having only 3.2 hours on STEAM but I have played this game for many hours. Despite being built on a somewhat janky engine NEO Scavenger is a fantastic game. You will die often like many rougue-likes but slowly but surely you will improve with each game. Its more realistic than most games as well e.g. being a nice guy rarely comes out in your favor in the post-apocalyptic US of A.  I can't recommend this game enough especially if you are a fan of roguelikes. Experiment a bit with skills. Just because you picked tough doesn't mean you will survive your first violent encounter. The game is updated frequently enough that everytime I have played the game has been improved in some way. In fact the last time I actually made it to the city there wasn't much you could do there. I hope the game continues to be updated and I still hope for more variety in items BUT the developer has ensured that each playthrough is challenging but fair.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is one of those low-tech gems that you find yourself immersed in despite it's obvious difficulty and it's lack of flashy presentation. You experience the life of someone in a strange, while still somewhat familiar world and you are left to what you can find to survive among a population that is more aggressive than passive. Friends are in a short supply, as are the means to adequately defend yourself from both the enemies of the world and the elements of it, two threats the game pits against you that are only outweighed by the threat you pose to yourself and your body's basic needs for survival.Can it look better? Probably. Does it need to look better? Absolutely not. Throw away what you think a game should look like and remember instead what a game should be, because that's what you'll find here. Certainly a selection for the determined as you will suffer inexplicable loss time and time again, but the constant struggle for survival make all of the moments of success you encounter, however many or few that you may find they be, all the more rewarding.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie Directions:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.Basically, this is the kind of difficulty and immersiveness you will find in this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								NEO ScavengerNEO Scavenger is a game that wants you to die. Even more than that, it is a game that wants to kill you. Brutally and rapidly if possible, but slowly will work just as well. From hypothermia to bandit attacks to starving to death, it pulls no punches in the “you’re going to die” department. It is an unforgiving game and makes no apologies about it. Quite frankly, that’s one of the reasons it succeeds so well. Before you go running off without reading further, allow me a moment to elaborate. A single paragraph is all I’m asking.You see, NEO Scavenger also wants you to succeed. It does supply you with the tools and skills you need in order to survive. It simply doesn’t hold your hand or coddle you along the way. You begin simply enough. You start the game by picking your few basic skills and you wake up on the floor of a cryogenic freezing lab with something mean heading your way. Your journey has just begun in earnest. You may use your chosen skills to assist with the incoming creature, via feeding it another survivor or simply locking the door. The skills you have chosen to outfit yourself often change the game in this way, leading to all kinds of different outcomes to little problems like this. It’s undeniably gratifying to halt an enemy attack by using your hacking skill to drop a cryogenic tank and feeding the creature a reality television star. Let’s be honest; who hasn’t wanted to do that at one point or another?Are you still with me? I thought that might get your attention. The aim of the game is fairly simple; find out who you are and what happened to the world. Things take place in a post-apocalyptic environment, and you have no memory of any of it. It’s fairly standard, but it plays out relatively well nonetheless. Hints are revealed through old newspapers you find scattered about and obvious visual cues. Your hand is never held at any point, there is no tutorial, and there are no retries. When you die, it is game over and you start again from the beginning. NEO Scavenger is a harsh, unforgiving piece of work. But you also get a little better each time, get a little further, and learn a little more. It’s tough, often seems unfair, and is always exciting.Technically, it is a pretty solid game. It’s still in development, so it does have its share of bugs and incomplete features, but what is currently present does work well and you shouldn’t be deterred from giving it a shot if you find yourself at all interested. Over the course of the next few months it will be fleshed out and cleaned up, and it’s looking like it will become a great little game. I would recommend it easily enough, especially considering the $10 price tag attached to it. If you think you might be interested, and don’t mind a rough edge or two, give it a shot. If you think you can take the abuse, that is.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												Never let it be said that you need a tripple A studio, an army of designers, developers and artists, and boundless resources to make a game that's challenging and fun.Neo Scavenger is a breath of nostalgic air, harping games like Wasteland and Fallout, but with the new hardcore survival-style normally only found in modern titles like Rust. Just a dash of RPG elements, an elloquent crafting system and an intense focus on resource management (though "scrabbling" might be the better word) the world of NS is a brutal one.Combat is surprisingly deep considering it takes place almost entirely through text, and often results in a desperate brawl. You'll never be too well equipped, as even the best gear can't save you from some of the nasties out there. Planning, tactics and luck will see you through though!That being said, it's not perfect. There's a few terrible bugs, save games can be lost, and the nature of RNG can sometimes leave the player in unfortunate or outright unfair situations. Balance and tweaking post release will likely fix this.But if you've missed games that punish you, or just have masochistic tendancies then this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
												Played when I bought it, since then I have been trying to survive, fought loads of bandits and looters, scavenging equipment. In the first hours, my character would die from starvation or dehydration or either get killed because for some reason Dogman(s) love to hunt me down. However on the second day I used the crafting page, and started to read some of the information at the wiki. This went on until I succeeded making the right character with the necessary traits to fortify my base and create alarm systems, and as well as foraging and hunting and making traps, producing clothing and distilling and sterilizing water, and also going beyond to even cure cooked meat with salt(ash). So far I think this game is realy really what I always wanted from an apocalyptic role-playing game. There is freedom of choice, and also a pretty large map and simulates even in a small platform a deep experience for anyone, who want to feel like role-playing in this large area infested with looters and bandits, predators, and hidden quests.I would really recommend you to try this game out, and also help the developers to finish the game and add more content into it. I am really impressed on how much they have managed to squeeze into this game. In my books the developers have scored 10/10 in gameplay and also the healing/medical system and the metabolism and other addictions and features which mimic the human body is outstandingly simulated. Perhaps even one of the first games which has gone so far as to bring in the human metabolism system into a game.

												It's actually a really cool survival game, with an interesting story, cryptids from Michigan, cannibalism, ghosts, incredibly expensive healthcare, alien midgets and beating up giant dogs, and people with a stick. "Dogmen" or "Enfield Horror" may not be the most realistic thing, but it's still a well made survival game.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								A very good survival horror game. I first got the game on the 'Free Demo' mode and found it good fun. So, I invested the money and got the full version. There are quite a few improvments in the Full Version, but not really worth the proce tag. Still, I enjoyed the game for a good few hours, and once I reached the town in the south east corner of the map found that there wasn't really much else to do to keep you playing any further. I would either stick to the Demo, or wait for the game to go on sale. I would add too that this is a 'Early Access' game, so I am also looking forward to the 'Full Version' in the future ;)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												A nice game about killing people and eating them. But seriously, this game is brutal. One second you'll find yourself punching up a melonhead, then going to sleep, and dying to a dogman. Extremely unforgiving and luck based. If you find what perk to pick up thought, (Mine are personally Melee/Strength, Trapping, and Ranged), you will survive longer. But the more and more I play this game, the less and less diverse I get. This is due to most of the skills being utter♥♥♥♥♥♥ If you want to actually survive, you got to pick trapping. If you want an early ranged weapon, you got to go ranged. This is a big problem, for the game doesn't really support the other lesser traits very often. Still, a fun game that I became a psychopathic murderer who eats the flesh of humans in.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2015
												Game is pretty much empty. You can do few things that are detailed but that is all you can do. Just check the news for "updates" and you will see there is almost nothing. Fixes with very few new things and some advertisement like "best RPG" or "NEO Scavenger discount" I got this as a gift and I'm thankful but game is pretty repetitive, the whole "STORY" is always the same even the locations and dialogues are the same so what is the point ? Only thing that can help this is some content added by yourself (mods) that will add things ( weapons, clothes, food, misc., locations etc. and there are very few of those and they aren't even that compatible ( I tried myself ) ). So, no don't buy this. Ask your friend who has this if you could borrow their Steam for a while to play this and you will see for yourself it is not much. I have to admit at the BEGINNING it WAS FUN when you discover stuff you find special locations and items and so on, but after you repeat that ( and believe me you will because you will die A  L OT until you understand this game enough to survive long enough to discover something that actually is special (there are few locations.) ) So once again, sorry but ! NO DON'T BUY THIS !

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												If youre going to have a survival game you should probably have a chance at getting a fair ways away from the start point. If youre looking for a brutal survival game youve found it. Pay $15 to freeze to death, over and over and over and over. It dident seem to matter what i found, two boots a shirt and pants to wear, froze to death. A good campsite, Death. but i digress. The UI you have to navagate is confusing and clunky i had to fumble around just pressing buttons for the first 15 minutes and i still dont fully understand it yet. This game has a simular style to the original fallout and by that i mean it seems like a duplicate exept in fallout you can acctually play for more than 10 minutes without parishing. There are seemingly cool ideas implemented into this game, a crafting system (wich you will never utalize before you Parish) drivable vehicles (wich you have no chance of utalizing for before mentioned reasons) and a campsite system (wich bearly helps you suvive). I see the efforts of the developer but its all wasted by brutal difficulty. The kind of difficulty that makes Dragons easyer to kill than snowy sabre cats in skyrim.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												I cannot recommend a game that forces you to survive based on the outcome of a random number generator. I used to like this game, because I figured that the goal was to carefully refine your strategy until you could create a character that could overcome any hardship. Over time, however, I realized that there's no such thing as a perfect build, and if there is, he still won't last more than three days or so. Your character is nothing bust a test pawn for the RNG, and the generator just sits there until it rolls a low number, then you die.If you like exercises in random chance, go to a casino. Don't drop $15 on this game.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2014
												Decided to redo this review. No one will read it. Don't care. Just wanna put my two cents out there.So. This game. I love this game. A lot. It's simple and addicting. Goal is simple, survive.Getting to the goal is the hard part, because you will die. It's the only constant in this world.Well...that and taxes but in post-apocalyptica I don't think taxes are a thing anymore.Game is very remeniscient of the old Isometric Fallout games when Interplay was the owner of the title, except for combat where you just pick an action and it's carried out.Most of the time, in my case, you'll die from little things. Like drinking impurified water, or not being able to find the right amount of clothes to keep you from going hypothermic.OR in my case, a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ dogman coming out of nowhere to eat your♥♥♥♥♥like a gourmet dinner.I hate this part of the game, but I love it so much. I just keep comming back no matter how many times I die. Because as Cleveland Brown once said; "You don't win, you just do a little better each time."

Early Access Review
								It's early access and rather buggy and there's no endgame yet.Yet I've found myself playing for over fifteen hours.It's a nifty survival simulator. There's a bunch of bugs and design decisions that can make the game utterly trivial, and after a certain point there simply isn't much to do. And even if you aim for the far-away goals, the chances are a bug is going to ruin your save before you reach them.It's not finished yet. But it is fun to play. If you like dying of cholera due to being careless, anyway.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Wow. This game is absolutely fantastic! I've played many games over the years, and I can safely say that this one is the best I've ever played. It ticks all the boxes for me:1. It's challenging. A game without challenge is pointless. When you first start playing, you will get yourself killed multiple times, in a variety of different ways. This will keep happening unless you engage your brain, and use the tools available to survive. Permadeath means that you can't afford to make mistakes, which makes the game much more intense, and progression is much more fulfilling. I wouldn't have it any other way. 10/102. Gameplay. This game is a sandbox turn-based rogue-likeish RPG. Some may not like this sort of game, but I've played many games of this sort, and it's the best of the lot. Most of these sorts of games over-complicate everything, and gameplay suffers as a result. This is not the case for Neo-Scavanger! The sandbox element is the cherry on top - do whatever the hell you want to do. Perfect! :D 10/102. Focus is on gameplay and NOT on graphics etc. Too many games these days look nice, but in reality they have no replayability or depth. Neo-Scavanger is the opposite - the graphics and UI allow you to play the game, they are not there to be pretty . It's graphics and art are still great though, proper old-school stuff. Also, there is the added benefit that ANY computer will be able to run this game. It's built in flash, so if your PC can handle some random online flash game, it can handle Neo-Scavanger no problem. 10/103. Depth. This game is deep! I have been playing for a few days now, and I have barely scratched the surface. I've just about got the point where I can reliably survive in the wilds, and have yet to actually explore the world. The game is mysterious, it's hard to know what the game will throw at me as I continue to play, and I love that feeling in a game. 10/104.Lore and story. I like anything to do with post-apocalytic settings etc, who doesn't? I havn't really played enough to comment on this aspect of the game, but from what I've played so far the writing and story is top-notch. 10/105. Thoughtful developers who listen. Having read a few dev posts, it is obvious that they care about this game. They are very open to suggestions and discussion. 10/106. Mods. I haven't researched the mods much, but I know that they do indeed exist. Always great to have that option!Summary: 11/10. Buy this game now! Even if you normally don't like this sort of game, give it a go! It's cheap ;)

Posted: April 27, 2016
												The game is phenomenal, compared to other grid based strategy adventure games, the story is very dynamic but falls short on certain aspects that could make players feel that they can actually become part of this world. There is no option to have a permanent home inside the City, and no option to actually control your faith or figure out more about the past. It would of been a much better choice to have the player kill the person in the apartments or take it over or anything, but I think you have to avoid a lot of things in this game to actually be able to enjoy many aspects of it, because scavenging and surviving just won't do it alone for anyone.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
Early Access Review
								Just bought this game a few days ago after playing the demo. I have to say I played the demo and was like.... meh.... then I bought it anyway because of the sandbox nature. The biggest issue is the lack of any explaination of the controls. I had to learn that the hard way. (IE how to flip items to fit in your bags, use crafting, find water from streams, etc) Now that I know how to use it I'm having so much more fun. (PRO TIP "x" is for crafting, and you have to "craft" the lakes to get water, or woods to get sticks. If you use melee skill, large branch, shard of glass and a shirt or cloth you'll get a broad spear that smacks guys around!)Anyway the only thing I wish this had was weapon skills, so I can get more deadly and have a better chance to kill with a bow or gun. I understand that will NOT be part of the final build and although I want it I am fine with not having it. Items degrade pretty quickly, and there arent many stores to buy stuff so you have to make due with what you find. Another thing thats awesome is cooking. Lets just say I killed a raider, was starving, had no luck with my animal traps and had to make a "life" decision, do I die or do I cut up mr raider and cook him? Overall very impressed with the game and I'm enjoying every minute!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												This game is way, way too hard. You cant even beat a normal person armed with stones when you're at full health and have weapons. As soon as you leave the starting area you're suddenly afflicted with hypothermia and tracked and attacked by dogs that you also have no chance of beating. Then, each time you start a new game you have to pick your traits all over again for the 5 minutes that you're going to live. You'll often die a day or two after leaving the starting area from hypothermia even if you do everything you can to not freeze to death. The first few turns, if you aren't lucky enough to find yourself some clothing and a rudimentary weapon, you can bet you're going to die in your sleep or as some dog (or Dogman)'s lunch. I love the concept and the style. A turn based survival that works off of hexes? Pretty clever. But the execution is far too brutal and with not even the most simple of tutorials to learn basic survival from, it's even more unforgiving... and not in a fun way. Buy this if you feel like being helpless and frustrated, otherwise I'd recommend passing this up until there are some major changes that put you, instead of RNG, in control of your fate.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												With the launch of Neo Scavenger I figured I would share my thoughts on this title.The good:* Great atmosphere.* Punishingly hard gameplay. One mistake and you die and have to start over.* Combat is best visceral and brutal. It's all text based but very well done.* Mostly well written story.The bad:* Pacing is really off. Feeding yourself off rabbits can take several in-game hours.* You sometimes feel like you're playing a hobo.* Sometimes too hard.* Lack of real character development options.* Unguided gameplay. You really have to dig deep to find the story and main quest.That said, I still think this is a superb title.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												I think this game is super unbalanced in terms of how much luck you need to get through it. It's really hard to survive combat without one of the combat traits but in taking combat traits you loose the survival traits that keep you alive over the long haul. It's not uncommon to spend a couple hours building yourself and your camp up up just to get wrecked by a dog you couldn't out run. Ultimately the scavenging and crafting are alright but the combat system is really what gets me. There is no consistant means of escape and no way to tell how much health your opponent has or has lost during the battle. On a side note I'm really interested in the story elements of the game. I want to see the robot facility and I want to find out whats in the middle of the swamp but I just feel like I'm spending all of my time dealing with malnutrition and water poisoning. This is again another luck based flaw. If you can't find a tin can or a pot to boil water in your as good as dead within the first day or so. In all honesty I think the best way to fix that would be to have more set, consistent points in the game. That way I"m not forraging through settlement after settlement just to have varying results of survival gear, weapons or neurishment which leave the players superunder capable of surviving.Maybe I"m missing things that others figured out but there isn't even a tutorial system to introduce you to the interface.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												Wasted potential. A neat idea made unbearable by an inexcusably horrendous interface, glitches and things that don't make sense and completely break any immersion. More chore than challenge; would not recommend.- - - - - - The interface is absolutely horrible for no reason other than bad design. You're going to be clicking on things at least five times more than you have any right to. What's worse, once you explore the map a bit, the game begins to be unreasonably slow and unresponsive.- - - - Game suffers from bugs that have no right to be in the final product. For example, if you get exiled from the city, get a different tracking bracelet and try to get it again, the game will treat the new bracelet as the old one and won't let you back in. What's worse, the only way to get back is to literally wait (!!!) for an entire year of game-time (8760 turns).- - - - Unimmersive; for a survival game, surviving stops being any challenge whatsoever as soon as you reach the city outskirts and stay there. You can live safely and comfortably indefinitely while earning a shootload of money, and the only reason to leave safety is to push the story forward. Also, the character is supposed to be someone who got dropped into this post-apocalyptic world out of the blue, yet in the extremely limited NPC interactions he somehow already knows about things he hasn't even come close to seeing. The "crafting recipes found on random pieces of paper scattered all over the place" thing not only makes no sense, but is also largely useless as they more often than not show obvious things like "heat source + kindling = fire", or "binoculars + strap = binoculars with strap".- - - It's a wiki game; the game itself fails to give you even the most basic information about things for no good reason; for example, weapon reach, not to mention things like weapon damage, etc. The player has to look things up that he really shouldn't need to, and even then, the wiki itself doesn't bother listing a lot of useful information about a lot of things, which shows a lack of any real player interest.- Minimum in-game sounds, almost no music.~ Game might seem "unfair" to a lot of people who dislike dicerolling and are used to streamlined games. Some situation can simply kill you, and there's nothing you can do about it. Permadeath.+ A challenging and exciting early-game. Caution and risk management are needed, and running for it is often the correct choice.+ An interesting, strategic and tactical battle system, once you get the hang of it.+ Character creation is also interesting, which lets you choose traits and disadvantages (which let you choose more traits)

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												Played the demo for a long time and finally decided to buy this game.Pros:-Learning curve is very fun and challenging-No level progression, so if you die, all you are really losing are items. No need to re-grind back up to level 200-Very atmospheric-Character customization is decentCons:-Very empty characters, only defining traits are those chosen at the start of the game. No real room for roleplaying.-Story is very difficult to uncover without multiple runs, and when you do uncover it, its also very empty and disappointing.-Music is so nonexistent that sometimes i forget its there-Dying is a bit unbalanced, explained more belowIf i have a fur coat, with a backpack jammed with goodies, and im wielding a crowbar, i should NOT get killed by a half naked man with his bare fists just because he had the "Strong" trait. Also getting OHK'd by a dogman when im in top shape because he just so happened to swing at my upper chest and got a good hit in, causing me to go into cardiac arrest. This may be a roguelike but that doesnt excuse poor game balance by the developers.Ill play this game from time to time when im bored but im definitely not jumping on this everyday when i wake up in the morning because im so excited to make ANOTHER empty character who i kill with alcohol poisoning because ive survived for about 5 years. (because thats how simple this game is once you master it)Game review aside, you should try Cataclysm DDA, its a free OpenGL game, and its wickedly addictive.Rating: 5/10Verdict: Buy it on sale if you have nothing more important on your wishlist.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												I had this game on my wish list for a long time, this past steam sale finally gave me the chance to buy it at a price i thought would suit it and I was really looking forward to playing.I had heard good things about it from some pretty reliable sources, mostly friends but also Steam reviewers as well, so I went in mostly blind not checking out the wiki or anything related to the game expecting a neat surprise. However, this game let me down. It let me down on every fundemental level possible for a game of it's genre, especially for the price. I'd recommend instead, downloading and playing Catacylsm : Dark Days Ahead. The game is within the same genre, but has a much more robust supply of activites to do in the game, and various styles to play the game. The best part of the game recommended is that is free. Hilariously this is the first time I can ever say Catacylsm also has a better UI than another game as well

								I love it, Honestly, i ♥♥♥♥ing love it, one minute you can find a  Rifle with 5 rounds and take down a armed Guard and grab his flak jacket and uniform and run off, and the other minute theres a sniper pinning you as two of the guards of the same faction is walking slowly towards with their pistols, and then you have a long hard fight where you have a little hope of winning, and you die.That is neo scavenger.It is the first game that has made me rage like insane, yet love it at the same time as im raging.You can die several times upon starting during to not finding clothing within the first (ingame hours) hours, and then die from Hypothermia, and then as you hopelessly try again, you go all rambo killing everyone you see without any need to try cause you know you will win, Untill you get unlucky, It has the short term fast paced game like Binding of isaac, but a much more complex system of the game, now that it has modding support i cant wait to see mods popup.In short terms10/10Not a 9.5 not a 910/10It is a unique game, it is one of the golden corns you find in the masses of indie games.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												For a game like this, you have to compare it to the other games in its genre, survival. I can think of Don't Starve and This War of Mine. Both games are probably superior to Neo Scavanger in both polish, balance and depth. The story/rpg elements in Neo Scavanger are very light so not worth mentioning. The main thing Neo scavanger has going for it compared to these two titles is it is turn-based.Don't starve has the most depth and polish.This War of Mine offers the most control (least randomness).Neo Scavanger offers turn-based experience and is probably more random.So do I recommend it? Well, I really like my games to be turn-based. If you are like me, consider getting this on a sale. Otherwise, the other two games are probably superior.Edit: Aaand I just got hit by a playthrough ruining bug involving my shopping cart bursting and the game not calculating my encumberance correctly.

Early Access Review
								NEO Scavenger is a great game for those who like games like DayZ. It is personally one of the best turn-based stratgey games i have played. NEO Scavenger is a great game that you can play over and over and never get tired of it because its different almost everytime (except for locations i think they stay in the same place I have a really good playthrough atm so im not sure). The traits that you can get at the begining of the game can really help or hurt you depending on what kind of playthrough you want to do. All in all, Neo Scavenger gets a 8.5/10 in my book.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												You wake up in a cryo facility, a slavering beast is approaching.  You're a skilled Mechanic, and you override the door mechanism, locking it out.  You step outside into a barren wasteland, a glow on the horizon to the East.  Somewhere, a pack of dogs howl, and they're getting closer.  You run for shelter and find a monkey wrench.  You put up a fierce fight ...You wake up in a cryo facility, a slavering beast is approaching.  You're a skilled Athelete, and you spring out the window unscathed.  You step outside into a barren wasteland, a glow on the horizon to the East.  A scavenger approaches you, spear in hand.  The look on his face is pure desperation. You try and run away, but fall to the floor ...You wake up in a cryo facility, a slavering beast is approaching.  You're a skilled Botanist, and you find castor plants, smearing yourself with them and making your scent toxic to drive the beast away.  You step outside into a barren wasteland, a glow on the horizon to the East.  You make your way towards the glow, picking up a mismatched pair of shoes and dragging around two grocery bags filled with twigs, kindling, and empty water bottles.  You're close to hypothermic, but just need to survive until the next day so you can focus the sunlight to start a fire to warm yourself.  As dawn approaches, you slip into oblivion...You wake up in a cryo facility... Good luck!NEO Scavenger is a brutal game where you'll die often, and in horrible ways - even once you understand all of the mechanics, the random number generator will seal your fate if you're not very very careful (and sometimes even if you are).  There's surprising depth in the crafting, combat, and survival aspects for a game without any animation.  You need a tin can, a lighter, and some twigs to make sterile water to drink.  You need the same things plus a dirty rag to make a clean rag.  If you get hurt and are bleeding, you need to wash the wound with sterile water (or another antiseptic) and then bandage it with a clean rag.  I died of massive infections twice by the time I realized how to properly care for myself after a fight.  I died several times in combat before I realized how to play defensively and wait for openings.  I still die just through bad luck, but I'm getting further and further into the game each time.

number of helpful: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												I've played this game for 14 hours, and I'm angry. Hear me roar.I played for 14 hours, slaughtered COUNTLESS beasties, raiders and robbers. I killed something called a "melonhead" and I've slaughtered so many dogs I could wear their skins and pretend to be the wolf-man.It was at that time - as I munched down another human steak, made on the desecrated remains of a man who had tried to steal my sled in the middle of the night, that I was assaulted. Well, it was actually while I slept after having eaten the corpse of the aformentioned adversary, seeing as time apparently stops when you eat things.In any case, let me recount to you, the story of Philip the Doghide boy.Philip, just as any man, awoke from cryogenic stasis in a secret lab, where he was quickly faced with a hideous creature screaming like the midnight wind 'cross a praire of bones so sharp as knives. And much like that praire of bones, the dogman was soon still and dead. You see, Philip was a total badass, and he vanquished this horrific beast with a few swift uppercuts and rock-hard right-left combos. The beast lay dead, and not satisfied with merely having sent this beast's soul to dogman-heaven, Philip decided that it's skin looked comfortable. He grabbed a shard of glass, cut it open and wore it's pelt - face and all, possibly while dancing to some trance-music and smearing cheap lipstick on himself. Naked. In front of a mirror.After that psychadellic trip, Philip wandered out into the wilderness, wearing nothing but the skin of his dead adversary. He was messed with. Attacked by rabid dogs and feral.. Dogs. And more dogs. This game has a lot of dogs. If you don't like killing dogs, this is probably not the game for you.Anyway, needless to say, dogs never really posed a problem for Philip. Philip had two good pairs of hands, and he had a shank made of glass in one of them. Philip was not to be ♥♥♥♥ed with.Now, Philip was a hulking mass of death, even when armed with nothing but a shard of glass, so I'll assume you understand what happened when Philip found a crowbar and a loaded shotgun in a shed. That's right. Philip turned into a lean, mean, psychopathic killing machine. This brings us to a dark chapter of Philip's life. The killing. The killing never stopped.Philip was a soulless husk of a man, and that crowbar whispered sweet things in his ears at night. It craved for blood. Lusted for it. Philip was renamed "Philip Mordake".Philip tried to fight it, of course. Philip was no murderer.. Philip merely loved to kill dogs, but that didn't matter. For each person that crossed Philip's path, the crowbar screamed. It pleaded, begged and demanded of Philip.. Terrible things. Great things. But terrible things.It drove him to insanity, the whispering. The screams. They all melded together as Philip gave in to the crowbar's crazed yelling. He'd separate flesh from bone, and smash until there was nothing left but something that barely resembeled a human. He'd eat the flesh. Why not? Cut it loose with a shard of glass, and eat chunk by chunk until he was no longer starving.Philip's path on this strange earth was carved from the blood and bone of any that entered his path. Any that dared touch his sled. Philip was a cruel God on this earth, his fury tempestous and his retribution violent and brutal as it was swift. He cut many a foe from existance, and wore their remains as trophies.This brings us to the end of Philip's journey. For Philip had been surprised to wake up in the middle of the night, at the sound of somebody stealing his sled! That could not happen - no not at all. And Philip's recourse to this - though predictable - was a thing to behold. He knocked down that poor thief, and whaled with his crowbar until there was naught left of his adversary. Philip hadn't even been injured at this. He was in perfect health, and continued to be so as he smeared himself with the blood of his enemy (note; you can't actually do this in the game. You'll wish you could, though.) and sat himself down again. He dozed off, and once more awoke. This time, to the face of the very first foe that he'd faced.It was a Dogman, looming above him like a gaunt, shadowy behemoth. The crowbar awoke. It screamed. It begged for blood, and Philip didn't have to be asked twice. He leapt for the creature! He cut it down, and bit it's flesh with that accursed crowbar time and time again! A hailstorm of blows weakened the beast, and it desperately slashed out!...Philip was struck in the heart, and died immediately. And the crowbar fell from his hand, going silent.. It was just a normal crowbar.Now, you might think that's an amusing story. Or maybe you hated that story, but let me tell you what.I spent 14 HOURS. 14 BLOODY HOURS ON PHILIP.Philip was a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ED MONSTER! He was the toughest thing since diamonds armed with shanks in a cuban jail.He'd survived battles with up to three opponents at once, and though injured, he'd come out on top.And now he just got killed instantly because of some fantastic stroke of good fortune for some psuedo-werewolf.This game is interesting, but it's interesting for about 10 minutes. If you've discovered amazing loot in one house, you've basically found all there is in this game. Sure, there are random events and such, but very few of them actually lead anywhere. You're Philip, and you'll always be Philip. Not Philippa, or Sam, or James the Jive♥♥♥♥♥Jukebox Jockey. Philip.You'll pick your perks, disadvantages and roll out. You die because of silly reasons or because you had a bad start. And then you have to start all over, without any progress having been made.After a while, it becomes tedious. It's not fun to micro-manage your campfire, clothes, hydration and hunger-levels, as well as spend the ENTIRE GAME TRYING TO FALL ASLEEP, I MEAN♥♥♥♥♥♥ JUST FALL ASLEEP, MAN! YOU JUST MASSACRED AN ENTIRE VILLAGE!All in all, I'd refund this game if I hadn't hate♥♥♥♥ed 14 hours of gameplay out of it. Do yourself a favour and look at a youtube-clip of somebody playing it without audio first. That will be your life in this game. Like what you see? Go for it.
