number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												You will freeze to death with one left boot on. This is the game in its entirety. I've played several survivor horror games in the past and I was looking forward to something different. Text/ turn based survival horror appealed to me.  At first, you kinda have to get used to the controls. Click this tab to do this, click this tab to do that. Click this button to turn off the text so you can do the only thing available to do. Speaking of, skills in this game are pretty much worthless.  Ya, some skills actually do stuff. Melee does help in combat, you can Hide while you explore the map, Botany gives you more loot to choose from in forest tiles, some cutscene you use tracking to reveal more text about something that happened when they just could have told you in the first place what happened. Other skills don't matter. Mechanical and Hide give you the ability to scavange buildings safely but reduce the probability of loot while scavenging.  Medic give you the ability to scavenge for medical supplies in the spawn point and gives you better healing but if you don't have any medicine ...who cares!  Your best bet is to hit the road and gather as much as you can to help you survive. The very first town you find will give you a cutscene and a little back story and that's usually it. Most times than not, this town is empty of stuff to take. So, you move out and explore the area around. And as you wander, in the cold and rain, you start suffering from hypothermia. You "could" build a fire but in the thirty five- fourty games straight that I played (because you almost always die within the first two in game days) I've found a lighter twice.  Now, as you reach near death due to freezing to death , you get a cutscene about an abondoned car. The car has a sleeping bag inside and if you use the Tracking skill, you will find one left boot. You can grab the sleeping bag and carry it to your camp, which camps always attract dogs, and if a dog or a soldier doesn't come into your camp and kill you, you can sleep for a few hours and warm up . But that just slows the inevitable. For the only out come for this game is..... you'll freeze to death with one left boot.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												NEO Scavenger is a fantastic, retro throwback to CRPGs of yore and a brutal simulation of post-apocalyptic survival. It's also one of the most frustratingly difficult games I've played. For every bit of smooth, crispy tactics and intriguing story bit you get, there's a death that comes within two minutes of booting the game, or scavenging five different city hexes with every effort coming up empty. It's obviously a very well built game and has a community that loves it, it's just entirely too difficult to have fun with.

number of helpful: 13 of 30 people (43%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 24
												GAWD DAM IT!!!!!!!!!!FUC!!!!!!!STUPID GAMEE!!!!!Finally got my feet under me.Took 3 arrows but won the fight...i don't take them out cause I figure it'll make the wound worse. Limped back to base. Fought off a dog on the way. Boil up some clean rags, notice that my wounds have stopped bleeding.♥♥♥♥♥♥this is going to hurt.Takes out an arrow, bandages (wow, I'll survive this!)Takes out another arrow, bandages (Damn right!)Takes out third arrow, everything goes fine! I'm going to live! Arrow in 'hand,' move cursor to place arrow on ground, click, not enough room to place. Game decides "oops, gotta put this arrow somewhere, but there's no room on the ground..."Game inserts arrow back into my gushing chest, slicing the pulmonary, kills me instantly.Fucing...hell....All because the game designers ♥♥♥♥ed up the item movement system. (FIX THIS!!!)So yeah.Otherwise, it's a pretty fun game, just lacks on content. I know, shocking...but I believe this. The big problem is how do you survive? Once you figure this out...not much left to do. The main storyline is pretty short all things considered (and not really deep or logical when you really try to make sense of it) and there's not terribly many 'random'/'lesser' encounters to keep you busy along the way. None of the guys that walks around ever talks to you, they just try to kill you or run away. Overall the impression you are left with is that you are fighting a wave of death. This is really cool. But shallow after about 5 hours because everything is so in depth that you are left wondering, "why isn't the human side of things as complex?"There should be people who are traders. There should be non-combat entities walking around on the map, trying to accomplish their own goals (secure a campsite like you...hunt deer or creatures for their faction). Desperates who are sort of lost, running away that you can interact with. You should be able to form a band of followers, be able to discuss their roles in your little band of survivors and start relationships etc... I feel like other games already do this but that people developing a game pick one main theme to go after then stop, instead of diversifying and branching out and growing.At the moment there are some 'encounters' that happen randomly when you enter a square...and these are great!...but there aren't enough. This is sort of like a 'first step' towards humanizing the game.There should be an alliance 'system,' so that if a guy with the 'trapper' skill settles down 20 hexes from you and makes that his base, you can go approach him, offer to trade, and develop a relationship. Now you can approach more freely etc...Here's another idea: Instead of adding human-centric 'content' in the form of side quests and dialogue trees, try and think of some ways you can mix it up. Be innovative. If you can add something that completely shocks people because they don't expect it from a video game, they'll love you forever and your game will be remembered.What I think is funny is that the devs tried to hook a story onto the game without any of the above 'humanization'. You get a thrill from uncovering the story but the SECOND you know what happens, you stop caring. The devs should hire some literacy major who just graduated and is working at BK (this would cost next to nothing) to take a look at their game and write some story in for them. Might even do it for free for the resume.So my advice: 1) Add some more 'systems' (like the allegience, like seriously expanded dialogue, like other NOT-PLAYER CENTERED characters etc.). Every system you add on top of what you've got will expand the scope, audience, and profit of the game geometrically.2) Hire someone who knows how to write a story and populate a world with characters. If you're going to end the story like you did (and hint at a sequel like you did), you need to have a reason for us to follow the guy we play as. For the audience to care, you need a good characterization and some intriguing humanization. Try engendering endearment with non-life threatening consequences (severing of relationships, loss of 'honor' or something else your guy values).3) Don't give up. You've made something really great here, but it seems like you've stopped. Don't do that.4) With every step you take, ask if someone has done it before. If you can, try to make your solution unique.good luck

number of helpful: 6 of 16 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												RNG + Grindfest + Enforced micromanage = This. Making a meh-ish game is one thing, but watering it down with RNG poopfest is definitely over the line. Even the infamous Dungeon Crawl tries to make randomness controllable, and this... 'game' is just... too much.At least in other roguelikes, you get to choose starting options. BALANCED AND MULTIPLE OPTIONS, IN DETAIL. Instead in this 'game', we get take-it-or-leave-it starter's kit with Tetris level freedom of choice. If you can't get to skin the Dogman at the start, you're likely to end up dead like 10 minutes after.Say that you made the build, got the coat. Well, congratulations, you completed requirement for 30-minute survival. Enjoy so-oh-♥♥♥♥ing-much-DayZ-like loot grindfest. Let's scavenge this! Duh, empty!  And this! Yes, we got completely useless shirts and jeans!...While managing god-awful award-winning inventory. It's complete nightmare : tiny tiny single slot items, liquids being treated as individual items, all those junk items with no clear given use or whatsoever. Whatever you craft, it it's makeshift, expect them to be broken down like 10 minute later.If the progression of game itself was fun, I'd bear it. But in this game... it's like kicking the same old ground. Scavenge, find♥♥♥♥♥♥ make♥♥♥♥♥♥ scavenge more, rinse and repeat.But even with all these ♥♥♥♥♥, I guess people will still play it, because of it being 'Unique'. Well tell you what, go play Unreal World instead. The game is older, with more contents and more things making sense, and less HARDCORE RNG SUHVIVORR ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												Ugh.  Let me just sum up my buyer's remorse with two points on why I do not recommend this game:1.) It plays as badly as it looks -- turns out this isn't one of those indy 'ugly duckling' games that have outdated graphics but excellent content and playability.  The graphics, story and gameplay are all sloppy.  Not to mention the previews are misleading.2.) The game relies purely on difficulty to make this a survival game, lacking any of the richness I was expecting given the high praise among the Steam community.  One would expect that a game rated so highly would have sacrificed looks for content, and it certainly is lacking in both -- instead it's a series of instant-death by storyline misadventure or because the character is about as hardy and resiliant as wet one-ply toilet paper... despite being 'tough'.I wanted to have some nice things to say about this game, but I really can't find anything worth the $15.  I would argue this should be considered no more than a $2 curiosity than a game worth the developer's asking price.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
												I keep coming back to this game thinking "I'll figure it out" but am frustrated every time. The concept is appealing and hats off for what could/should be a fun game to play, but the implementation has me face-palming every time. I pick an athletic character so I can run away from baddies. I meet one and flee, farther and farther... now over 200 spaces away... he keeps coming... I'm weary and try to rest. Lo and behold, all my camping gear is still here. Where have I been running. Can't see which hex I'm in. No graphical way to see how far the baddie is away from me. I'm thirsty, hungry and weary. He's still far off. I have time. There's food and water here, but for some reason I can't eat or drink any of it. I wait so long that eventually the baddie falls asleep. I creep away. Success! When I finally get back to a map, I'm only one hex over and all my gear is back in the hex I left. My chosen skills are perception, hiding and tracking so I "spy" on the hex I think I just left to see if the baddie is in that hex. (I have no idea where I've been running for literally five minutes.) Nothing detected in that hex. I move back in only to be attacked and die from the baddie. Screw it. I give up. Delete.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												There crux of this game is you wandering around the wilderness re-arraning your pack to carry the maximum amount of junk you find. Descriptive working  titles include:"Homeless Man Shopping Cart Arrranger" or "Vagrant Cardboard Box Simulator"also "Hobo with a Shotgun Plastic Bag Minmaxxer."The idea for this this game and it's mechanic is very ingenious. The developer is very dedicated. The RNG element makes the skill cieling very low.In general: Random elements exist postively in a game for two primary funtions; to create variety & to approximate the large & infinte variables of reality. While I appreciate their intended role in this game is to do precisely those two things the simple fact is their implementation is coutner-productive here. The simple fact is if the RNG doesn't grant you the ability to find clothes in the first 12 tiles or so your game is over. God help you should you get attacked before findin a weapon.I really liked this game (& the developer) but I can;t in good faith reccomend it.Also the combat is like doing the Math portion of the SATs whilst ȿhit-faced; an ardous ordeal whereupon your efforts to apply skill or reasoning only inhibit the actual deciding factor: random chance.

												way too hard, way too much luck involved. boring because permadeath makes you start over and over again - which means no chance to follow the story.it feels like black jack... you try to minimize the chances against you but in the end you know the bank is going to win at some point.of course you could start to hide a lot and to walk away from every fight and hide your tracks and stuff like that but then the game would become way too slow and it would take aeons to get through the story (and the rage factor after some really unlucky death would rise to infinity). i mean it is already slow because you have to deal with too much micromanagement and some really counter intuitive stuff. now add some permadeath and one really dumb encounter and everything starts again.i made two posts on their forums about those issues but the die hard fanboys over there don't seem to get the point that everything they love about this game makes it a really crappy experience for the average player who has been lured in by phrases like "We serve the core role-playing game market by making role-playing games that focus on:exploring worldscustomizing characters and equipmentcreative problem solvingstory".sorry to bring it to you but in neo scavenger you neither explore worlds (because you die and start all over again due to unlucky circumstances) nor get something from the story (because permadeath + no luck). i played it now for 24 hours and all i've seen is the facility i wake up in and it's near surroundings. creative problem solving: well in a twisted way you have to solve some really creative problems like for example the shoe problem - your player character is too dumb to put his shoes on. no joke. so if you wonder why you wear a pair of the same shoes but still get that improper footwear message just check if the right shoe really is on the right foot and the left shoe really is on the left foot. (<- my favorite example because it really represents just how bad the game design gets at stages). at least you can customize your character and equipment.it's a shame that you don't see anything of the world and story because what i really like about this game is that it somehow still manages to be immersive.this game is for people who love micromanagement and boring repetitive stuff. definitely not a game for someone who's into story and exploration and adventure.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												This game is the reason why I don't like spending more than $20 on a game.  Put simply, the game is terrible.  At its heart, it's a crafting game.  I like crafting games, but this one suffers from the same pitfall as many other titles in the genre.  There is no effective way to organize one's inventory.  It's a huge mess of items arranged by size.  It's nearly impossible for a player to understand what he has at any given time.  This would be forgiveable if the gameplay was decent, but it's not.  Combat is a complete mess.  I found myself trying to avoid combat because it is simply too much of a hassle.  There is almost no information given about the foes, and who wins is pretty much a crapshoot.  I have nothing good to say about this title.  It is one of the two worst games I've played in the last couple of years.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
												I wanted to like this game. I really did. I'm a fan of roguelikes, but this game tried to be both roguelike and linear at the same time. You start in the same place every time, and while that wouldn't be an issue, it's always the same scenario. That's the issue I have - I don't play a roguelike to do the same tired story missions over and over. It has some pretty unique elements to it, but the things that aren't good really ruin the game for me. In most roguelikes, I accept the sense of permadeath and the inevitability of some unfair losses, but this game takes it to another level, stranding you with little to no resources and then giving you a disease that can only be survived through either extreme luck with the RNG or a very specific item. It'd be different if it was avoidable, but you can contract it simply by getting close to the enemies that carry it - and a nearly unavoidable game-ending feature like that doesn't make for a good roguelike.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2016
												The game looked intriguing and certainly has a number of positive reviews, so I gave it a try. Ultimately however, this game just wasn’t for me.My main issue was that the game requires Adobe Flash Player, which (for me) frequently popped up during game play due to security settings, and ultimately crashed the game. And this was a huge annoyance, because every time I attempted to bring up the task manager to ‘end task’, the crash-screen interceded. It did present a quit or send error option, however neither responded to my input, ultimately I had to restart my computer.The other issue, which I admit is simply a stylist preference, was the color depth and color pallet, this game is definitely retro, like C64 retro. This included the user interface, which was very challenging (for me) to navigate, and in the short time I played this game I was never quite sure that what I intended to do was actually completed successfully (in a word: feedback).Unfortunately I was unable to play long enough to experience the story and atmosphere, which have been repeatedly praised for this game.

number of helpful: 13 of 35 people (37%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 24
												Great game, if you like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. I was in perfect condition, no wounds, full health, everything. Out of nowhere, I get "Poison stage 2" "Sepsis" "Severe Abdominal Pain". So I go to the hospital. Get "Treatment for all sicknesses and Poisons"(♥♥♥♥ing nanorobots!). Painkillers. Anitbiotics.It does nothing. All of a sudden I get "Blood loss" (without wounds btw). "You are getting colder" AND "you are suffering from heat exhaustion"(at the same time lol). Bam, dead. Btw, this is WITH a trait that says: "You have a strong immune system".In the Forum, I find a bunch of posts a la: "Sepsis uncurable" etc.So yeah, lots of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t RNG. Like enemies RIGHT NEXT to you being able to escape, etc.Let's get into it.Right off the bat, this is a really amatureish game. It runs in Abobe FLASH PLAYER (lol). You can't take screenshots. If you click "New game", it doesn't even ask whether you want to delete your old save. It just deletes it instantly. So one misclick, and you're ♥♥♥♥ed.The inventory system is really bad; just your basic grid inventory. There is an auto arrange function. But that's it. No logic. Can't flip items. Can't put items in your hoodie's pockets, if you have a coat over it. Got some wire? You can hang a crowbar over your shoulder! But not a spear.Crafting is stupidly tedious. You have to drag items into the screen, to even see what you can make. WHY? How about you just show us what we can make from all our items? Nope.Recipes are nothing but written instructions. Have fun scrolling through pages of text. Intuitiveness = 0.Also, it's got the most basic quest system I have EVER seen in a game. IF you can get someone to talk to you, they give you one sentence, end of conversation. I say IF, because even if you hold someone at gunpoint, they won't talk to you. BUT you waste a turn, so now they can hit you in the face. And then escape. Seems legit.Also, just a little PSA to all wannabe game desingers out there: Items do not BREAK so quickly in real life. This is a survival game TROPE, and it needs to die. It's stupid.Survival Games "survive" on REALISM and LOGIC, and this game is just sub par in those regards.The fact that there is no help/tutorial whatsoever doesn't help either... Dying of some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t is NOT "experiencing" or "learning". It just sucks. I refuse to play another mediocre survival game, while having to read the ♥♥♥♥ING wiki...That's another ♥♥♥♥ing survival game trope. Gtfo!That being said, the game CAN be fun at times, in the usual survival game fashion. But seeing as this BS is making me consider just stopping this game already, I think it warrants a "thumbs down"If this was the first survival game ever, it would be ok. But survival games come a dime a dozen, since over a decade, so you should have the genre figured out by now. And being an "Indie", is not an excuse.VERDICT: Low production value survival game with BS RNG mechanics, lack of logic, and -occasionally- fun.Buy at your own risk. Don't expect a great game.UPDATE: Just died in a fight. I had a knife. It "Scratched" him. Guy hit my arm with the blunt end of a pistol. I passed out from "unbearable pain" (hahaha). Guy kept hitting me. Died from brain injury.♥♥♥♥ this game.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												This game isn't challenging like one would expect it to be. Faster Than Light is challenging, Don't Starve is challenging, this game is just plain unfair.This game is completely dependent on luck. The first place the player scavenges from might either give the player clothes, a backpack, medicine, etc, or, and far more likely, will give the player absolutely nothing with a high chance of the building calapsing on top of the player. Going to sleep can either result in actually sleeping for a healthy amount of time and waking up the next morning, or just dying in the player's sleep(players can set up noise traps and all that but that never works). Combat can either result in three hits to the skull with a weapon actually killing the enemy, or getting punched once and dying instantly from it. Though usually before any of these scenarios can occur, the player will just die of hypothermia. People on the forums will tell others that if they get that skill, and this skill, and that other skill, then do this and that, then the player will never die, sure sounds like a lot of fun don't it?

												I hate this game so much. I die, I play again, I die again, I hate this game again. I stop for a few days. I come back. I play again. I die. I hate it so much.I install cheats. I still die. I hate this game. I keep wanting to play this game, but I hate it so much. I sit at my computer wanting to play a video game, wanting to play NEO Scavenger, but also hating NEO Scavenger, so instead I just sit here thinking about how much I hate this game and how much I want to play it longer than two in-game days before dying. I hate this game so much.It's like erotic denial when you didn't ask for it.It's like having a black hole in your stomach so you just keep feeling hungry no matter what you eat.It's like an arranged marriage to someone who keeps putting to toilet paper roll the wrong way.It's like discovering your new graphics card doesn't fit your computer case.It's like insomnia.It's like all those things but not really like all those things, but really I just hate this game. But I'm gonna go play it right after finishing this review. Actaully, I'm gonna go look for a Save Game mod before I go play again. Game Saving is the only thing I need for this game. Game Saving would make me NOT hate this game. Game Saving--any kind of Game Saving--would save this game. Only Save at camp with specific paramiters, only Save at certain locations, only Save five times ever per play session. Any of those would work. Any of those would make me not hate this game.I like everything about this game except the perma-death. Literally everything else. The world, the gameplay, the mystery, the NEED to discover what is going on with my character. Everything is good. But perma-death makes me hate this game more than I have hated any game in a long time. It is literally stopping me from enjoying this game. It's the only thing I need this game to have. I hate dying because I don't know what a thing in game is, and then having to slog through the ENTIRE beginning again and hope I find useful items again.This game is too brutal to not have saves.

number of helpful: 36 of 91 people (40%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												A "game" with no gameplay elements.Every aspect of the game is completely random and simply beyond your control. No skill or tactics to employ, just plain old luck determines whether you'll live each day. Combine this with permadeath, and you find yourself stuck replaying the same day over and over again, having about as much fun as Bill Murray did when caught in the same loop.I'm being serious, you can fall, cut yourself, and die of blood loss just from *walking* if that's how the dice roll (advancing in combat carries the chance to trip and fall). Whether or not you find shoes and clothes in time to keep warm and not die from hypothermia, pure luck. Whether you wake up in time to defend yourself before an enemy kills you in your sleep, pure luck. Whether you can actually get to sleep because it's random whether or not you'll find a sleeping bag and it rains constantly... again, luck. Whether your very first fire started in a burnt out office building because you are hiding from the rain with nothing but a hospital gown and a large stick attracts an entire pack of feral dogs who you literally have zero chance against... need I go on?There's just no meaningful interaction. All of your equipment wears out shockingly fast and it's a crapshoot whether you'll find a replacement. At times it feels like a miracle during an encounter just to close the gap to an enemy without tripping over yourself and falling to the ground before you can poke 'em with your spear. Start a fire to keep warm and attract an enemy you aren't ready to deal with. Lay low and hide, die of hypothermia. Damned if you do and damned if you don't. Either option is viable based solely on luck. You're not playing a game so much as just watching the unluckiest man on Earth die over and over again.There is no character progression. You know how to make everything right away. Just put all of your swag into the crafting table and whatever can be made is instantly available. However good you are at fighting and surviving from the moment you wake up is as good as you're ever gonna be. All of your equipment has a ridiculously short lifespan. So even if you find a really good anything, don't get attached. Even crowbars wear out... CROWBARS! Solid bars of pure steel... wear out.  Seriously?There's just no feeling of accomplishment. None. If you manage to survive for a week, it's not because you did anything right, you just got lucky. A first playthrough can net you shoes, cargo pants, a hoodie, a multitool, and a saucepan after 12 hours of scavenging. A second playthrough can net you a cut arm, 200 pebbles, a handful of poison berries, and 3 shards of glass after 12 hours of scavenging. The player is reduced to the role of spectator of the very short and uninteresting life of some guy named Phillip.Without engagement, without meaningful choices to make, without progression, there's just no game here.

number of helpful: 12 of 40 people (30%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								It is a bad sign when the demo is more fun than the main game.NEO Scavenger has, as everyone has said, a TON of potential.  There is just so much they could do here.  Combat feels granular and staisfying, while at the same time being crazy-lethal if you're not careful.  The loot you find feels like you're struggling to survive, and the crafting system is elegant.  Character creation is simple, but offers meaningful choices.  It's got a LOT of good stuff in it.But the main game also wants to have a story.  And that main quest line feels kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥ when it's next to what would make a fantastic open-world survival game.  Since death is frequent, and often from kinda unfair places, having to redo the same quests over and over is unsatisfying, to say the least.  And I'm not a hundred percent sure if the game has magic in it or not, because it sure seems like it sometimes, and that clashes with the flavor of a sci-fi wrecked earth.Oh, the deaths.  Man.  I have died a dozen times at least from starting a game, and freezing to death before I can find shoes.  I have died because I can't find clean water, or anything to boil water in to sterilize it.  I have died from a single lucky gunshot.  I like how lethal the game can be, but I do not enjoy at all how arbitrary it feels at times.Also, the demo thing.  The demo shows off a scavenging system where each city tile has multiple things to search.  Do you check the storage shed, which may have nothing but is pretty safe, or do you go for the high rise, where you might get jumped, but could have a lot more left over?  The main game has one thing to search per tile.  Choice : eliminated.  Just right out the window.  I cannot, in good faith, recommend a game where the main game takes AWAY choices.

												This is overall a good game I think. it is not however worth 10 dollars as it is now. The game still feels like im playing to alpha test, and i understand this is an early acsess game, but is nowhere near complete enough to ask 10 dollars for. This game has real potential and i wished I waited until it was finished cooking before getting food poisoning by trying it early.Update 11/28/15: Saw it had been released and gave it another shot. content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								We are in 2014. The game is made with Adobe® Flash® Player, by someone who does now know this "technology". As a direct consequence, the game is very buggy, and should be free, on newsground; not $10 on Steam.I recognize that there is some work on the artistic side, even though the use of Flash just negates most of it. Technically, this game is a failure, and will stay that way: it is not possible to correct that point without a FULL RE-DEVELOPEMENT of it; and let's be honest, we can't expect that to happen. So, as a result, do not buy. Too bad, it seemed promising.EDIT: I see that there is 70% of negative votes on this review. I could maybe use a little feedback. So if you voted down, please comment, if you can. Thanks :)EDIT 2: If the game is re-released using something such as Unity or Game Maker instead of AFP, I will re-review it, with the game in mind, rather that with AFP in mind.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is an incredibly deep game with a ton of customization options but I found that most of the time I was trying to figure out what the developer wanted from me instead of playing against the game itself. A robust tutorial should be an immediate goal. And formatting to fit full screen on standard resolutions instead of playing in a Flash window would also be a great next step. At this time I wouldn't recommend it. But I'll watch it with interest as development continues.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								I got this game in a humble bundle, which is the only way I would suggest getting it. This is essentially a text-based game. The only way you know things are happening is by reading the log. You have buttons presented to you that are options. When you click the button, the log updates. Nothing else happens on the screen. Even if you win a combat, the only indication is from the combat log.The graphics are awful. The UI layout is haphazard. There are lots of slots and buttons that make no sense. For example, when you are in your inventory, there is a red X in the upper corner, which usually means "close window", but in this case it does nothing and has hover text that says "Current cursor mode. (1) Take (2) Drop (3) Use." What? I was able to drag a lake and forest around in my area inventory. Why? The game allows you to hang yourself constantly. It never seems to help or guide you to an appropriate choice. For example, it will let you start the game without picking any traits! Combat seems to happen randomly, and is a baffling ordeal. If you just click "Confirm" and have no action selected, your enemy will alternate between charging at you, advancing, leaving himself open, etc. No clue what's going on, there. I could never figure out how to eat. When I right clicked on berries in my hand and "used" them, they fell apart in my hand. Huh???Overall, this game is a complete mess, even if you can get past the crude graphics and terrible UI.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								Absolutely terriffic game. I love the scavenging and survival aspects, because this game does almost all of these right. The dialogue and combat are both fantastic, and the events are wonderful, too.However, this is all completely ruined by the fact that you will probably always freeze to death. You will not go in the right direction to find clothing. You'll be very lucky to find a lighter. And even if you do all these things, you probably already have hypothermia, and you'll be dead in a few turns. Almost always.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Fun for a little while but it gets pritty boring pritty fast. Understandably you start out with more or less nothing (depending on the skills you picked and if you bothered to use them in the first room) and for the genre and setting thats fine, however when 4 out of 5 Games Ends because you cant find a shirt, pair of pants and a set of boots before you freeze to death in what is clearly not a sub freezing enviroment the initial new game pains are a little frustrating.On top of that if you dont pickup either Trapping or Botany, you are going to starve to death. Beyond that its rather easy to stay alive. Remarkably easy really. The trailor vidoes hint at every decision potentially resulting in life or death but ive had very little trouble from noisly ransacking every building or storage unit i come accross with a crowbar and lighter. That might change however if i can ever light a fire... but of course ide need a tiny slip of paper to tell me how to use my lighter to start a fire and by the time i find that ill realise that I dont have the appropraite skill to start fires. Meanwhile Ill have alrleady hacked 2 laptops and a plethora of smaller eletrical devices to gain access to more or less nothing but a GPS that isnt neessisary because my map allready points out exactly where I am.Basicly I would give this one a pass for now, keep an eye on it though more features are bound to come out in time.

								This game is the worst form of survival games. It is a random number generator linked to some stats if you don't find the needed items randomly by scavenging your choices do not matter at all and you die. Early Access Review
								At no point have I ever had fun 'playing' this game. At no point have I ever been glad I purchased it. At no point will I recommend this game to my friends. I will recommend NEO Scavenger to child molesters, terrorists who spill American blood, and women who call grown men 'hun' because they deserve to suffer. This is not a game for people. NEO Scavenger is a device used to test if a player is human or not, much like the Voight-Kampff Test. Time spent interacting with his horrid program will only expose a player as being a poorly made simulacrum, a hollow mimic, who is not truly alive, because real people play real games. NEO Scavenger isn't a game, it's a punishment.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								Don't let the boardgame hex look and turn-based gameplay fool you: This is a complex survival simulation, one of the best I've played and almost certainly the best on Steam. Even in early access, the game is in a completely playable and mature state, a notable contrast to the buggy, imbalanced status of almost every game available in this genre.The drag/drop crafting system is intuitive yet almost too simple, at once the game's greatest asset and biggest barrier to sinking too much time into it. A few minor ease of use tweaks would go a long way. Still, conceptually, this is the kind of system RPGs need to return to, especially outside of the roguelike/survival setting. The far less accessible UnReal World is the only game I can think of that compares. This game drops a lot of the old-school roguelike cruft in a positive way (usually that's a bad thing!), so I would honestly recommend this to anybody interested in this sort of game first.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								NEO Scavenger is a fun little indie title by Blue Bottle Games, if your vision of fun is watching your character slowly dehydrate to death after you develop diarrhea from a diet composed of berries and swamp water. Despite being incredibly unforgiving the permadeath mechanic makes it an excellent game to play in short bursts, and death itself is not that much of a frustration.In its early access state it has a great crafting system and survival mechanics that can only get better, but it suffers from a combat system that needs a lot of work and a big lack of NPC interactions.If you enjoy the survival genre or even turn-based games this little gem is a nice title.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								Imagine the original Fallout set in Michigan, with text based combat that goes into far more detail- well, nearly every aspect of this game involves detail, detail, DETAIL! I died so many times in the beginning because I failed to realize you actually have to boil water, lest you will sooner or later drink something nasty and slowly die (that is, if a raider, bandit, or mutant does not take advantage of your weakened state first). Events utilize traits choen at the beginning to provide you options based on your skill sets, such as using medical knowledge to release a cryogenic tube's inhabitant as bait, so you can make a clean escape from a mutant freak. Pressing survival issues also include sleep, hunger, hypothermia, health status (pain, poison, infection, bleeding, all of which can be combatted with aid such as banadages and antibiotics.... or even scotch as a painkiller!). It really is too bad though that you can only wear boots, but cosmetics aren't much of an issue when the average character lifespan in the beginning is less than 3 days.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game does an excellent job of combining roguelike elements (map randomization, loot randomization, permadeath) with a post-apocalyptic environment.  As a parent of two children, it's rare when I spend 24 hours (at the time of writing this review) on a single game.Although I am still working my way through the narrative, I am finding it very interesting and it reminds me of my early days of computing where the story is told using text with minimal pictures, allowing you to form your own image of what's going on.  I didn't realize I had missed that until I played this game.  It's great.In other games (Elder Scrolls, Terraria) I have not been a huge fan of crafting, but I'm finding that in this game I really enjoy it.  I've found most of the basic recipes, but I have a feeling some more will appear as I progress through the narrative.  This game has changed my opinion of crafting in games and got me looking into others (Project Zomboid, for example).As this game is still in beta, I think some user interface improvements would be helpful going forward.  Some examples include the ability to easily combine stacks of items such as pills, without removing them from the pill bottles, and the ability to consume stacks of items such as berries (rather than eating one at a time).  Recipes could be streamlined as well if there were a way to chain them together.  For example, harvest meat, create fire, cook/cure meat.  Or create fire, sterilize water.  These are minor annoyances and don't detract from the enjoyment of the game, but could greatly streamline things.Overall, I really like this game.  As someone who didn't care for rogue likes or crafting games in the past, this game has really opened my eyes.  I don't know how to explain other than I play the game just for the fun of the game.  Rather than playing to progress the story as in a traditional RPG.  Many times, I don't even pursue the story; I just scavenge and try to get the best equipment and camping gear possible.  Lastly, I'm also excited to see what the recently implemented modding ability will bring.

								Neo scavenger is a game that allows you to select a number of skills and disabilities, such as being good at lockpicking, identifying herbs and mushrooms, or being shortsighted, fragile, or weak.You then go on a journey across a hexagonal map, scavenging buildings and combatting various gruesomes, crafting items and completing quests.Think of it as a small scale S.T.A.L.K.E.R.I find it fun for short bursts.Protip - Tracking is a great skill - it lets you make a high quality piece of clothing from the first enemy you encounter - If you fight it that is.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								Neo Scavenger is a unique game thats been in development a long time. If you're a fan of survival strategy games, or just like playing great games, this is the game for you. Its the kind of game you can play whether you care about stories or not, you can play the story to the currents end, and roam around, just seeing how long you can survive, or just skip to surviving right away. Both are equally fun. In a sense, the game is a little like Dwarf Fortress: Adventure Mode, where "dying is fun!," and where its fun to bumble around and ♥♥♥♥ yourself over countless times. However, just like Adventure Mode, its annoying in the sense that if you don't know what you're doing, you're liable to shoot yourself in the foot right off the bat, however the learning curse is pretty low, so you won't have to worry about that for long, espically if you watch videos on Youtube or read forums.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Do you like an intense game that rewards player skill, encourages thoughful play, and punishes reckless play styles? Do you like a game with a broad open world with plenty to explore and do? Do you like running screaming from crowbar weilding maniacs?Well, Neo Scavenger has all of this and more. This game with torture your psyche and leave you begging for more. This game is an intense and brutal introduction to a realistic post social collapse world. A world of monster, and maniacs. This game with♥♥♥♥♥♥you off, and bring you to your knees in frustration, and yet, at the same time, leave you cackling maddly after barely skating by in a pitched battle with an all too lucky looter. This game will delite and agrivate you in fairly equal parts, and always give you a reason to pick back up and start a new game each time you find your character has once more gotten his skull caved in by one of the many hideous monstrosities in the game. The best part, most of the monsters in this game are flesh and blood humans, not mutants, not zombies, normal humans, driven to the edges of maddness by a cold cruel and uncaring world.Will this world drive you mad too? Are you up to the challenge of the Michigan wilds? Can you handle the constant threat of being someone or something else's next meal? Can you survive in the brutal world of Neo Scavenger? Or will this brutal world swallow you up without so much as a burp, as so many before?

								This is a very interesting game with great looking art, an AMAZING system for just about everything, and it's also the only game I have ever even heard of where you can die from cholera, blue rot, being gored to death by a robotic saber tooth tiger, being chopped to bits by a robot, acute bleeding in the lungs, traumatic head injury, and numerous other diseases and medical conditions. 								This game exceeds all the survival post-apocalyptic games I have ever played. It truly gives a new meaning to survival where finding a can of soup is life and death. That person you just killed even though he didn't have any form of defending himself has clothing and shoes for you to survive longer in the cold nights. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								As a post apocylipic survival game, Neo Scavenger serves as a (probably) pleasent diversion from the typical zombie survival genre. In this game you are faced not only enemies from both the earth and beyond, but also with realistic factors to your person that may prove your undoing if neglected, and you are also faced with perma death.Combat in this game makes up with it's lack of action with it's in depth desicion system that controls how you approach situations, which also comes to play in miscelanious events that fall outside of regular gameplay. These 'events' will grant you with better outcomes if you select the right perks for your character at the beginning the game. Select the wrong ones during character creation, however, then you might as well let the dogmen (not to be confused with werewolves) eat you where you stand.The cruel realism of the game forces you to think, making this game fun to play and giving it it's strategic element. And now that modding is becoming available, I personally cannot wait for all the crazy - or scary - ideas the comunity can grant for this game!

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								You either live long enough to see the source of the lights to the South-East, or you die from hunger, dehydration, hypothermia, or by a single attack from another human you couldn't sneak away from in the first few days.While you have a choice of skills at the start, the majority of the game is strongly effected by luck.  Luck of loot found, luck of places to camp in, luck during encouters; a single fluke can kill you.  With permadeath a constant fear, one must be wise about every action taken.It's a good turn-based survival, almost table-top-like game.  Your real entertainment will be seeing how long you can survive in this post-apocalypse world.  You have to use your imagination for most of it, but to those who enjoy roguelikes or table-top strategy games will find this a good buy.There's a demo; if you're even the slightest bit curious, TRY IT.  (there are things omitted from the demo, but it'll give you a very good idea of how to play the game)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								I now got nearly 24 hours of this game on the clock. And i really like the simplicity of the design and the general way the game throws stuff randomly at you. It's not Disneyland and at least you do not need to worry about the occasional troll like in DayZ or else. BUT.Here goes:   - The GUI is sometimes cumbersome to control. For example you need to switch from the crafting screen to the movement screen to end your turn with a click of the mouse. Or you need to get send to the movement screen after waking up. need to go to the sleeping screen to sleep again. I see that the pattern of view fields on the left and action fields on the right is partially implemented. but could use some rework to make it more smooth. And the inventory moves stuff around, when consumed, that just confuses.   - You do not really see how many moves you got left and how much moves something takes. As a person, you normally have a good feeling how long you take for what task and plan accordingly.   - The important part, realism:    - Infections do not kill you within hours (i had no fights, no injuries and i get killed by an infection of a wound recieved in a fight, just a few turns back.. That got treated with sterile cloths and antibiotica... yeah no).   - Cured meat lasts far longer than two days tops. Iregularly smoke fish without salt and fish is far more prone to go bad than regular meat, and it lasts longer.  - The water consumption is way over the top, for the climate displayed. Heck you can't even sleep a night through without waking up by thirst in the middle of darkness!I'd like to see the points above as an encouragement to the dev to make a good game great.As i said, i got no problems with the randomness of the opponents or that you can get killed by a lucky blow of your opponent.♥♥♥♥♥♥happens ! Random loot, fine by that. Selling Prices at the Junkyard. Maybe Tannine Tea is a bit much, but thats a small thing. Corn-A-Cola too much effect? Nope! I've seen people collapse after they fell into a sugar and caffein low with red bull. I am unsure about the watermechanic of the game . Normally water from flee flowing runnels and streams is generally safe to consume to an extend (i mean the setting is clearly not in the tropics). Best but slowest is water gathered after rain or from dew, then again we do not know how much the rain is polluted in the game. All over all a good game, considering the pricetag and that it is early access. I played less hours on Titanfall, and that was quite hyped.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								The combat is turn based, but feels organic and possesses a gritty realism that is unparalleled. The first few fights are always the worst until your last. You take turns tackling other survivors to the groud, kicking while they're down, dragging and scraping and brutally beating one another with whatever wrench or saucepan or tree limb that is at hand until one of you begs for mercy, but only after sustaining a broken arm and internal bleeding. On the other hand, simply waving a gun and shouting is usually enough to scare off scavangers, nevermind you don't have any bullets because they don't need to know that. When a turn based system can get your heart pounding, something is being done right.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								First - try the demo. The game style is somewhat of a niche, so it may not be for you. After that... well if you're still reading, perhaps a review is in order.Perhaps the best way to explain why NEO is worth a shot is the fact that I've introduced three players to it, with each having exactly the same responses (almost stages of grief style). First is the inevitable freezing to death ("What? What did I do wrong? This game is stupid!"). Next is figuring out how to survive that part ("Ah, I can use that sleeping bag until I find clothes, or possibly light a fire"), normally followed by having your head bashed in by someone ("What? What did I do wrong? This game is stupid!").Next run through you figure out how to make weapons ("Now I can go take on those damn bandits!"). And, after killing a couple, you WILL get cocky and drown on your own blood ("What? What did I do wrong? This game is stupid!"). By about the fourth serious run (normally with a half-dozen freezing to deaths in there) you're surviving, and doing it well. You start analysing the risks of combat (he has a machete, I have a bow... how close do I let him get?). From there your deaths are almost always due to errors on your part - surviving can be time consuming but is generally not hard, unless you want to deliberately handicap yourself by not taking the easy way (no trapping skills, no botany skills) for a difficulty boost - and all three players were hooked. At each stage you could see them figuring out what to do next, how to avoid the mistake they made last time.Despite what some reviews have said you do not need to find the recipe papers to make anything - they tell you how to, but if you put the ingredients in the crafting screen it will let you know what you can make. Generally it's pretty intuitive too - large stick plus knife equals sharpened stick, for example, but you soon learn the crucial recipes by heart.Yes, it's unpolished. Yes, it's flash. Yes, the story and interface leave a lot to be desired. But it's still well worth the time.

								This is a game where some desperate guy will try to beat you to death with a stick to get that one left boot you're wearing. If you survive the encounter, now you have to deal with your broken limbs and keep your cuts form being infected.  I've like some other survival games like Don't Starve, Terraria, etc., but it works so much better turn-based. The setting is like a more believeable version of the shadowrun universe. content:

Early Access Review
								A well-made survival game with simple graphics yet offer a good amount of contents. To survive in a place full of looters, gangsters and even cryptids isn't an easy task, and you have to take care of your wounds, your daily food consumption and to manage resources available to you wisely. I've been like 4 hours into the game, and restarted four times with a new character of different traits each time. Every trait grants you unique ability to aid you in your survival, or even add some unique actions in certain encounters, however you can only choose 4 of them at the beginning (Or more than that up to 8 if you willing to add penalties to your character), so pick wisely and experiment on their effectiveness. Only through continuous learning shall you survive the unforgiving Michigan wasteland...

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
Early Access Review
								Well, if you're into games like FTL, or df in the way you pretty much lose no matter what, this is your game! GAMEPLAY:In every way its a flash game, as most of us gamers believe, flash games suck for the most part. Though, this game is interesting and enjoyable. There are wolfdogs(kind of like a warewolf but dog instead....first encouter creature) and melonheads(science experiments gone wrong?), then you have good old raiders and looters. The AI in this game is really good! It tracks you(every time you move you have tracks layed down, and the AI can/will follow them if you dont hide them. There are skills that allow you to scavenge better, like lock picking. You can build things with machanic, etc. There is a large crafting system, vehicals to pull/push your stuff around(aka sleds, shopping carts.) So, all in all if you're like me, meaning you pinch every penny and get at least 20+hrs from every game, then this is most likely for you. 10/10 would buy.

								Wow. Just wow. This game is hard, unforgiving, and near impossible. I love it. My last playthrough, I had taken a guides advice with slight modification of my own and I was a super power nothing could kill me, except for nature herself. I had taken down four dogman, six strangers, Ftons of melonheads, and an enfiend horror all within six hexex of each other and only minors cuts and bruises as my reward, oh and a few dozen bullets, a couple guns, water bottles, and furs out the wazzo. This was only half way through. I wasn't playing the story, I wanted to gear up, I was challenging myself out in the wilderness and it was fun! Just doing what I wanted, fighting when I had to, chatting when I didn't, and just surviving. This can be a casual game or a hardcore game it depends on how you want to play, do you want to follow the story or simply explore the whole map. But in my opinion fun is all this game is going to be. Don't mistake it though. Remeber the badass you just read up there I overestimated myself and attacked when I should have dodged with hunger and thirst nearly claiming me along the way. Thus ending my adventure but also beginning a new and, hopefully, better one.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								Very much enjoyed this game and will likely play it some more. I haven't even gotten very far so far, just under 5 days of survival I believe. Much like FTL (Faster Than Light) you will find this game gives the player a number of significant choices in a world that is generated differently each time with events equally varied and random. The game has it's flaws, to be sure. And without using much of a guide thus far I still occasionally get confused or am unsure as to how some mechanic works. It has occurred once that I was in a fight I believed I was winning when all of a sudden my equipment had disappeared and I was out of battle finding myself thinking to the game "I'm sure you're right, but why?". All in all, the game has many possibilities to make it immersive, there are a few things to be improved on, a few minor bugs and a learning curve if you want to make your way far. But all in all, I would say this is great for a player looking for a good survival game. Much like FTL, this game isn't made for you to be the hero, or in your favor like other games where you are central to the plot. You exist on it's terms, you can't run around being all-mighty.I would also like to add that this game has static graphics to accommodate the text/UI based game so don't expect anything aesthetically amazing. The graphics accomplish what they need to accomplish, they will make the world feel complete, but not 'beautiful', and to be frank that's fine. It suits what the game is. With that said, I would also like to add that the text portions are very well written in my opinion and the events I have encountered thus far have been incredibly interesting.This game isn't for everyone. If you aren't interested in survival games I wouldn't recommend it, nor if you are looking for a beautiful game. If you believe you have the imagination however or desire to see how you'd fare in a survival game I would definitely suggest looking into the game a bit further and possibly throwing out the $10 to buy into the game.

content:

Early Access Review
								I got this game AGES ago when it was MUCH less complete than it is now, and even then it was great. Since then, the game has grown by leaps and bounds, and with every new build it gets better. A post apocalyptic setting that isnt just an irradiated desert makes for an interesting environment with a lot more options. The crafting system has so much depth its rediculous. Countless items, weapons, ingredients, great resource management elements, weather systems, and a story that will slowly but surely draw you in. Permadeath is a bummer, but you can always reload a previous save. However, chosing to start again with new traits and skills is just as rewarding, with a new experience with each new game. Even the opening moments of the game will change depending on your chosen traits. I can not reccomend this game highly enough.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								NEO Scavenger is a fun little indie title by Blue Bottle Games, if your vision of fun is watching your character slowly dehydrate to death after you develop diarrhea from a diet composed of berries and swamp water. Despite being incredibly unforgiving the permadeath mechanic makes it an excellent game to play in short bursts, and death itself is not that much of a frustration.In its early access state it has a great crafting system and survival mechanics that can only get better, but it suffers from a combat system that needs a lot of work and a big lack of NPC interactions.If you enjoy the survival genre or even turn-based games this little gem is a nice title.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								Imagine the original Fallout set in Michigan, with text based combat that goes into far more detail- well, nearly every aspect of this game involves detail, detail, DETAIL! I died so many times in the beginning because I failed to realize you actually have to boil water, lest you will sooner or later drink something nasty and slowly die (that is, if a raider, bandit, or mutant does not take advantage of your weakened state first). Events utilize traits choen at the beginning to provide you options based on your skill sets, such as using medical knowledge to release a cryogenic tube's inhabitant as bait, so you can make a clean escape from a mutant freak. Pressing survival issues also include sleep, hunger, hypothermia, health status (pain, poison, infection, bleeding, all of which can be combatted with aid such as banadages and antibiotics.... or even scotch as a painkiller!). It really is too bad though that you can only wear boots, but cosmetics aren't much of an issue when the average character lifespan in the beginning is less than 3 days.

Early Access Review
								This game looks and is low-tech, with alot of difficulty for new players. (suggest you get the demo first). That being said, this game is amazingly fun, replayabled and has ALOT of places it can expand into. If you like hardcore survival and a great challenge, I can't recommend this game enough for you. I was amazed at how many hours I put into it after awhile, and just how easy it is to get back into it for a few hours. It gives me a feeling of satisfaction when surviving fights and finding great gear, because it isn't easy. The fighting is Do or Die and one wrong slip or one strong thrust of a spear from a Bad Mutha and you're out. Once again this game is great and I hope alot of people buy and support its creator.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								I really like Neo Scavenger. That's why there will be a long, LONG review on it. To Start, in even a short time of five hours, this game has left a great impression on me, from death to art style to dialogues... It's brilliant to begin with.Gameplay: You wake up in the middle of Michigan in some sort of year, in which humanity is back to the dark ages. Heal yourself, fight, scavenge, explore, talk, DAMN. And more. Every choice is better then Mass Effect's Endings and choices. DAAAAMN. 10/10Story/Quests: Survive in the apocalypse, find out who you are, DUN DUN DUN! Kinda cliche, but I will give the quests and random encounters credit. 7/10Dialogues: Pretty long, and most of the lore is delivered through it, which was somewhat of a let-down. However, the dialogue was good. I'll shame it for it's lack of a Dialogue Tree thus far. 7/10AI: The AI was great. Enemies were either cowards or knew how to fight, and their AI reflected that. With the combat system, it sets up a difficulty of COMPLEXITY, and that's either really good or bad game design. Here, it's done great. 8/10World Design: Semi-Dynamic, beautifully designed, randomly generated. It's luck, but damn good luck. 9/10Graphics: The game is set up in a 32-bit art style (I believe?), and the graphics look promising. Some shots of the world are detailed, even with 32 pixels. This game would have great graphics back in the 32-bit era, and good indie graphics. 8/10Sound: Haha. None. 0/10Music: There is a death track, thus far. Nothing special. 4/10The verdict for NEO Scavenger is an 8.75/10. It delivers well, and it's promising, even for late Early Access. Some small tweaks, and this could easily go over a 9.DayZ Review Gimmick: "Slept in an office, robbed and left with my plastic bag. 8.75/10, would sleep again."

content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												I was honestly extremely skeptical about this game for its appearance and price tag. However, that skepticism turned out to be about as valid as trying to say that FTL isn't a good game because its graphics are primitive—the actual gameplay is masterful. I have been at this non-stop for maybe ten hours, and there's still obvious signs of endless story left. If you are the kind of person who plays Fallout New Vegas on Hardcore, has ever played a game of Rifts in your life, ever went on an Outward Bound and found it a little too tame, or just appreciates an all-consuming survival horror game; then this is for you. If it's on sale, it's definitely for you; but I've paid more for games I've liked a lot less!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												ORIGINAL REVIEW: Got so excited when I finally found a left shoe and a right shoe (even though one was a boot and the other a flip flop). Then my boot fell apart. Then I was mauled by a feral dog, and presumably eaten. Now I have to go back for more. 10/10FINAL REVIEW: After playing more, my opinion of this game has come to change. I still recommend it, because it is enjoyable, but buy it on sale. Starts as a 10/10, finishes as a solid 7/10. The mechanics are fantastic. It has the right "feel" for a game that has Scavenger in its name. The storyline is intriguing, and well presented through random newspaper articles. Combat is a treat, taking a break from standard "X ability does Y damage" combat, instead simply treating combat as any other encounter, and allowing you to determine which skills to use each turn. But there is simply not enough to go around.The beginning of the game feels like you're dipping your toe into a vast, deep, dark lake. But after a while, when you begin to figure things out, you realize that you aren't stepping into a deep dark lake filled with unknown dangers and treasures. No, you are simply looking at a puzzle, with pieces scattered, a system of parts that just need to be put together in the correct order. Don't get me wrong, puzzles can be fun. But they don't have the replayability that I seek from a roguelike. No matter how many times you dump the pieces out in a random order to start with, the end is always the same. Oh, and speaking of a lake...why no fishing? You can eat a squirrel. You can eat a dog. You can eat a person. But no fish?

												This game is fantastic! It is a little difficult at first getting the hang of it all, being there is so much you can do, but after a few hours, you get the hang of it. This is the game I've been looking for! I love it! So much is left up to you. You decide how you want to survive. You can take a stealthy botanist route and survive off the land or go bruiser and headbutt anyone you come across. One minute you could happily be cooking up some food and then suddenly realize you are being surrounded. Fight your way out, sneak out, or just hide. Truly a fantastic game and I've only had it one day.

												I am OBSESSED with this game right now. I definitely recommend it. The graphics aren't great, but I think the game makes up for it in content. I found it to be pretty tricky to survive on my first few play throughs. You'll probably die a lot. There's quite a bit of luck involved as well as strategy. You have to scavenge to find all your items, and it can be frustrating if you don't find shoes/clothes anywhere. I think the trickiest thing is finding a matching pair of shoes. There is a lot of storyline involved as well if you enjoy reading. Random events will pop up as you're wandering around. There seems to also be a main plot of figuring out who you are and who released you from the cryo chamber. All in all, it's a great game once you get the hang of not dying. lol

												This is one of my favorite games in recent years. It can be brutal, it can be unfair, it can be fruitful; sometimes all the preparation in the world won't help you out of the situation you find yourself in. Something about this game keeps me coming back and trying again, no matter how many times I end up dying. When you play a game that can keep you playing again and again, even after ruthlessly killing your character over and over again, it's a wonderous thing. If you end up buying this game, I recommend looking online for tips and hints, because there it is very difficult to learn everything you need to know just from playing the game by yourself.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												I was honestly extremely skeptical about this game for its appearance and price tag. However, that skepticism turned out to be about as valid as trying to say that FTL isn't a good game because its graphics are primitive—the actual gameplay is masterful. I have been at this non-stop for maybe ten hours, and there's still obvious signs of endless story left. If you are the kind of person who plays Fallout New Vegas on Hardcore, has ever played a game of Rifts in your life, ever went on an Outward Bound and found it a little too tame, or just appreciates an all-consuming survival horror game; then this is for you. If it's on sale, it's definitely for you; but I've paid more for games I've liked a lot less!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												I revisit this game once in a while because I've yet to find anything like it. It's a turn-based post apocalyptic survival game with elements of sci-fi and fantasy. My favorite thing about this game is probably that the inventory system attempts to be realistic, which I find to be annoyingly rare in video games.Criticisms?I really like that there is permadeath, though I think I would enjoy the game more if I felt it was possible for a skilled gamer to beat it on their first try. There are important details I've only been able to learn by dying or visiting the wikia, and I feel that takes away from the immersion. I've yet to beat it despite around 20 attempts.Why not have learned recipes carry over to future games?I'd prefer more of the information found on the wikia to be displayed in game, such as item component properties and weapon damage/range.Even the wikia doesn't have important details such as the degree to which things are affected by stat bars.I've forgotten or otherwise left out other issues that frustrated me about this game at first, but I don't regret buying it. For new players I recommend the first attempt be done without the wikia, and the expectation to survive. After that you may find that use of the wikia adds a considerable amount of replayability.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
												This game is brutal. It is unkind and unforgiving and sometimes it is straight up mean. Sometimes whatever God is left in the NEO Scavenger world decides that you looked at him funny, and so he introduces you to pain and anguish and misery. But in the event that God does not doom you to such a fate, you will find in this world amazing potential and unique adventures.You will learn what fear is. Fear will guide you away from conflict. Away from that man, from those dogs, from that Dogman. You fancy yourself a proud fighter? Proud men die. Fear will keep you on your toes, will check any scrape and cut meticulously, will get you home by nightfall. You will learn what hunger is. You'll find yourself starving, losing energy, panicking. Maybe you'll trap a squirrel for a snack. Or beat a feral dog to death for some real meat. Maybe you'll take a step back and wonder how things got this way - huddled in some burnt out building, greedily eating packets of ketchup and saltines, washing them down with questionable river water. You might even find yourself in an unthinkable situation. You might manage to hold your own against a bandit. He came upon you while you were sleeping and tried to loot your camp. You woke, and he punched your head in a panic. You stand and brandish a crowbar. He turns to run, but he trips. You seize the opportunity. You strike. Again and again. Soon his blood rushes from his crushed head. And only then do you realize how hungry you are.tl;dr buy it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 29, 2015
												I've played this game for fifteen hours now, not very far into it. I can make a few assertions about the game quality however. First allow me to state this fits into my desired game "style" very well. Turn-Based and Survival and two of my favorite types of games - this has both. Perma-death is also another great feature of the game. Namely, the sense if you die you have to start over is a great motivator to be extra careful while scavenging.The combat mechanics take a bit of getting used to, but once you have them down it's fairly easy to "manipulate" the encounter to be in your favor. Naturally you don't want to attack everything you see, sometimes it's wiser to stay hidden and let the group of guys with guns walk past you.The crafting system is great, it's very well thought out. I love having the ability to make a tarp shelter and after I'm done sleeping breaking it down and collecting my tarp and string to be able to move along with a smaller load.Scavenging for supplies is well done, the mechanic is both rewarding and frustrating at the same time - mainly when you're looking for something specific and keep getting trash.On my last play through I was horrifically murdered by the shop keeper. All I did was try to sell him cured human flesh, is that really so wrong?

												The first thing you have to know about NEO Scavenger:You will die. A lot. I was told there is a fabled ending to the game but I have yet to see it. That said, I adore this game. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												I have discovered my true calling as a hobo, fighting off feral dogs to scavenge post-apocalyptic ruins for anything remotely valuable.This game is quite good. It's actually very short, which is probably a good thing because it's so difficult. However, despite the amount of random ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that seems to kill you in this game, I never had a death where that I couldn't see why it was my fault. The world is extremely harsh, but you'll mostly find out about the stuff that kills you early in the game, or it's common sense, so you won't get to the endgame only to be insta-killed unless YOU do something stupid. Just be aware that the minute you DO do anything stupid, you will probably die. This, together with the core gameplay around surviving, is what kept me coming back to the game, even after ragequitting in frustration and deciding to never play it again. The different systems around survival -health, scavenging, combat, crafting, character creation, bartering, and inventory - work together extremely well. I have a weakness for survival and sandbox games, especially rogue-like survival games, but I'm also very harsh on them. I have a lot of problems with games like Minecraft, Rust, Ark, Terraria, DayZ and more. NEO Scavenger has been the perfect survival experience for me though. It's not something to spend hundreds of hours on, no. Based on my playtime so far and the playtime of other reviewers, 70ish hours seems to be the cap before interest dives. That's when I felt like I had thoroughly learned how the game worked. What makes this an engaging experience is going from knowing nothing about the game to being able to take on any challenge it thows at you. Amazingly, it succeeds in being an experience both fantastic and realistic.It's not perfect, of course. The story events and random events have some problems, but even though these choose-your-own-adventure style events can kill you, they're actually surprisingly lenient compared to the core mechanics of the game. You usually have to screw up pretty bad to get killed, and most frequently you just get a slap on the hand if you didn't choose exactly the right path through event. Since I died so much outside of the events, it was pretty fun to see how different paths and different character builds affected the outcome. Other than that, I personally couldn't care about the story and events very much. It's interesting, moderately good quality, and original. I normally love narrative and world-building in games, but in NEO Scavenger it took the backseat to the core gameplay. The only negative thing I can say about that is it could just use MORE. The art style, while flat, is exactly what it needs to be for the game, but everything definitely looks the same after only an hour or two. If there were a few more hex-types and some variation in textures, and especially if there was some physical depth, as in changes in elevation, to the terrain, it would be much more visually interesting. The item count is decent, but if there was just a bit more customization possible it would be awesome, and then every single npc wouldn't look identical. The map is actually quite large, and it can take a long time to get across it when you're looting everything that's even slightly lootable and fending off all manner of dangers along the way, but it could really use a few more unique locations with events tied to them, even though I said that's not what I'm here for. The character building is great: it really does feel like original Fallout and it totally determines what you can do and how you play, but for a system so deep it just feels so small. The world NEO Scavenger takes place in is very interesting, but outside of vague newspaper articles there's not actually all that much to explain it all. With a more cohesive and expansive lore, I could really get into this world. The story, like I said, is very short, and I frankly don't care that much about it; it's good enough for me. But it does have this interesting problem that unless you explore everything you can easily "complete" the story in just two "quests". It's pretty hard to tell what kind of story NEO Scavenger wants to tell, and how. I don't think it needs to be longer. With multiple paths and endings and the difficulty of the game it benefits from being short. But it does need a few more storytelling mechanics, and probably a better, more dense distribution of the story throughout the gameplay. As is, you play the core game and progress for a long while, and then you get a big chunk of wall-of-text story.All in all, if you want a solid survival role-playing game, this is what you want. I think that for the type of people who enjoy this game you can expect as much as 70 hours of extremely engaging time with this game, which is definitely worth $15. Enjoy!

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												In my last run, I found myself holed up in the cryo facility, which I'd made into quite the comfortable little strong-hold, with electric light, a comfortable bed, the works.  I'd only leave to collect water, firewood, or go hunting.  I could use the firewood to boil the water, and cook the food.  I scavanged what I could nearby, but that part of the map is pretty well picked-over.  I could get back to the barter-town and plot line, probably, but it'd be a lot easier if I could repair my push-cart.  I guess I'll chill at my chateau till the right parts show up on one of my few scavenging trips (I still need lighters from time to time, after all).  I'm armed enough that most critters and people in that part of the world aren't really a threat.  Yep, life is actually pretty good.  I'm thinking about taking up some farming, maybe learn to play an instrument, or ferment my own wine from the less poisonous berries around here.  I think I win the game, at this point, don't I?
