number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												Imagine if wasteland, Fallout, and stalker all came together and had an orgy. This is their love child. Hands down one of the best survival games I've ever played.Pretty much nails every aspect of survival as it should. Unlike most games you actually have to boil water, not eat every berry you find and not just place a cloth on a severe cut. The thing is if you have knowledge to survive in the wilderness in real life it makes this game a bit easier to play.I say a bit easier because in reality this can be a very difficult game. Expect to die loads of times before getting the hang of things. However, the game is fun and different enough on each playthrough to keep you going. Lots of times you might run across events or other things that you haven't before.Another reason I love this game is all the twists and turns you'll go through when you start uncovering the well hidden story in newspapers and when you first wake up.The game doesn't look bad and definitely gives me nostalgia to those old post-apocalyptic video games. You can do pretty much whatever you want to. If you want to run at a guy wielding an ak-47 with a stick, you can. If you want to run around naked stealing other people's stuff, you can. If you want to make a suit of tinfoil and become a crazy hobo you can.There is music in the game and it's pretty good, almost sounding like something that would be in the half life series. Sometimes the only sounds you'll hear is the various birds and critter chatter giving you a real sense of isolation. Although when you spot an event or something interesting one of the tracks might start up providing a cool atmosphere.It's really hard to talk about this game without spoiling anything, but what I can say it's one of the best survival post-apocalyptic games out there. So while you can go running through the woods butt-naked, you can also try and discover who you are and what exactly happened to the world around you. The choice is yours.

												NEO Scavaneger is a turn-based hardcore Survival game. The goal is to survive as long as you can in the harsh environment of post-apocolyptic Michigan. The game is quite brutal, and you will find yourself dying a lot. But the interface is easy enough to manage. You WILL feel pretty powerful once you're fully kitted out with the goodies you find scavenging around the map.The color scheme is defintely on the dark side though. There are way too many games that use desturated dark tones in them lately. And sometimes, the RNG can take you down pretty quick even if you have all the nice things in your posession.All in all, it has it's flaws, but it's still worth a good play.

												Awesome game. Definatly a "one more turn...." game. Crafting can be tedious but once you learn it, you basicly can craft your beggining gameplay style within the 10-15 turns before the first night. The combat system is unique in that it's 1D so basicly you are only concerned with spacing between you and your opponent, sounds too simple? You can have a fight go from throwing rocks at each other, to a knockdown drag-out fight, then the next moment you are choking the enemy to death and passing out on top of him due to blood loss.....zzzzzz....zzzzzz... You wake up and fibnish choking the enemy. End turn. You enter another encounter. No sight on enemy, next move "scan for enemy", "You have been hit brutally in the chest with a .45 fmj.", "You are caughing up blood!", "You have died due to internal hemorhaging."You can play this game and die, and still be laughing your♥♥♥♥♥♥off. Its a great game. You can also be 9/10th towards your goal and die of salmanale poisening that leads to vomiting on an open field area with no shelter as rain sets in. You died from not boiling an egg in turn #4, on turn like #200. START ANOTHER GAME!!!!!*Don't trust people who cough on you.*The strange meat is always human meat*Boil your water like Waterboy taught you.*Shards of glass and tarps will quickly become more involved in your life then ever before.*Item materiel quality = weapon durability = win

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												>Run into guy with Yukon backpack and bow>Decide to rob him>Guy has no arrows for his bow, I'm armed with a spear. Fight takes two seconds and he's knocked out>Take his bow and backpack, but decide to show mercy and leave my spear with him (wont be needing it now, planning to maker arrows at next campsite) to give this poor NPC ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ a shot>Get a few hexes away from my unconcious victim and set up camp, make arrows, prepare for next day.>Get woken up in the middle of the night by sounds around my campsite, cant see♥♥♥♥♥♥>Keep looking around to see anything>Suddenly I see the spear I left behind, it's in my chest.>♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ hit me straight in the heart.>I die instantly.10/10 would die by karma again.A really fun survival game set in a post apocalyptic world that's got a pretty unique form of apocalypse (or at least I don't think I've seen many other games with this sort of apocalypse) surviving in this world is challenging, food and water are hard to come by, and eating anything that wasn't cleaned properly could screw you over in the long run. The combat system is pretty interesting (altough I wish they'd impliment a different stamina system, so you wouldn't feel like taking a nap right after caving a mutants skull in). The story I described earlier is completley unscripted and just happened all on its own, as are pretty much all of the stories in the review, they might not happen to you personally but you'll probably have your own unique story of that one awesome/hilarious death. I definitley recommend the game to anyone who wants a challenging survival experience.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												This is a solid turn-based post-apocalyptic survival rogue-like (that's a lot of hyphens). I found it to be addicting and sunk a lot of hours into it when I had things that needed to get done, that's the way it goes with these types of games. Pick your starting characteristics and then wake up in a lab with something fearsome at your heals. Every action could lead to your death. It takes you a while to figure out how not to die from hunger, thirst, and exposure. Next comes figuring out whether you can handle combat and to what degree. After that you worry about what happened to you and the world, and where you need to go. All this is done while crafting or looting nearly all your equipment and dealing with the survivors of this world.You should try this game out, it's an experience you need to have.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Bought this game thinking this was a simple turn based rouge like to waste time to, ended up discovering way more. Once you can get past the learning curve (even so this game will find ways to ♥♥♥♥ you, you will die A LOT), there's a lot of really interesting things that occur plot-wise. With all the traits you can choose from, there are always different ways to handle or solve things during events or otherwise. Trust me when I say that spending a lot of time with this game will be very rewarding; there are a LOT of possibilities with this game.Definitely not a game for the impatient, I wouldn't recommend this to you if you're the type of person what will give up after carefully spending many hours building up your gear and supplies, then suddenly get killed by a seemingly random or unavoidable force. To me, that only adds more to the post-apocalyptic feel. Nobody how hard you struggle, there's never a guarantee that you're actually going to survive; you're never fully in control of the situation and there's always something much bigger than you out there. Sometimes it just takes sheer luck.

												This was one of my first buys on steam and my introduction into rogue-like games. I started palying this game in early access and learned to love this game. Despite the simple graphics and mesic do not be fooled this game is deep and difficult. I've lsot count of the number of times I've died. Sometimes it's heat stroke, or dysentery, other times it was a Bad Mutha smahing my head in like a pumkin in the middle of the night, I've been suffocated under a pack of Melon Heads and knocked out by scavengers. I've spent days having diarrhea after eating the wrong berries. Spent many sleepless nights waiting in dark abandoned apartment complexs for a pack of Dogmen to come and rip me to shreds. And despite all the deaths, all the battles,  and sleepless nights I keep on playing because the map is vast and there are so many places to go and people to talk to. Because the lore of the game is hidden in a multitude of places and despite the number of times I've lived and died at Zom Zom's I still come back for the BBQ

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Neo Scavenger, ahh, my old friend which i have returned to more than garry's mod...Right, down to business.So, you begin the game with picked skills slumped over a cyro-sleep tube, with a wolffman coming towards you. What do you do? Hide? Lock the door? Dump another cyrotube so that someother poor sod gets eaten?When you survive that (and it's impossible not to) you are thrown into the big, bad world of post apocalyptic Michigan. I've battled canabalistic mobsters over a bottle of whiskey, I've died of Cholera because I failed to purify my water, I've done a whole lotta things, but won't go into much detail due to the spoilers that would arise.Pros:Great gameplayGraphics fit wellRegular updates (Thanks Dan!)It just went into the finished game (Early Acess person)Lots of tools, bags, boxes, weapons and general stuffSteam trading cards (If that's something you judge by)Brilliant crafting system (the sun can be used for example)Tetris-like inventory that matches weight with space (Yes, I'm looking at you Skyrim/Fallout)Well-done combat systemFull range of medical conditions, and more are being added. (Blisters, cuts, lacerations, bruises, punctures, abrasions, burns, etc)Thoughtful (albiet incredibly frustrating) storylineCons:There are only two things I dislike:The first is the random encounters. Now that they are much more frequent, they play a bigger role in the game, however attempting to do the morally dubious option, nearly always gets you injured (not killed, but injuries very quickly can become fatal.) Two cases: You enter an arcade where there has been a slaughter by the fanatically religious Blue Frogs. A man croakes to you to help him. Helping him, gives you small items, but useful, bottles of water, lighter etc. Rifling through his pockets results in anything from a bruise to a cut due to him fighting back. Next example: A pimp comes up to show off a prositute, you can walk off, but because I wanted to see what happens, I asked if I could hire her. Two scenes later and i'm stabbed and bleeding out in a ruined apartment because suddenly my guy thought it was a bad idea and the pimp got angry at him.Lastly is the storyline, which ofter results in banishments, deaths, or injuries: You mut find out about your past, and to find the man who was paying for your cryosleep, you must visit two completley random locations, to get two completley random items, then have picked the almost useless hacking skill if you don't want to get chucked out of the city. And don't even get me started on the time I got run over and died due to not tipping at a cafe/eatery/diner type thing.All in all, NEO scavenger is a great game, with an active development and well thought out gameplay. Ten out of ten, buy this game already!

												Have you ever watched shows like Man vs Wild, Survivorman, Naked and Afriad (title is very similar to the early game, lol), and a host of other survival-based shows and thought, "I would like to know what that is like, but I don't want to die."This is the answer.There are many horrifing, diabolical, grusome ways you can expire which include, but not limited to:-Starvation-Hypothermia-Sniped from 60 yards away by a UAV-Sniped from 60 yards away by an angry canibal with a hunting rifle and a scope-Blue Rot (like smallpox, but not)-Cholera (*Painful flashbacks to Oregon Trail*)-Gettind fried alive by an ADS (Area Denial System)-Getting your intrails forceably removed by a Dogman-Eating the wrong mushrooms-Eating the right mushrooms, and drinking infected water-Going to the house by the lake-Taking off your Copper Talisman-AND MANY MORE!!!!In all seriousness, it may be a flash game, but it's better than the majority of Triple-A Games released in the past 2 years.

												A friend of mine designs games and I wanted him to make a game where you were dropped into the desert and had to use what was around you to survive. He said he was too busy making aa tank game called shellshock skirmish, so im glad to have gotten round to finally purchasing neo scavenger. After being on my wishlist for a long time I picked it up on sale and its worth it and worth spending the time on. Using your brain to figure things out rather than being on a guided tour is a refreshing aspect not allowed in many games and theres plenty of small details and replayability to be had. Not a game for those who enjoy giving up as you will die many times, each time figuring things out more and more. On one of my plays through I had a good haul of equipment 7 days in and was progressing with the story (there is a story, you have to find it!) when I stupidly setup camp in a bad place and was murdered in my sleep, in another playthrough after just making it to the east coast i died from an infection from having drunk infected water on the trip!All together this is worth your time and the turn based nature allowd you to relax and play alongside doing something else like checking your emails or cooking :)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
												This game drops you right into conflict: you wake up amnesiac, barefoot, naked, with a hungry wolf-thing in the adjacent room of a cryogenic facility.The first second of the game is pretty much the last time you won't be desperately hungry, thirsty, hypothermic, exhausted, bleeding out, diseased, hunted down, or some gruesome mix of these things.From there, the game revolves around challenging resource management as you explore a large hex-titled world looking for supplies and answers.Do you leave behind the squirrel-trap or the cleaver?Do you carry the sleeping bag or the rifle with 5 bullets?Do you risk alerting the raiders nearby with a bonfire or do you let the cold weather grip you a bit tighter for another sleepless night?Do you eat the rancid meat or do you risk a fist-fight with another looter to see if they have food?Do you slowly drag their corpse to the woods to cook their flesh or do you press onwards into the fog of war?Do you run to your next destination and get there in a day or do you silently sneak there and get there in three?Until NEO Scavenger, I had no idea a turn-based hex-tiled game could compel such a convincing post-apocalyptic desperation.My advice to you is to just jump in and hang in there until you've spent a couple hours. To be honest, I didn't even like the game at first until I'd suffered about ten deaths or so. Then I began to understand and get a glimpse of what the game had to offer. Like when I let a bandit limp away from a fight only for him to come back five turns later to kill me in my sleep with the cleaver I left behind at a salvage site a few tiles away.It also sometimes feels like you aren't making any progress since it's so easy to die (permadeath), but soon you realize that you're surviving a little longer every attempt - 3 days, 5 days, 1 week, 2 weeks. And the game just gets better and better as you begin to master it. What used to seem like a basic combat system turns out to be a nuanced one. What used to seem like a pointless skill/ability becomes your favorite. etc.My only complaint is that the UI is sometimes a bit tedious. For example, having to put down the sleeping bag every night and remember to pick it back up in the morning. Or doing the same 10-mouseclick dance with the crafting system to chop wood, light a fire, cook meat, and then eat the meat. But then again, you're usually so happy to find meat that 10 or so clicks is a small price to pay.Also, due to the crafting system UI, it's tedious to answer the question: "What can I craft with the things I currently have in my inventory?" As I accumulate items, I often find myself flipping through my recipes to see if I can make anything useful, only to do it again in five turns to see if anything changed. The game would benefit from a quick-view of "Here are the items you can currently craft" with the ability to click those items to instantly make them.However, the grid-based inventory management system is a fun minigame in itself. It really is addictive to answer questions like "Should I put the pistol with zero bullets in my pocket or should I fill my pocket with these gummy bears?" - Oh wait, your worn-out pants are going to disintegrate in about five turns, but you'll probably get hunted down by a mutant wolf before you have to deal with that.Good luck!

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
Early Access Review
								Well, if you're into games like FTL, or df in the way you pretty much lose no matter what, this is your game! GAMEPLAY:In every way its a flash game, as most of us gamers believe, flash games suck for the most part. Though, this game is interesting and enjoyable. There are wolfdogs(kind of like a warewolf but dog instead....first encouter creature) and melonheads(science experiments gone wrong?), then you have good old raiders and looters. The AI in this game is really good! It tracks you(every time you move you have tracks layed down, and the AI can/will follow them if you dont hide them. There are skills that allow you to scavenge better, like lock picking. You can build things with machanic, etc. There is a large crafting system, vehicals to pull/push your stuff around(aka sleds, shopping carts.) So, all in all if you're like me, meaning you pinch every penny and get at least 20+hrs from every game, then this is most likely for you. 10/10 would buy.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												Neo Scavenger is, in my opinion, one of the greatest survival games ever put to market.I strongly advise you to play the demo before you decide if you want to purchase this, as how you feel about the inventory system will likely make or break the game for you.It's brutal, at times tense, at times it may feel unfair, but there's genuinely no other game like it out there, especially in the survival subgenre.The combat is rough, dirty and unforgiving. Get shot? I hope to god you know how to treat that because you're not walking away until you've got that under control.  The environment is dirty, broken down and makes finding food so difficult you're likely to consider cannibalism a few times.If the price seems a bit high, play the demo a few times and see how you like it. I've already sunk 30+ hours into the game and I still haven't beaten it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								I cannot express my love for this game enough.I've always been a fan of minimal graphics games which can deliver such a compelling, engaging story and survival based-gameplay. Every step through the Hex world brings with it the chance to stumble on the thing you most need to survive. Or turn out to be something which leaves your bloodied, broken, bacteria-ridden body crawling back to one of the last bastions of human civilisation.When my character was dying of thirst and racing back towards the city gates, the howls of dogmen in the background, I felt every slick of the mouse which was one step closer to salvation. A rush without the need for a next-gen PC :PThe inventory management takes me back and time can be spent organising your goodies and packing the essentials close to hand.The developer is fantastic, responds to the players and is constantly evolving the game to new levels of awesomeness!Do it. Do it now. Brave the wastelands!Sidenote; multiplayer would be an awesome addition, no matter how slow it might go.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is one that I have been wanting for a while now. I happened upon it while browsing games to but after I sold my Australium Wrench and out of all the games I have purchased, this one is probably one of the Top 5 Most Addicting. The ability to choose your own abilities and weaknesses at the beginning allows you to create a survivor based on what you personally think you can do (and each trait seems well balanced, though with some combinations *cough* 3 melee traits *cough*). With a realistic inventory system (carry only what you could actually carry with two bare hands), difficult combat, and the harsh environment constantly wearing you down, the depth of this game is the most unreal part. Other than the fact that I keep dying because the damn scavengers run faster than I can kill them and a lack of much wildlife, resulting in me starving rapidly, even with a slow metabolism.Plus my character got addicted to human flesh and went insane because I couldn't find anything else. 11/10EDIT: Shot a thug with 3 arrows. He then procededs to rip them out one by one and stabs me to death with them as all 3 broke off inside of me, even though i proceded to club him in the head with a crowbar. Shouldve used the bullet that couldve bought me 10 meals...

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								ANOTHER terrific retro game! If you think "Under-Rail" is intriguing (another steam title) this is another gem in that vein. A perfect blend of RPG and Rogue-like, you are thrust into the post-apocalyptic world with no idea of what has happened and the whole open world to find out what the hell is going on. Brilliant turn-based fare, and really easy to get hooked on. This game reminded me of the day when games had to offer greatness in other ways, because it was before a time graphics could sell your product. Instead, it enthralls, intrigues, challenges, and keeps you drawn with it's personality. Recommended. I am so thankful games like this are still coming out!! <3

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								Funny how a $10 dollar flash game mangages to deliver more visceral, tension-packed combat using only text then most AAA "action" titles. A prominet example is when a werewolf sneaks into my camp in an abandoned office bulding. Luckily I woke up before it mauled me and grabbed my rifle, at this point a glorified club on account of using all my ammo to kill melonheads the previous day. I spent the rest of the night partaking in deadly tango with a werewolf for a partner, knowing the slightest miss-step would spell death for me. He would attack, I would either dodge or parry with the butt of my rifle. Evantually, maybe out of impatience, the werewolf made a flurry of attacks that I easily dodged, giving me the opurtunity to smash his face with my rifle, stunning him. Suffice it to say he didnt last long after that, and by morning I had a new coat and a comfortable amount of meat. Two days later I died a ♥♥♥♥♥'s death, but to elaborate more would give major spoilers. Hint: remember to pay tips, mkay?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								I just wanted to do what I can to try and promote this amazing game. I am absolutely loving it and I think it deserves a little more praise and hype. It's a single player, post-apocalyptic, turn based, permadeath, hex-mapped, rogue-like, rpg. I love these flavour of games and now that I have a tiny baby to look after these days, I thought I might try something more 'pausable' because I may have to suddenly be elbow deep in doodie duty at a moment's notice. Which is something that you just can't reconcile with games of unforgiving immediacy like DayZ.There are some great intro tutorial videos on Youtube that explain the slightly foreign quirks of what is basically a gui format you should be comfortable with.There is a free demo version available on the Steam Store, so you can check it out fearlessly before making up your mind.Should be a big hit with my Tabletop folks.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												Good lord is this game hard.Trust me when I say this, this game holds no punches. Think pixelated turn-based STALKER. It's one of the best games I've played in a while. Turn-based combat is normally a huge hurdle for me, but this game does it really well. You WILL end up being so hungry you will resort to cannibalism (No, really, this game has cannibalism). All the combat is text based, but instead of leaving a lot to be desired, it lets you imagine how the event played out. Were you tripped and are desperatly trying to grab at your attacker or are you secretly planning to show weakness right before you lash out with a concealed knife? It's one of the more original titles out there and it's not in early access anymore. But don't take my word for it, try the demo! (Word of warning though, the demo is a lot worse than the full game)ADHD Version: Bash people's face in with a rock so you can steal their pants.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												Very fun turn based RPG, set in a post apcalyptic world of ruins and forests. random events are encountered, and enemies are abound. everyone is suspicious. you will die often when you first start playing, it will take time to get used to this gem. heres a hint, explore the cryo place you start at, and check it for a campsite. you can use it as an early base. there is A LOT of exploring to be done, and it is randomly generated every time, so there is very high replay value. you can pick various traits when you start off that will help you along the way, such as extra strength, electrician, mechanic, trapper, eagle eyed, etc, etc. these traits can be used at critical times to give you a slight, but needed edge in the game. i have still yet to see the entirety of it all, use every object, make every crafting item, explore the entire map or story. it has a lot to offer. HIGHLY RECOMMEND, this is an indie gem.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												There is something about this game.   I love it. I hate it. Sometimes it makes no sense.   I'm certain it's pure RNG. I mean, when I have a 99% chance of finding loot, I get nothing. Then I have a 5% chance and I find a backpack, a pot, water bottles, clothes.  The entire game feels like a crap-shoot, where skills and abilities mean far less than a random roll of the dice.   Aside from that, IF you get lucky (really, REALLY lucky), it's pretty fun. This is a game where one mistake, or one bad "dice roll", will kill you.   You will end up yelling at your monitor, but all in all, it's worth it!   7/10 because the dice roll means way more than skills.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								To the developers I love this game I have about 15+ hours of offline play as well as my online time and it is just great I love the permadeath, random encounters and traits features. But I would like to see more traits a new start instead of just starting in the room with the dogman all the time it just gets annoying. There should also be an in game guide for beginners to get them started instead of just forcing them to learn basic features. The good thing about this game is that it makes you think ahead like should I or should I attack this enemy to get his gear Considering his weapon do I have enough medical items if I do get injured. Another one of the cool things is how suddenly a battle can change one minute you can be shooting the S**t out of the guy then the next minute he caves your head in with his crowbar.  Considering your opponent is a big thing for example I was trying to kill a melon head then he starts calling for others so I started to fight them but then my guy got tired so I had to retreat. When I got out of the combat screen I saw that all 4 hexes in front of me were filled with melon heads which would have made me pass out if I kept fighting and could have killed me.  The things that aren’t that good about this game are not very major just things like the lack of types of enemies, traits, the same starting room all the time, no beginners tutorial, some overpowered enemies, how you can only put one weapon with a strap over your shoulder, sometimes there is a lack of enemies around and there could be more items like more bags, guns, melee weapons and clothing.But overall this is one of my favorite games that I own and not just on steam out of all my games. My recommendation is to buy this game it is easily worth the $10 but I suggest that people try the demo first. Note: many features of the game are not in the demo. 10/10 for me keep up the good work developers.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
												A good, fun survival game.I used to have a much more negative review, but the patches are consistent and this has become one of my favorite games. Great updates from the developer.Now, although my review is much more positive and this is probably one of my top indie games, I still retain my old complaints from before:You are referred to as "Player" which kindof kills the immersion. No way toname your character, no "Phillip Kindred" or "Phillip". Just "Player".The forced permadeath (as opposed to optional) and flaws of RNG (instances where a NPC will appear with a gun 4 feet away at Round 1, and shoot you instantly killing you, or stepping out of the Cryo Center beginning and encountering a dogman.) are also a bit stupid at times.When will developers learn that permadeath should always be optional? This is yet another developer who forces their playerbase to play the game the way the developer himself wants- not the way that is most fun. In this way, the bad design and RNG can instantly kill you, forcing you to lose hours of work!So for the fundamentalist "force your playstyle down their throats" mentality so many roguelike devs have, I do not recommend this game. If you don't mind this playstyle, even when it is not fun, then I definitely recommend.Also, the game is a bit easy once you learn the way to do things or read a guide. Once you learn that Spear + always 3 feet away = Easy Win in all Combat (unless they have a gun, in which you die instantly), some of the fun is taken away. Also, trapping turns the game into EZ mode.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Neo Scavenger, ahh, my old friend which i have returned to more than garry's mod...Right, down to business.So, you begin the game with picked skills slumped over a cyro-sleep tube, with a wolffman coming towards you. What do you do? Hide? Lock the door? Dump another cyrotube so that someother poor sod gets eaten?When you survive that (and it's impossible not to) you are thrown into the big, bad world of post apocalyptic Michigan. I've battled canabalistic mobsters over a bottle of whiskey, I've died of Cholera because I failed to purify my water, I've done a whole lotta things, but won't go into much detail due to the spoilers that would arise.Pros:Great gameplayGraphics fit wellRegular updates (Thanks Dan!)It just went into the finished game (Early Acess person)Lots of tools, bags, boxes, weapons and general stuffSteam trading cards (If that's something you judge by)Brilliant crafting system (the sun can be used for example)Tetris-like inventory that matches weight with space (Yes, I'm looking at you Skyrim/Fallout)Well-done combat systemFull range of medical conditions, and more are being added. (Blisters, cuts, lacerations, bruises, punctures, abrasions, burns, etc)Thoughtful (albiet incredibly frustrating) storylineCons:There are only two things I dislike:The first is the random encounters. Now that they are much more frequent, they play a bigger role in the game, however attempting to do the morally dubious option, nearly always gets you injured (not killed, but injuries very quickly can become fatal.) Two cases: You enter an arcade where there has been a slaughter by the fanatically religious Blue Frogs. A man croakes to you to help him. Helping him, gives you small items, but useful, bottles of water, lighter etc. Rifling through his pockets results in anything from a bruise to a cut due to him fighting back. Next example: A pimp comes up to show off a prositute, you can walk off, but because I wanted to see what happens, I asked if I could hire her. Two scenes later and i'm stabbed and bleeding out in a ruined apartment because suddenly my guy thought it was a bad idea and the pimp got angry at him.Lastly is the storyline, which ofter results in banishments, deaths, or injuries: You mut find out about your past, and to find the man who was paying for your cryosleep, you must visit two completley random locations, to get two completley random items, then have picked the almost useless hacking skill if you don't want to get chucked out of the city. And don't even get me started on the time I got run over and died due to not tipping at a cafe/eatery/diner type thing.All in all, NEO scavenger is a great game, with an active development and well thought out gameplay. Ten out of ten, buy this game already!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												Alright, so you wake up in some abandoned medical research facility, some sort of creature is pounding at the door ahead of you, using your affinity for mechanics, you lock the door and prevent it from getting in. Going outside, you notice its cold, so you scavenge a near by town for clothes, but its too late, you freeze to death.So one more try. Again, you wake up an abandoned medical facility with a monster pounding at your door. This time, you chose to excell in strength, so you decide to fight this thing head on. You take a few scratches, but otherwise you beat. Using your trapping abilities, you managed to make a cloak out of its fur, keeping you warm for the forseeable future. Right on! so you start scavenging, you come across some food, a butchers knife, so shoes. You are doing pretty good! Buuuuut remember those scratches from before? You never treated them and they got infected, so you die. Again. Third times a charm, no? So you start again. You kill the monster, you make a cloak, this time you manage to find some clean rags to cover your wounds and carry on. You scavenge, find a nice ole' shotgun to keep you safe, but you come across a stranger, you don't know much about this person so you ease your way up, you threaten them and they try to run so you blow them away. They start crawling, and you decide to finish them off and loot whats left of the innocent guys corpse. You get a little tired, so you rest in the woods when something wakes you up in the middle of the night. Its a feral dog, and oh♥♥♥♥♥♥ youre out of ammo. You decide to stick to beating the thing with the but of your gun, but its no luck. One too many bites means its game over.Incase you can't tell, you will die a lot in neoscavenger. Like...a lot a lot. The game makes no attempt to hold your hand, and that will inevitably turn some people off, while others will find this a refreshing change of pace. Neo is a tough game for sure, and the survival aspects are fantastic. Of course you have to eat, sleep, drink etc etc but you also have to make sure you don't freeze to death, make sure your wounds are tended to and don't get infected, make sure you have shoes so you don't get blisters on your feet, try and make some interesting moral choices along the way (Do you help the mother and her child escape from the cannibals? How about watching people fight to death in an arena for scraps of food?) All in all, I think Neo Scavenger is one of the gems of 2014. I didn't even know about it until searching through steams library. I think if you're a fan of the survival genre and want something that's tactical with a lot of options and a nice change of pace in terms of story other than your typical "Oh my god! Zombies!" schtick, I recommend you check it out.

												Bought this game thinking this was a simple turn based rouge like to waste time to, ended up discovering way more. Once you can get past the learning curve (even so this game will find ways to ♥♥♥♥ you, you will die A LOT), there's a lot of really interesting things that occur plot-wise. To me, that only adds more to the post-apocalyptic feel. Nobody how hard you struggle, there's never a guarantee that you're actually going to survive; you're never fully in control of the situation and there's always something much bigger than you out there. Sometimes it just takes sheer luck.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								NEO Scavenger is an excellent example of survival RPG, bringing to mind other isometric games like UnReal World and Haven and Hearth.  This game masters the eerie, abandoned quality present in Fallout, and is as challenging to navigate.  You will realize the painful cost of each difficult decision.That said, the game features nothing by way of world building.  You can craft your own ramshackle gear from the broken remnants of the pre-war world and the often hazardous wilderness, but you cannot cultivate, construct defenses, or harvest natural resources apart from sticks, branches, water, and a few edibles.  Everything in the game is slowly decaying, and ultimately, so are you.  If you want a sense that your character has a future other than ending up the corpse someone else scavenges, this is not the game for you.I can honestly say I feel I've had my money's worth, but I don't think I'll finish the main story line.  This game may well leave you feeling like a murderous hobo, starving, infected, insane, who would gleefully pop out of nowhere and bludgeon some random stranger to death with a tree branch for a shoddy left boot and a plastic shopping bag.  But some people who enjoy the survival genre are looking for just that.Happy hunting, you psychopath.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								I really like Neo Scavenger. That's why there will be a long, LONG review on it. To Start, in even a short time of five hours, this game has left a great impression on me, from death to art style to dialogues... It's brilliant to begin with.Gameplay: You wake up in the middle of Michigan in some sort of year, in which humanity is back to the dark ages. Heal yourself, fight, scavenge, explore, talk, DAMN. And more. Every choice is better then Mass Effect's Endings and choices. DAAAAMN. 10/10Story/Quests: Survive in the apocalypse, find out who you are, DUN DUN DUN! Kinda cliche, but I will give the quests and random encounters credit. 7/10Dialogues: Pretty long, and most of the lore is delivered through it, which was somewhat of a let-down. However, the dialogue was good. I'll shame it for it's lack of a Dialogue Tree thus far. 7/10AI: The AI was great. Enemies were either cowards or knew how to fight, and their AI reflected that. With the combat system, it sets up a difficulty of COMPLEXITY, and that's either really good or bad game design. Here, it's done great. 8/10World Design: Semi-Dynamic, beautifully designed, randomly generated. It's luck, but damn good luck. 9/10Graphics: The game is set up in a 32-bit art style (I believe?), and the graphics look promising. Some shots of the world are detailed, even with 32 pixels. This game would have great graphics back in the 32-bit era, and good indie graphics. 8/10Sound: Haha. None. 0/10Music: There is a death track, thus far. Nothing special. 4/10The verdict for NEO Scavenger is an 8.75/10. It delivers well, and it's promising, even for late Early Access. Some small tweaks, and this could easily go over a 9.DayZ Review Gimmick: "Slept in an office, robbed and left with my plastic bag. 8.75/10, would sleep again."

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								I want to love this game, I really really do. I still would suggest it to people who like rogue-like(lite) games, and enjoy the survival because the survival is incredibly well done. I’m akso sure I will play more hours of this as time goes. With that said, my main issue is, unlike a lot of other permadeath games, this one has a story to tell, which might take you a long time to figure out when first playing, and it seems really interesting. The problem is, very few will ever get to experience that story as no matter how you gear up or character build, your character has the staying power of a lit candle in a hurricane. Little to nothing can stop a low or average enemy from getting in a lucky shot that will knock you out or kill you in one blow, costing you hours of game time. You will lose anything and everything you were working on. Having to re-create a character and starting again with the repetitive cryo facility wake-up scene. I understand this is the concept of this genre, but to have nothing left after working so hard to build up a character and losing 3-5 hours, for me, is frustrating. There are some who may love that, though. Once again, it’s not the permadeath for me, as much as it is the lucky cheap-shot.There are several mods for it already, though most just give more items and such. There are no saving mods as of yet, and the only way that truly seems to provide a means to see the story is some kind of invulnerability mod. Though removing the challenge entirely isn’t any fun at all. There is also a great mod out there that gives limited repair features that help shift the gameplay.With that said, the scavenging and survival system is absolutely incredible. Sometimes it can be a little over-complicated when you first play, but as a general rule most recipes make logical sense. Found a shard of glass? Use it as a cutting tool, wrap it with a piece of paper for a makeshift shiv, or use it as a weapon in dire need at the risk of cutting yourself. Found a glass bottle? Smash it and use it to threaten off an enemy. Use clean water or whiskey to sterilize your wounds before using those rags you sterilized in boiled water to stem the bleeding.The survival is the strongest aspect of this game and it shines over everything. From having to keep warm, to managing your health. Accidentally drank some bad water? Got sepsis from that wound you forgot to clean? You better find a place to hunker down and heal up with that bottle of anti-biotics you found in the locked shed with your makeshift lockpicks. Forage some wood and keep that fire going to stay warm and keep your immune system up, but make sure you set up some noise traps because people and…things can see it burning.The in-depth survival system makes this an amazing game to enjoy overcoming what I have said above, which is why I still suggest it. To see an indie dev put together a system that a AAA company could never have the creativity to pull off is a breath of fresh air. A game that will make you♥♥♥♥♥♥your pants in excitement just for finding a shopping cart.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												I personally really enjoy this game! Its very remenesent of original fallout titles, but I feel like this game expands on Turn based actions and combat. (for example, the tough ability, since it gives you the ability to headbutt someone.)I find that the abilities and flaws you can choose from give the game a lot of replay ability, and can be either incredibly angering, or extremely useful. The difficultly makes you really try to find good ways out of a situation, and plan ahead, but even if you plan you could freeze, dehydrate just a hex before a river, or find a pack of feral dogs/Looters. IT makes you actually panic when you see your character in danger, since you know that if you take one small step in the wrong direction, you have to restart.the random situations in the cities make you feel as though you really are helpless at times, becuase sometimes no matter what you do you wont be helpful, It paints a grim picture on how far humanity had fallen, and really helps set the scene.I've gotten to the DMC around 4 times, though its hard to last long after that for me! After finding out that strong + trapping the wolfman in the beginning of the game gives you a warm coat, Dehydration has been the worst for me. The only issues I've found with the game is that the "New game" and "save and quit" button are the same, so if you don't pay attention, you'll press new game by reflex, and I've lost 2 DMC saves to that. Another is that there's no setting to turn off permadeath, I know some people who would love to play this game, but the difficulty and permadeath keep them away(like a lot of people with dark souls, haha)A large glitch I've found is where you will be able to see the "scavenge" button, but it refuses to activate scavenging, though its available in the area (you are notified of scavengeable area's with a glass icon) and you have to turn your game off and on again to fix this. People have talked about this glitch for a long time now, but it hasn't been resolved. In short, the game is one I'll be recommending to a lot of people, Since I really enjoy it. (at the time of this review i've had the game for 2 days, and played 28.4 hours) If you like challenges, survivals, permadeath and looting, this is a game for you!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												NEO Scavenger is a hard-core survival game that takes place in a dystopian post-apocolyptic future.  The interface is simple and the graphics are basic but this masks a game that is flush with choices and possibility.  You awaken with nothing on you and no knowledge of what has happened to the world.  From the moment you are revived at the beginning of the game until you die due to exposure (or starve to death...or get torn limb-from-limb...or...) you are constantly pressured by the environment and your characters own survival needs to move ahead.  Death is far more likely than survival and the options to keep yourself going can get pretty deep and dark (for example, eating the flesh of other humans is a perfectly acceptable way to go...if you don't mind a growing ravenous hunger for the flesh of the living).  To be completely honest, I've yet to get anywhere close to the end of this game but  never stop revisiting it because the sheer diversity of options always leaves me feeling like there were other choices and that any of those other variations might have led to a profoundly different outcome (IE - death by some new lurking horror or contraction of an unexpected disease).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												After hours of hard work and days of in-game hard-earned survival, I was well off: a cart to carry all of my heavy items that would bog me down in combat, two compound bows stocked with arrows (enough to take down pretty much anything before it even knew what hit it), enough provisions to last until judgement day, and my trusty spear should things get a little too close for comfort. I set up camp for the night in a dense bit of brush, threw together a lean-to using a tarp I took off the corpse of some raider who thought he'd take me for all I was worth, laid out my sleeping bag, and went down for the night. Around 2 AM I was awoken by a massive *crack* in the woods near my position. Suddenly I remembered forgetting to hide my tracks, that's how it found me: a savage creature the size of a truck with teeth and claws protruding like foot-long razors. It saw me before I saw it, and that was all it took. Its claws tore across my chest before I knew where the danger was coming from sending blood flying all over the campsite along with what focus my eyes had achieved in the 5 seconds since their rude awakening. I was able to bring up my spear before the next attack landed and sliced open the creature's powerful arm, interrupting its strike. Vision fading quickly, I lunged. The beast let loose a shriek as the spear found its mark and dove deeper, piercing the heart. I'm not sure what gave out first, my legs or the crumpled heap of what was once the hulking black monstrosity.Somehow I dragged myself to my backpack and fished out some rags. I quickly bandaged the massive gash in my chest, ever mindful that giving in to the swirling blackness meant never waking up. I popped a couple of strong painkillers and some antibiotics to ward off the inevitable infection that comes with a reused bandage (like there was any other choice) and retreated back into the safety of my lean-to to rest and give my wounds time to heal.I must have dozed off, I'm not sure, all I remember is the pain. The incredible pain that only follows a crowbar being slammed into your knee. Two thugs stood over me, wearing what appeared to be the mismatched hides of dozens of small animals. I didn't even have time to cry out in pain before the the bigger of the two brought his crowbar down again, silencing me permanently.My vision churned and faded as I fell to the ground. Lying in an ever-growing pool of my own blood, my last sight was the assailants as they picked apart the life I had fought so hard for. As my sight turned to black, I had only one final thought:I should have stayed in that cryotube...Like an abusive relationship with a man who hates me, I keep coming back 11/10

content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
												Decptively simple, extremely nuanced, thoroughly frustrating.  It's one of those games that is easy to hit the wall right from the beginning and feel like you're not progressing.  If you keep trying and ram through, it's a very deep survival game.  Even the most mundane things cannot be taken for granted. A small cut can turn into a life threatening infection to not having shoes to walk across the map.  It is a very brutal and unforgiving game, but rewards you greatly when you manage to survive long enough to reach a town or even establish a base.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												I don't normally recommend games that I have no intention of finishing, but this one has enough depth and originality that I'll make an exception for it.  If an unforgiving TBS game that features old-school second-person narration*, puts you in the role of an amnesiac cryonics patient who wakes up in a hostile post-apocalyptic world, and forces you to realistically manage every aspect of your well-being with meager supplies sounds like something you'd enjoy, I can safely say you won't be disappointed.  It exceeded my expectations, which were admittedly low, in part because of the uncreative title (but ultimately, it just wasn't my cup of tea).  The one thing I think needs an overhaul is the combat.  It feels tedious and, in contrast with the rest of the game, unrealistic.  It feels unrealistic when my adversaries are fellow human scavengers but never say anything before or while attacking me, and it feels unrealistic when, after beating a guy so badly that the game describes him as being in severe pain, coughing up blood, suffering from a concussion, and blacking out, he nonetheless refuses to surrender and continues trying to kill me.  Still, that's only a problem because this is a game that focuses on realistic survival simulation rather than combat, making it a relatively small complaint.*It does not, however, stick to second-person, and instead frequently refers to the player literally as "player", which is annoying and breaks immersion, but now I'm just nitpicking.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								To the developers I love this game I have about 15+ hours of offline play as well as my online time and it is just great I love the permadeath, random encounters and traits features. But I would like to see more traits a new start instead of just starting in the room with the dogman all the time it just gets annoying. There should also be an in game guide for beginners to get them started instead of just forcing them to learn basic features. The good thing about this game is that it makes you think ahead like should I or should I attack this enemy to get his gear Considering his weapon do I have enough medical items if I do get injured. Another one of the cool things is how suddenly a battle can change one minute you can be shooting the S**t out of the guy then the next minute he caves your head in with his crowbar.  Considering your opponent is a big thing for example I was trying to kill a melon head then he starts calling for others so I started to fight them but then my guy got tired so I had to retreat. When I got out of the combat screen I saw that all 4 hexes in front of me were filled with melon heads which would have made me pass out if I kept fighting and could have killed me.  The things that aren’t that good about this game are not very major just things like the lack of types of enemies, traits, the same starting room all the time, no beginners tutorial, some overpowered enemies, how you can only put one weapon with a strap over your shoulder, sometimes there is a lack of enemies around and there could be more items like more bags, guns, melee weapons and clothing.But overall this is one of my favorite games that I own and not just on steam out of all my games. My recommendation is to buy this game it is easily worth the $10 but I suggest that people try the demo first. Note: many features of the game are not in the demo. 10/10 for me keep up the good work developers.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm really enjoying this game, except for a couple of details.- Picking [Strong] [Melee] [Tough] is overpowered. If anything. ANYTHING comes within melee range and you're carrying a branch, they can kill their♥♥♥♥♥goodbye.Got a rifle? Nevermind the bullets, just use the gun's butt and turn them into a greasy paste.- If you get a disease, that's pretty much the end of the game. I was in an extremely profitable run, but caught dysenteria, then bloated, then the symptoms subsided. It came back not long after, then I reached "the lights" and I traded almost everything for a medikit, which couldn't do anything to save my life.- There's an enemy that will call for reinforcements in the middle of a fight. While this is an interesting and welcome mechanic, IT DOESN'T MEAN THEY ARE CALLING MONSTERS FROM NEARBY HEXES. THEY ARE GENERATING MORE OF THEM. I got into a fight with one of them, I was hiding and using a slingshot and by the time I managed to kill the first, 4 more had shown up. By the time I killed the next, 3 more had appeared. I kept picking them off, but more kept being summoned.Had it not been for the lack of ammo, I wonder if they would've kept spawning infinitely?- It's turn based, but sometimes my actions are limited. Sometimes I get 5 actions per turn, sometimes, I just get 1, and I get no explanation as to why.Like any good roguelike, it relies in random chance.It has a very interesting crafting system that uses the skills you picked and an array of "substitute materials" in which it specifies what *kind* of item you need to craft."Waterproof, fireproof container" may refer to a pan or a glass bottle, "sharp edge" may be a piece of glass, a shiv, or a knife...It's a very interesting game, which is a bit frustrating at times. If you get out of a bad fight alive, you're likely to die anyway.Combat is turn-based with options for actions, which will vary depending on what you picked for skills. For example, picking [Tough] will allow you to headbutt an oponent sometimes, and the [Trapping] skill will let you lure an enemy into a makeshift trap.Crafting is relatively easy. Drop the right items and skills into a grid, click the "craft" button, presto. You got yourself a new bow.In the end, yes, it's still early access, but it's still fun, complex and interesting. I had a smile on my face when I fought a big, furry monster barehanded, took no damage, and got a "video recording of you beating the crap out of a wolf-man barehanded".I like a game with a sense of humor.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												The gameplay itself is simple and uncomplicated and the whole setting is equally involving; there's so much to explore, which is a big plus.  However, the game's mechanics can be set a little too high.  Deleting saved games when your character dies (which can be a little too easy at times) makes it extremely difficult to actually explore a world that's otherwise very interesting.  No amount of wit or cunning will help when you're ambushed by three to four feral dogs simultaneously while sleeping and ripped apart in a hopeless battle with no escape.  However, the fact that the game is extremely mod-friendly (with a whole section devoted to it on their website) redeems the game, enabling the player to customize their game to their own individual preferences.  The basic "out-of-the-box" game itself is hard, but the mods can make it as challenging as the player wishes.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
 Survival done right NEO Scavenger is another survival game set in a post-apocalyptic scenario where your mission is to, you guessed it, survive. Lately I've noticed that many games of this genre are, for the most part, shallow and very boring. Whether it's the oversaturation or my lack of interest, but I just haven't been able to find a good realistic survival game to spark my interest. But then comes Blue Bottle Games and gives us this fantastic, well-thought-out RPG that I just can't stop playing.The gameplay is probably my favorite part about it, because it involves turn-based strategy, the best kind of strategy that fits these types of games so well. You will cautiously think about every next move you make. The style is similar to games such as Wasteland or S.T.A.L.K.E.R. but the difficulty resembles that of a Dark Souls game.I think it speaks volumes when an indie game does a much better job at creating a world so dark and brutal that will make you dread every moment you explore it than most AAA titles with their overblown visuals and lack of originality. Just to make it clear, this one of the best survival simulations that you can experience, this game does not favor sloppiness, you will die until you learn how to survive the wasteland.HIGHLY RECOMMENDED! 10 shoes/10

content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												This is a great game, it has story perfected, combat mastered and scavenging done in a interesting way. The start of your insigificant adventure as one of thousands of survivours is new with your main problem of navigating the menus and learning the simple things like what you need to throw in the crafting pit to make a fire. Past that things are easy to pick up on. The combat is self explainitory with its buttons being 'Kick' or 'Sprint away'. Scavenging is a odd task with you choosing what to use to improve stats of your search with 'Lighter' improving chance of finding things and lowering risk and stealthlyness.The one problem is that there are preset things you find in the same place every time you play. One is where you find a monsterless warm sleeping bag in a car if you are freezing. You eventually just see the picture and click 'Take' as you run off with Lemming#12. The story while great is repetitive and very soon you will see your self skipping all that wonderful text some guy has lovingly made.As negitive this note is do not mistake it as harmful ranting. If the problem(s) I pointed out are real turn offs for you don't spend the fifteen bucks. If you can ignore them like me and can see the quiality and work of this game it is worth it. [T]/

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												I hate roguelikes. At least I thought I did. Maybe I just hated and the general culture and mentality of their fiercest fans, and the developers who used it as a cover for not balancing their game. I love NEO Scavenger. This dev put in to work, as I saw through early access, to make the game fair, not just hard. There is very little luck, good or bad, in this game. Just consequences. And the fact that no two lives are lived or died the same means the replayability doesn't fall into the bitter repetition that made me think I hated roguelikes. I don't hate roguelikes. I hate bad games. This is not a bad game. Not by a long shot.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												Imagine if wasteland, Fallout, and stalker all came together and had an orgy. This is their love child. Hands down one of the best survival games I've ever played.Pretty much nails every aspect of survival as it should. Unlike most games you actually have to boil water, not eat every berry you find and not just place a cloth on a severe cut. The thing is if you have knowledge to survive in the wilderness in real life it makes this game a bit easier to play.I say a bit easier because in reality this can be a very difficult game. Expect to die loads of times before getting the hang of things. However, the game is fun and different enough on each playthrough to keep you going. Lots of times you might run across events or other things that you haven't before.Another reason I love this game is all the twists and turns you'll go through when you start uncovering the well hidden story in newspapers and when you first wake up.The game doesn't look bad and definitely gives me nostalgia to those old post-apocalyptic video games. You can do pretty much whatever you want to. If you want to run at a guy wielding an ak-47 with a stick, you can. If you want to run around naked stealing other people's stuff, you can. If you want to make a suit of tinfoil and become a crazy hobo you can.There is music in the game and it's pretty good, almost sounding like something that would be in the half life series. Sometimes the only sounds you'll hear is the various birds and critter chatter giving you a real sense of isolation. Although when you spot an event or something interesting one of the tracks might start up providing a cool atmosphere.It's really hard to talk about this game without spoiling anything, but what I can say it's one of the best survival post-apocalyptic games out there. So while you can go running through the woods butt-naked, you can also try and discover who you are and what exactly happened to the world around you. The choice is yours.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												This game is very fun, and incredicly frustrating. I cannot stress how easily you will die.Killed by a dogman, 3 hours into the game (no weapons aside from fists to fight with).Brought a knife to a gunfight thinking the enemy didn't have bullets (a rare and extremely expensive commodity).Didn't have Botany skill, died from posionous foods (berries and mushrooms).Got infections from having dirty rags on wounds.Drank bad water.Tripped in combat.Random encounters.The list is unending.But through it all, this game is a lot of fun. After the 5th or 6th try, you start to get the hang of it (as long as you choose the same skills in the beginning). Get used to living off the land, by the way. Hoarding is good, but make sure you don't keep everything on you, you only have so much room.Some good advice, you ask?Botany makes for eating on the run, as well as making tea that helps boost your immune system (very important).Ranged skill allows you to make bows/arrows, as well as slings (early game weapons), as well as use pistols, rifles, and shotguns more efficiently (more late game (as far as late game exists) weapons).Always equip better durability gear.ATN members are naturally friendly, and won't starts fights. They are, however, pretty strong, and will end them if you aren't similarly equipped, or ambushing them. (eaiest way to tell them from others is they have white faces, and mohawks)Members of the Blue Frogs should be avoided, especially in melee combat. Just being near them gives you a chance of getting sick.But most importantly...Don't take off the Bronze Talisman...

												One of my favorite rougelike games in recent memory. I actually really enjoyed learning all the mechanics of survival, and going from only being able to survive for less than a day reliabily to learning how to survive for days and weeks on end was really rewarding.I must have spent 30 hours learning the systems, and around 2-3 hours for a winning run. I only wish that there was more content: it felt like the game was only just getting started by the time I had won. Then again, I guess it does make sense to end the game when you're getting a run to the point where you're pretty self sufficiant. It could get a bit boring otherwise.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
												Decptively simple, extremely nuanced, thoroughly frustrating.  It's one of those games that is easy to hit the wall right from the beginning and feel like you're not progressing.  If you keep trying and ram through, it's a very deep survival game.  Even the most mundane things cannot be taken for granted. A small cut can turn into a life threatening infection to not having shoes to walk across the map.  It is a very brutal and unforgiving game, but rewards you greatly when you manage to survive long enough to reach a town or even establish a base.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												I don't normally recommend games that I have no intention of finishing, but this one has enough depth and originality that I'll make an exception for it.  If an unforgiving TBS game that features old-school second-person narration*, puts you in the role of an amnesiac cryonics patient who wakes up in a hostile post-apocalyptic world, and forces you to realistically manage every aspect of your well-being with meager supplies sounds like something you'd enjoy, I can safely say you won't be disappointed.  It exceeded my expectations, which were admittedly low, in part because of the uncreative title (but ultimately, it just wasn't my cup of tea).  The one thing I think needs an overhaul is the combat.  It feels tedious and, in contrast with the rest of the game, unrealistic.  It feels unrealistic when my adversaries are fellow human scavengers but never say anything before or while attacking me, and it feels unrealistic when, after beating a guy so badly that the game describes him as being in severe pain, coughing up blood, suffering from a concussion, and blacking out, he nonetheless refuses to surrender and continues trying to kill me.  Still, that's only a problem because this is a game that focuses on realistic survival simulation rather than combat, making it a relatively small complaint.*It does not, however, stick to second-person, and instead frequently refers to the player literally as "player", which is annoying and breaks immersion, but now I'm just nitpicking.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												After hours of hard work and days of in-game hard-earned survival, I was well off: a cart to carry all of my heavy items that would bog me down in combat, two compound bows stocked with arrows (enough to take down pretty much anything before it even knew what hit it), enough provisions to last until judgement day, and my trusty spear should things get a little too close for comfort. I set up camp for the night in a dense bit of brush, threw together a lean-to using a tarp I took off the corpse of some raider who thought he'd take me for all I was worth, laid out my sleeping bag, and went down for the night. Around 2 AM I was awoken by a massive *crack* in the woods near my position. Suddenly I remembered forgetting to hide my tracks, that's how it found me: a savage creature the size of a truck with teeth and claws protruding like foot-long razors. It saw me before I saw it, and that was all it took. Its claws tore across my chest before I knew where the danger was coming from sending blood flying all over the campsite along with what focus my eyes had achieved in the 5 seconds since their rude awakening. I was able to bring up my spear before the next attack landed and sliced open the creature's powerful arm, interrupting its strike. Vision fading quickly, I lunged. The beast let loose a shriek as the spear found its mark and dove deeper, piercing the heart. I'm not sure what gave out first, my legs or the crumpled heap of what was once the hulking black monstrosity.Somehow I dragged myself to my backpack and fished out some rags. I quickly bandaged the massive gash in my chest, ever mindful that giving in to the swirling blackness meant never waking up. I popped a couple of strong painkillers and some antibiotics to ward off the inevitable infection that comes with a reused bandage (like there was any other choice) and retreated back into the safety of my lean-to to rest and give my wounds time to heal.I must have dozed off, I'm not sure, all I remember is the pain. The incredible pain that only follows a crowbar being slammed into your knee. Two thugs stood over me, wearing what appeared to be the mismatched hides of dozens of small animals. I didn't even have time to cry out in pain before the the bigger of the two brought his crowbar down again, silencing me permanently.My vision churned and faded as I fell to the ground. Lying in an ever-growing pool of my own blood, my last sight was the assailants as they picked apart the life I had fought so hard for. As my sight turned to black, I had only one final thought:I should have stayed in that cryotube...Like an abusive relationship with a man who hates me, I keep coming back 11/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								You either live long enough to see the source of the lights to the South-East, or you die from hunger, dehydration, hypothermia, or by a single attack from another human you couldn't sneak away from in the first few days.While you have a choice of skills at the start, the majority of the game is strongly effected by luck.  Luck of loot found, luck of places to camp in, luck during encouters; a single fluke can kill you.  With permadeath a constant fear, one must be wise about every action taken.It's a good turn-based survival, almost table-top-like game.  Your real entertainment will be seeing how long you can survive in this post-apocalypse world.  You have to use your imagination for most of it, but to those who enjoy roguelikes or table-top strategy games will find this a good buy.There's a demo; if you're even the slightest bit curious, TRY IT.  (there are things omitted from the demo, but it'll give you a very good idea of how to play the game)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Do you like an intense game that rewards player skill, encourages thoughful play, and punishes reckless play styles? Do you like a game with a broad open world with plenty to explore and do? Do you like running screaming from crowbar weilding maniacs?Well, Neo Scavenger has all of this and more. This game with torture your psyche and leave you begging for more. This game is an intense and brutal introduction to a realistic post social collapse world. A world of monster, and maniacs. This game with♥♥♥♥♥♥you off, and bring you to your knees in frustration, and yet, at the same time, leave you cackling maddly after barely skating by in a pitched battle with an all too lucky looter. This game will delite and agrivate you in fairly equal parts, and always give you a reason to pick back up and start a new game each time you find your character has once more gotten his skull caved in by one of the many hideous monstrosities in the game. The best part, most of the monsters in this game are flesh and blood humans, not mutants, not zombies, normal humans, driven to the edges of maddness by a cold cruel and uncaring world.Will this world drive you mad too? Are you up to the challenge of the Michigan wilds? Can you handle the constant threat of being someone or something else's next meal? Can you survive in the brutal world of Neo Scavenger? Or will this brutal world swallow you up without so much as a burp, as so many before?

												All-righty, nothing like waking up from a nice long cryo slumber with nothing but a hospital gown, a wrist-Band, and a 1970's medallion to your name. Then immediately being assailed by a cross between Cujo and Hulk Hogan, which causes you to flee for your life into the wastelands  of Detroit...(Which oddly enough is a lot like present day Detroit). It is all good for a while drink a little scavenged H2O and some berries ( I suggest the Botany Skill ). Ahh yes you can feel the rumble in your tunny as the unfiltered and tainted water begins to take it's toll. Soon you are crapping blood and running for your life to find the nearest tree so you can prolapse your♥♥♥♥♥♥, congratulations in the not so distant future amoebic dysentery is alive and well . After crapping yourself into the who's who book of The Screaming Squats, you realize you are now suffering from hypothermia...but it is ok you can pretty much scavenge , salvage, and construct most anything. That is of course if the Melon-Heads, and Bad Mutha do not find you and make you "Squeell Like a Big Boy! CAUSE YOU SURE DO GOTS A PERTTY MOUTH!". MAYBE YOU LOOSE IT AND AXE MURDER THE WHOLE LOT OF THEM WHILE THEY SLEEP...!Just do not eat them, eating human meat is for Punks...dont be a Punk, harvest a berry or eat a shroom....then start beating feat again...Just understand you are gona die...maybe you'll freeze or starve, or crap yourself to death, get eaten, electrocuted....who knows,but it will happen....But it is OK, because this is one fun as hell game...It will not try to dazzle you with BS, no super flashy graphics to hide the fact that it sux more than a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ named Eureka..No, see because if you took this game from Samuel L Jackson and dropped it in a bag of other games, and then same told you to give him his Sh*% back and you asked which one was his...Sam would tell you...It is the game that has Bad Mutha f%$#$% written on it. Listen if you have 15 or so bucks do yourself a favor and buy this game, buy it play it and then watch your character die horribly and love enjoy it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												So I've played this a bit before release so you know... Playtime not entirely accurate.I don't really have much to say or add but here goes:It's a minimalist, roguelike, RPG that manages to be intruiging without any visual elements. Obviously there are visuals and not just text, but they serve more to simplify the UI. The UI is pretty great honestly and it's something a lot of these hardcore roguelikes just don't give a crap about, so it's a breath of fresh air to say the least.I love the addition of the ambient soundeffects and the music. It livens up the experience quite a bit and makes it easier to immerse yourself.To sum things up: it's immersive like a great text adventure. Lots of descriptive text and important decisions with the addition of much needed visuals and soundeffects.It's just really solid and I recommend it if you like great text adventures and hardcore roguelikes. Just don't expect a flashy presentation.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												Nicknamed ''Hobo Simulator'' by some, this is THE game you have to play if you enjoy survival games. An unforgiving roguelike where you start with nothing and everything you scavenge is randomized, NEO Scavenger is played from a top-down perspective in a turn-based fashion. There is a story to go along with your desperate search for food, clothing and materials, and from what I saw, it's alright. However, nothing keeps you from simply playing as a wandering vagrant murdering people for their belongings.This game does not hold you by the hand. You will die repeatedly while learning the mechanics, but it's one of those games in which ''losing is fun''. For 10 bucks, it's a great deal.Some cons to take into consideration:- EVERYTHING is turn-based, including combat, which can get very tedious when you have to select the same option over and over again to run after a fleeing target, attack someone, etc.- Since scavenging is entirely randomized, it is entirely possible that you will find nothing to help you survive your first days, and die from exposure to cold/sickness/a blow to the head without really having the time to get into the game. This can be a huge turn-off for some.- A few bugs here and there.
